book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. Praise be to Allah who created creation from nothing, established it, and ordained within it the measures of His wisdom, then executed them. He exalts whom He wills by His wisdom and abases whom He wills by His justice. He is the One deserving to be worshipped and unified, sanctified and glorified. Exalted is He in His Essence and the perfection of His Attributes, and He is Unique. And I send prayers upon our Master and Prophet Muhammad, who straightened the foundations of the Sharia, clarified its paths, and paved them. May Allah's prayers be upon him and upon all the Prophets and Messengers, always supported, and upon his family and companions. As for what follows: The one in need of his Lord, Abd al-Rahman bin Hamad bin Zaid al-Mughayri al-Lami, Ta'i by lineage, Hanbali by school, and Najdi by homeland, says: Some brothers asked me to collect a summary on lineage that includes the origins of the Arabs. I was not of the people of that field, but I was compelled to do so by people's lack of desire for this art, which was the habit of the Arabs before us. Allah Almighty said: (O mankind, indeed We have created you from male and female and made you peoples and tribes that you may know one another. Indeed, the most noble of you in the sight of Allah is the most righteous of you). Some commentators said: 'Peoples' (Shu'ub) refers to non-Arabs, and 'Tribes' (Qaba'il) refers to Arabs. It came in the Hadith: "Allah Almighty says on the Day of Resurrection: All lineage is severed except My lineage, which is Piety." And it came in the Hadith: "Learn from your lineages what enables you to know your kin, and join your ties of kinship with it." And the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "If you conquer Egypt, treat the Copts well, for they have dhimma (protection) and kinship." Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Learn lineage, and do not be like the Nabataeans of the Sawad (rural Iraq); if one of them is asked about his origin, he says: 'From such and such village.'" Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, was a genealogist, as was Sa'id bin al-Musayyib. Some wits said: "If you see a man hating the science of lineage, know that his lineage is mixed with non-Arabs." I selected this copy from books of lineage and history, such as Qala'id al-Juman by Al-Suyuti, Saba'ik al-Dhahab by Al-Suwaydi, Wasaya al-Muluk (Wills of the Kings), Al-Iqd al-Farid, and the History of Ibn al-Athir. I named it: "The Selected Book in Mentioning the Lineage of Arab Tribes." I also took from trustworthy men from the Bedouins and city dwellers present today. For as is observed among the Arabs, one of them might be in a tribe but attributes himself to another. The reason was the mixing of some with others through alliance and intermarriage, and the protection of some by others; thus they mixed. Yet, they preserved their merits and lineages; no one is called by other than his father, nor attributes himself except to his tribe in any state or place. There were among them those who attributed themselves to Qahtan, and the Adnanite to Adnan. The beginning of mankind is Adam, peace be upon him, the Father of Mankind. Ibn al-Jawzi and others said: Adam lived a thousand years after descending to earth, and it is said he lived longer. It is mentioned that Eve bore him forty sets of twins, in each womb a male and a female, and they all perished except the lineage of Seth. Ibn Jarir said in his history: Eve bore him forty children, and it is said one hundred and twenty. Between the death of Adam, peace be upon him, and the birth of Noah, peace be upon him, were ten generations, and it is said more. Noah is the son of Lamech bin Methuselah bin Enoch (Idris) bin Jared bin Mahalalel bin Cainan bin Enos bin Seth bin Adam. It is said in Al-Iqd al-Farid: Noah the Prophet, peace be upon him, is the Second Father of Mankind, upon him be blessings and peace, because those before him from the children of Adam did not have surviving lineage after the drowning in the Flood. The survivors are from the lineage of Noah. Allah Almighty said: (And We made his descendants those remaining). Noah had several children: Shem, Ham, and Japheth. The children of Shem: The Arabs, Persians, and Romans. The children of Ham: The Sudan (Blacks), Berbers, and Copts. The children of Japheth: The Turks, Slavs, and Gog and Magog. Ibn al-Athir mentioned in his history the descendants of Noah, peace be upon him. Wahb bin Munabbih said: Shem bin Noah is the father of the Arabs, Persians, and Romans. Ham bin Noah is the father of the Sudan. Japheth bin Noah is the father of the Turks and Gog and Magog. It is said the Copts are from the children of Qut bin Ham. He said the wife of Shem bin Noah was Salib, daughter of Batawil bin Mahul bin Enoch bin Cain bin Adam. He said: As for Japheth, he had children: Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras. From the children of Gomer are the kings of Persia in one saying. From the children of Tiras are the Turks and Khazars. From the children of Meshech are the Spanish (Ashban). From the children of Magog are Gog and Magog. From the children of Javan are the Slavs and Burjan (Bulgars).

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: He said: Japheth begot the Romans, who are the Banu al-Nazar bin Yunan bin Japheth. As for Ham bin Noah, among his children are Cush, Mizraim, Phut, and Canaan. From the children of Cush is Nimrod bin Cush; it is also said Nimrod is from the children of Shem. The rest of Ham's children are the Nubians, Abyssinians, and Zanj. It is said that Mizraim's children are the Copts, the people of Fayoum, and the Berbers. They are two groups: a group of Arabs and a group of this lineage. As for Phut, he traveled to India and Sindh and settled there; their people are his descendants. As for Canaan, from his descendants are Sindh and India, and some of them joined Al-Sham (the Levant); the Children of Israel fought them and expelled them from Al-Sham. As for Shem bin Noah, he had children: Elam, Arphaxad, Aram, and Ashur. From the children of Elam: Persians and Jurjan (Gog and Magog?) and Imliq (Amalek), who is the father of the Amalekites, from whom are the tyrants of Al-Sham called the Canaanites, and from them are the Pharaohs of Egypt. As for Aram bin Shem bin Noah, from his children are Thamud, the people of Salih. Their dwellings were in Yemen with their brothers Banu 'Ad bin Aram. They moved from Yemen after Banu Ya'rub bin Qahtan overcame them, so they settled in Al-Hijr; they are the people of Salih, counted among the Bedouin Arabs. As for their brothers Banu 'Ad bin Aram bin Shem bin Noah, discussion of them will come, God willing, when mentioning the classes of Arabs. As for Nabit, he is from the children of Nabat bin Mash bin Aram bin Shem bin Noah. The Persians are from the children of Tiras bin Masur bin Shem bin Noah. As for Arphaxad bin Shem, Salah (Shalikh) was born to him, and to Salah was born Eber ('Abir), who is the "Father of the Hebrews". To Eber was born Peleg (Falikh), meaning the divider, because the earth was divided in his time. To Peleg bin Eber was born Reu (Arghwa), to Reu was born Serug (Sarugh), to Serug was born Nahor (Fakhur), and to Nahor was born Terah (Tarikh), whose name in Arabic is Azar. To Azar was born Abraham (Ibrahim), peace be upon him. To Abraham was born Isaac (Ishaq), and to Isaac was born Jacob (Ya'qub), who is "Israel"; from him are all the Prophets of the Children of Israel and their kings. To Abraham was born Ishmael (Isma'il), who is the Sacrificed One (Al-Dhabih) in some opinions. From Ishmael come the Adnanite Arabs, and discussion of them will come when mentioning the classes of Arabs. To Eber bin Salah bin Arphaxad bin Shem bin Noah was born Qahtan bin Hud bin Eber. They used as evidence the saying of the Qahtani poet: 'Our father is the Prophet of Allah, Hud bin Eber... So we are the children of Hud, the Purified Prophet.' Some say, quoting Al-Masudi and Al-Tabari: He is Qahtan bin Hud bin Abdullah bin Rabah bin Al-Khulud bin 'Ad. In the Book of Al-Bad' by Ibn Habib: Hud bin Abdullah bin Rabah bin Harb bin 'Ad. They used as evidence for this the Almighty's saying: (And to 'Ad [We sent] their brother Hud) to the end of the verse. Some commentators said: He is their brother in lineage. They also used as evidence the saying of the Prophet, peace be upon him, to Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him: "All the Prophets are non-Arabs ('Ajam) except four: Hud, Salih, Shu'ayb, and your Prophet, O Abu Dharr." The correct view is that Qahtan is the son of the Prophet Hud, peace be upon him. Section: On Mentioning the Classes of Arabs. They are three classes. Their lands and homelands are the Arabian Peninsula, located in the southwest of Asia. It is surrounded by the Red Sea and the Wilderness of Tih (Sinai) connected to the Suez Canal from its west, the Persian Gulf from its east, the Sea of Oman which is part of the Indian Ocean from its south, and the deserts extending between the Levant and the Euphrates from its north. It is eight sections: Section One: Hijaz: Located southeast of Mount Sinai on the coast of the Red Sea. It is called Hijaz because it is a barrier (Hajiz) between Tihama and Najd. Section Two: Yemen: Located south of Hijaz, and to its north is the land of Asir. Section Three: Hadhramaut: East of Yemen. Section Four: The Province of Mahra: East of Hadhramaut. Section Five: Oman: Connected to the Persian Gulf from the north and south, and the Indian Ocean from the east. Section Six: Al-Ahsa: The islands of Bahrain in the Persian Gulf, extending on its coast to the Euphrates River. Section Seven: Najd: Its lands are elevated. It is in the center of the Peninsula between Hijaz, Al-Ahsa, the deserts of Al-Sham, and the province of Al-Yamamah. It connects to Al-Sham in the north, Iraq in the east, Hijaz in the west, and Al-Yamamah in the south. Its land is the best in the land of the Arabs. Section Eight: The Province of Al-Ahqaf: A low land in the country of the Arabs on the western side of the land of Oman. Al-Yamamah is counted in this section. Section: The First Category of Arab Classes, the Extinct Arabs (Al-Arab Al-Aribah / Al-Ba'idah).

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: First: Called Al-Ba'idah (The Perished). They are the pure first Arabs. Detailed news of them has been lost to us due to the passage of time. They were many peoples and tribes, descendants of Aram bin Shem bin Noah. They are nine tribes: 'Ad, Thamud, Amim, Abil, Tasm, Jadis, Imliq (Amalek), Jurhum the First, and Wabar. The seat of their kings was Sana'a, and they ruled Al-Sham and Hijaz. Tasm and Jadis ruled Al-Yamamah among them. Al-Yamamah was called Jaww in their time. Al-Yamamah was named after the woman who could see a distance of three days journey, called Zarqa' Al-Yamamah. When Hassan bin Tubba' killed them, he killed the woman. The story of this invasion is famous in history books. This nation is the oldest of nations after the people of Noah, the greatest in power, and the most intense in strength and impact on the earth. The Second Category of Arab Classes are the Arabized Arabs (Al-Arab Al-Ariba), and some call them Al-Muta'arriba. They are from the children of Qahtan bin Hud bin Eber. Their dwellings were in Hijaz. They were contemporaries of their brothers, the people of the First Class, allied with them and supporting them. They remained gathered in the desert, far from the kingship that their brothers the First Ariba had, until their virtues branched out in the earth, and their clans and tribes multiplied. They crowded their contemporaries, the sons of the First Class, seized the opportunity of the decay of their state, and wrestled it from them. Qahtan bin Hud bin Eber was the first to settle in Yemen and overcame 'Ad and the Amalekites there. This class of Arabs (the First) perished, and the last two classes remained: the Qahtanite and the Adnanite. The existing Arabs are from these two origins. Section: On Mentioning Qahtan. The book 'Wills of the Kings' mentions that Qahtan bin Hud, peace be upon him, bin Eber bin Salah bin Arphaxad bin Shem bin Noah, peace be upon him - and the scholars have agreed that he (Hud) is a messenger prophet sent by Allah Almighty after Noah, peace be upon him, as a bearer of glad tidings and a warner, and trustworthy with His revelation and message. He is the one about whom the Qahtani poet says: 'Our father is the Prophet of Allah, Hud bin Eber... So we are the children of Hud, the Purified Prophet.' They mentioned that Hud, peace be upon him, advised his sons, saying to them: "I advise you to fear Allah and obey Him, and to acknowledge His Oneness. I warn you against the world, for it is deceptive, not lasting for you, nor will you remain upon it. So fear Allah to Whom you will be gathered. And let not Satan deceive you, for he is a clear enemy to you." Then he turned to his people, advising them with what he advised his sons and admonishing them with what Allah Blessed and Exalted related about him: (And to 'Ad [We sent] their brother Hud) to the end of the verse. Their response to him was (O Hud, you have not brought us clear evidence) to the end of the verse. Then Qahtan, after his father, settled in Yemen and ruled it. It is said: He was the first to wear a crown and the first to be greeted with "Abayta al-La'n" (May you refuse the curse). They mentioned that Qahtan advised his sons - and he had children: Ya'rub, Jurhum, Oman, Hadhramaut, and Al-Harith as mentioned by Al-Bayhaqi. It is said he had ten children. He said to them: "You are not ignorant of what befell 'Ad to the exclusion of others when they were insolent towards their Lord, took gods to worship besides Allah, and disobeyed the command of their Prophet Hud, who is your father who taught you guidance and made known to you the straight path. Whatever blessing you have is from Allah. I advise you to be good to kin. Beware of envy, for it is a caller to severance. Your brother Ya'rub is my successor among you, so listen to him and obey. Preserve my testament, act upon it, and be steadfast upon it." Then Ya'rub bin Qahtan preserved his father's testament and remained steadfast upon it. He is the greatest king of the Arabs over Yemen, and the first whose people greeted him with the royal greeting. Ibn Sa'id said: He is the one who possessed the lands of Yemen and overcame the people of 'Ad there. He overcame the Amalekites in Hijaz. 'Ad bin Qahtan [ruled] over Al-Hijr, Hadhramaut bin Qahtan over the land of Hadhramaut, and Oman bin Qahtan over the land of Oman. Ibn Hazm said: From the children of Al-Harith bin Qahtan are Al-Aswur; they are the group of Hanzala bin Safwan bin Al-Rass. Al-Rass is between Najran and Yemen, and Hadhramaut to Al-Yamamah, mentioned in Al-Ibar. They mentioned that Ya'rub was the first to speak the broad Arabic language, and spoke its most eloquent, rhetorical, and concise form. Arabic is attributed to him, derived from his name. He is the one whom Hassan bin Thabit Al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him, mentioned in poetry elsewhere.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Then Ya'rub bin Qahtan gathered his sons and advised them, saying: "O my sons, memorize from me ten qualities that will be a remembrance and a treasure for you. O my sons, learn knowledge and adorn yourselves with it. Leave envy aside and do not turn to it, for it is a caller to severance among you. Avoid evil and its people, for evil brings evil people to you. Be fair to people from yourselves so they may be fair to you. Beware of pride, for it distances people's hearts from you. Adhere to humility, for it draws you near to people and makes you beloved to them. Forgive the wrongdoer, for forgiving the wrongdoer cuts off enmity and increases suzerainty (Siyah). Suzerainty with virtue is abundant virtue. The prestige entering upon yourselves, its beauty is your beauty. If the condition of one of you worsens, it is better for him to improve the condition of his neighbor. People only miss the one who is followed. Support the clients (Mawali), for they are your clients in war and peace, and their right upon you is like the right of one of you upon the rest. If someone consults you, advise him with what you would advise yourselves, for it is a trust placed upon your necks, and trust is as you know. Hold fast to manufacturing men (doing favors), for it is more useful that you lead others through them, and more likely to increase you in honor and pride to the end of time." It is mentioned that Yashjub bin Ya'rub took the Kingship after his father, and held fast to this testament unlike the rest of his brothers and clan, so he led everyone by his steadfastness on the testament and his preservation of it. Some genealogists said: I asked about the brothers of the Banu Ya'rub. It was said: The First Amalekites from the children of Aram bin Shem bin Noah, and the other group who are the inhabitants of Mecca and its surroundings from the children of Ya'rub, and their brothers Tasm and Jadis, and the tribe of Jurhum and 'Ad the Younger. Yashjub bin Ya'rub had mastery over it through loyalty from his brothers and all his clan. Then Yashjub bin Ya'rub bin Qahtan advised his sons, saying to them: "O my sons, I did not lead my brothers and clan except by preserving the testament of my father Ya'rub bin Qahtan, by acting upon it, and by steadfastness upon it. And my father Ya'rub bin Qahtan did not lead his brothers and clan except by preserving the testament of his father. And Qahtan did not lead his brothers and clan except by preserving the testament of his father Hud, peace be upon him, preserving it, and acting upon it. So remain upon what you found me upon, for it is what honored me." Then he spoke poetry in which he mentioned his son Abd Shams. Abd Shams, his son, is Saba; because he was the first to take captives (Saba) and capture prisoners. He built the city of Saba and the Dam of Ma'rib. The author of Al-Tijan said: He raided the regions; it is said he toured between the East and West, striking the rebellious land until he conquered it. He built the city of Ain Shams (Heliopolis) in Egypt and appointed his son Balyun over it. Saba had several children, the most famous being Himyar and Kahlan, from whom are the two great nations. Among his sons is Masruh, mentioned in Al-Iqd Al-Farid; this Masruh will be discussed later, God willing. Ibn Hazm counted among his children Zaydan and his son Najran, after whom the land of Najran was named. Al-Suhayli added: And among his children are Wael and Malik. They mentioned that Saba held fast to the testament of his father Yashjub, preserved it, and acted upon it, so he led his brothers and clan. He was the king of all and their pillar. It is said he raided Babylon with horses and conquered it, taking its tribute. He struck with horses and men in the land, and no land was mentioned to him but he intended it and conquered it. He toured the easts and wests of the earth, and thus was named Saba. Ibn Jarir mentioned him in his exegesis: Abu Kurayb Abu Usamah told us; Al-Hasan Abu Al-Hakam told us; Abu Sabrah Al-Nakha'i told us, from Urwah bin Masik Al-Qutayni, may Allah be pleased with him, that he said: "O Messenger of Allah, tell us about Saba, is it a land or a woman?" He (peace be upon him) said: "It is neither a land nor a woman, but a man from the Arabs. Ten children were born to him; six went to Yemen (Tayamanu) and four went to Sham (Tasha'amu). As for those who went to Sham, they are Lakhm, Judham, Amilah, and Ghassan. As for those who went to Yemen, they include Kinda, Al-Ash'ariyun, Al-Azd, Madhhij, and Anmar." Genealogists, including Muhammad bin Ishaq, said: His name originally was Abd Shams bin Yashjub bin Ya'rub bin Qahtan. He was the first to give glad tidings of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, in his early time. Section

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Al-Hamdani mentioned in some of his books that Saba gathered the people of his kingdom and the notables of his household and clan. He seated his son Himyar on his right and his son Kahlan on his left. Then he said: "O people, give me your covenants and pacts that if my right hand transgresses against my left hand, you will prevent it, or my left hand against my right hand, you will prevent it." So they gave him covenants and pacts on that. Then he said to them: "I did not mean by my right and left except Himyar and Kahlan. I am not safe from them differing after me in affairs. I did not take covenants and pacts from you except that you may intervene after me between whoever of these two intends evil and dissension for his companion, or if one of them seeks more than what is apportioned to him. Himyar is older than Kahlan, and his right is to be my right hand. Kahlan is younger than Himyar, and his right is to be my left hand. The share of Himyar in my kingdom is like the share of my right hand from my body, and the share of Kahlan in my kingdom is like the share of my left hand from my body. O people, whoever is fit for the Right of the Kingdom, call him to the Right, and look at who is fit for the Left of the Kingdom and call him to the Left." He said: So they handed to the Right the sword, the pen, and the whip, and judged for the Right with that. They said these are three things the Right works with, and the Left does not work with them without the Right in visions. He said: Then they judged that the owner of the sword is only fit for steadfastness and standing in his position. They judged that the owner of the pen can only be a superior, pleasing administrator. They judged that the owner of the whip can only be a politician (manager). Then they judged that standing, steadfastness, unraveling and binding, administration, training, and politics belong only to the Great King stationary in the House of Kingdom and enduring enemies wherever they are. They judged that the Head repels harm, conquers wars upon meeting, and bears responsibilities. They judged that the bow reaches the opponent and adversary from a distance. Then they judged that leading the reins of horses, enduring enemies wherever they are, repelling harm and conquering upon meeting, and opposing and confronting enemies is only fit for the Owner of the State defending it, shooting from its domain, filling its gaps, undertaking its wars, and repairing and blocking the frontiers, and he is Kahlan. So Himyar assumed the Stationary Kingship in the House of Kingdom and it was handed to him, and he was named Yamin (Right) due to sitting on his father's right. Kahlan assumed the Outskirts and Frontiers, their works, wars, opposing enemies, and confronting them wherever they were. Kahlan has upon Himyar the right of aid with money and succor, and Himyar has upon Kahlan the right of obedience and sufficiency in what he assumed. Himyar and Kahlan remained upon that, as did their children after them and their children's children. Then Himyar gathered his sons. Abu Muhammad bin Hazm said he had children: "Al-Hamisa', Malik, Zayd, Wael, Masruh, Ma'dikarib, Aws, and Murrah." He lived, as Al-Suhayli said, three hundred years. He was the first to be crowned with gold. He said to his sons in his testament: "O my sons, no two people gathered, supporting and aiding each other against five scattered people, but they overcame them and possessed their captivity. No five people gathered, supporting and aiding each other against ten scattered people, but they overcame them and possessed their captivity. Any group that overcomes forty men is likely to overcome two hundred, and overcomers of two hundred are worthy to overcome a thousand. No man is obeyed by one who repays him but he is obeyed by ten. No man is obeyed by ten whom he repays but he is obeyed by a hundred. No man is obeyed by a hundred whom he repays but he is obeyed by a thousand. No man is obeyed by a thousand men but he has certainly prevailed. Whoever prevails possesses, and whoever possesses has been given the utmost of his hope in his world. O my sons: obey the most rightly guided among you, and do not disobey Al-Hamisa', for he is my successor over you and my trustee among you. He is your sword; what is the spearhead without the spear? Nay, what is the spear without the spearhead? You are by Al-Hamisa' and for him, and Al-Hamisa' is by you and for you." Then Al-Hamisa' bin Himyar took the Kingship after his father, preserved his testament, stood firm on it, acted upon it, and treated them as his father Himyar treated them, walking among them with his biography. Likewise, Al-Ayman bin Al-Hamisa' took the Kingship after his father Al-Hamisa' and led his brothers and clan. Then when Al-Ayman took the Kingship after his father, he walked among the people with the biography of his father and grandfather, preserving all that reached him of the testaments of their fathers and ancestors which they acted upon, advised with, and preserved for the politics of the Kingdom and maintenance of the State. Then his son Zuhayr took the Kingship after Al-Ayman. When Zuhayr took the Kingship after his father, he was one of the best kings in conduct. Then he advised his son 'Arib bin Zuhayr - and he had no other - saying to him:

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: "O my son, the testament of your grandfather Saba bin Yashjub has reached you, and what the two separated upon on the day of testament and division—namely your grandfathers Himyar and Kahlan. So do not conduct any matter except what the two conducted from their time to this end. Advise with that whoever is fit for this matter among your children. I advise you to be steadfast on what you found me upon of justice among the subjects, overlooking the wrongdoer, distancing from harming the clan, and endearing yourself to them, for a man is nothing without his people even if he is mighty and high." Then 'Arib took charge after his father, stood firm on his testament, acted upon it, and treated them according to it. Then he advised his sons, who were four: Sabah, Najadah, Abraha, and Qatan. He said to them: "O my sons, I found honor, suzerainty, might, succor, obedience, and kingship revolve around six things. O my sons, I found suzerainty is not attained except by generosity, and there is no suzerainty for one who has no generosity. I found might in numbers wherever they are, and there is no might for one who has no numbers, and no numbers for one who has no clan. I found succor in favors, and there is no succor for one who has no favors. I found obedience in justice, and there is no obedience for one who has no justice. I found kingship in manufacturing men (winning loyalty), and there is no kingship for one who does not manufacture men. O my sons: Preserve my advice and do not disobey your brother Qatan, for he is my successor over you and the guardian of the Kingdom after me." He said: Then Qatan took the Kingship after his father and walked among the people with his biography and the biography of his ancestors. He entrusted the Kingship in his lifetime to his son Al-Ghawth, saying to him: "O my son, I did not entrust you with the Kingship out of desire to leave it, but I wanted to observe your conduct among the people and your politics in the Kingdom, and to know how their obedience is to you, so that I do not leave the world while I have a lump in my throat regarding your affair and the affair of the people. O my son, I advise you regarding your brothers to do for them what I did for you, to offer them your advice, and to lower your wing to them. I ask you to do with your clan what I asked you to do for your brothers, for comfort is only in the fingers, and the forearm is with the upper arm." Then Al-Ghawth bin Qatan held the Kingship during his father's life and after his death for a long time. He was one of the best people in conduct and the most steadfast on the traditions of his fathers and grandfathers. Then his son Wael bin Al-Ghawth took the Kingship after him. The testament of Al-Ghawth to his son Wael was this: "O my son, the Kingdom is a house Allah Almighty built for your ancestors, so they inhabited it with justice and beneficence. Likewise, I inherited it from those before me, and likewise I bequeath it to you after me with its habitation; so inhabit it with what your ancestors inhabited it with. Know that a house is a house as long as its walls are built and its corners raised, and no breach occurs in any of its structure, for a breach is followed by another. I advise you well regarding the subjects." Then Wael bin Al-Ghawth bin Qatan took the Kingship after his father and managed the Kingdom with a policy praised by the people of his time. Likewise, his son Abd Shams bin Wael took the Kingship after his father and walked among the people with the biography of his ancestors and grandfathers. This Abd Shams is the grandfather of Bilqis bint Al-Hadhhad bin Sharhabil bin Amr bin Muawiyah bin Shaddad bin Qatat bin Amr bin Abd Shams. None of these but ruled what Abd Shams and his father before him ruled, and their stories are too long to explain. Amr bin Muawiyah is known as Ibn 'Allaf bin Shaddad bin Al-Maqtat. Then the Kingship transferred from these to Himyar the Younger, who is Zur'ah bin Ka'b bin Sahl bin Amr bin Qays bin Muawiyah bin Yashjub bin Abd Shams bin Wael bin Qatan bin 'Arib bin Zuhayr bin Ayman bin Al-Hamisa' bin Himyar the Elder. It is mentioned that Zur'ah's conduct among the people was good when he took the Kingship, as was his son Shaddad bin Zur'ah. Zur'ah advised his son Shaddad saying: "O my son: If a king could dispense with people's opinions due to his own piercing opinion, superior intellect, perfect knowledge, brilliant manners, and acumen, and based on the past experiences of his ancestors which he preserved and narrated, encompassing the traditions of the ancients among his fathers and the kings of his people and the traditions of the past, I would be the person most able to dispense with sharing opinions, sharing with the Aqyal (princes), and the advice of advisors. However, a king must have a helper to aid him in opinion, commanding, and forbidding. He must have a counselor to carry some of what burdens him of that. And a son must have a testament from a father, whether the testament is little or much."

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: They mentioned that Shaddad bin Zur'ah - and in one copy Sadad with the un-dotted Seen, derived from rectitude (Sadad) - held the Kingship for a long time. No one from Himyar or Kahlan disobeyed him in his kingdom, which encompassed most of the earth and those in it. He walked among the people with the biography of his fathers, treated them according to the traditions of his grandfathers, preserved the testaments of the ancients among his ancestors, acted upon them, and stood firm on them until he died and the Kingship transferred to his uncle Al-Harith. Malik bin Himyar had conquered the people of Oman. His son Quda'a ruled after him, then his son Ilhaf, then his son Malik bin Ilhaf. Then war broke out between Malik and Al-Saksak bin Wael bin Himyar. Malik prevailed over Oman. After Al-Saksak, his son Ya'fur ruled, then his son Al-Nu'man succeeded him. Ya'fur is known as Al-'Arif. Maran bin Awf bin Himyar, known as Dhu Riyash, usurped authority from him; he was the ruler of Bahrain, then settled in Najran and busied himself with warring against Malik bin Ilhaf. When Al-Nu'man grew old, he imprisoned Dhu Riyash, usurped his command, and lived a long life. His son Asham ruled after him. At that point, the affairs of Himyar became disordered, and the Kingship became divided among factions (Tawa'if). Banu Kahlan used to rotate the Kingship with Banu Himyar. From the tribes of Qahtan, the Banu Zaydan bin Ya'rub bin Abyan bin Zuhayr ruled - mentioned previously - and this Abyan is the one to whom the Arabs in Yemen are attributed. Also ruling from them was Abd Shams bin Wael bin Al-Ghawth bin Hayran bin Qatan, mentioned previously, then his son Shaddad ruled after him, mentioned previously.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: It was said he is Shaddad bin Qatan al-Matat bin Amr bin Dhi Haram bin Al-Hawar. After him his brother Luqman. Then his brothers Dhu Shadad, Yatudh, and Marathil. Some say Dhu Wael and some say Dhu Madathir; he is Al-Harith, grandfather of the Tubba' Kings. The Kingship settled in his sons after him. He was named Al-Raish (The Featherer/Enricher) because he divided the land of Yemen, its plains, mountains, and valleys among his clans and helped them cultivate it. He brought out livelihoods for them, so the people and clans prospered, and some became independent of others and of much of what they needed from what he possessed; therefore, they named him Al-Raish. His name is Al-Harith. He was the first king to invent armor for his companions and clothe them in it. Ibn Sa'id mentioned from the historians of the East, and quoted it, that Al-Harith Al-Raish was succeeded by his son Al-Sa'b, who is Dhu al-Qarnayn bin Al-Harith bin Qays bin Sayfi bin Saba the Younger bin Ka'b bin Sahl bin Amr bin Qays bin Muawiyah bin Bakr bin Jashm bin Abd Shams bin Wael bin Al-Ghawth bin Qatan bin 'Arib bin Zuhayr bin Ayman bin Al-Hamisa' bin Himyar bin Saba bin Yashjub bin Ya'rub bin Qahtan bin Hud, peace be upon him. The name of Dhu al-Qarnayn was Al-Sa'b. He took the Kingship after his father Al-Raish. He is the one whom Allah established in the earth, and he reached its easts and wests. Allah mentioned him in His Book. He marched between the two mountains (Al-Sadafayn) and built the Dam against Gog and Magog, contrary to what some scholars, historians, and linguists claim that he is Alexander the Roman. For Alexander the Greek, builder of Alexandria, did not build a dam, though he was titled Dhu al-Qarnayn; this is a grave error. By this, they confused the weak-minded and contradicted the Great Quran, [claiming] that no dam exists. It is said: The Macedonian Greek or Alexander the Roman did not build a dam; rather, the one who erected the dams is Dhu al-Qarnayn, and his name is Al-Sa'b bin Al-Raish. Mustafa Al-Ghalayini mentioned in his book saying: Tilling Alexander the Macedonian as Dhu al-Qarnayn has spread on the tongues of many people, linguists, commentators, and historians, and it is a grave error. For "Dhu" is a purely Arabic word; Dhu al-Qarnayn is one of the titles of the kings of Yemen. Among them were Dhu Jadan, Dhu Kila', Dhu Nuwas, Dhu Nashatir, Dhu Ru'ayn, and other titles. Dhu al-Qarnayn is the one whom Allah established in the earth, whose kingdom was great, and who built the Dam against Gog and Magog; he is Al-Sa'b bin Al-Raish. Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, was asked about Dhu al-Qarnayn whom Allah mentioned in His Noble Book, and he said: "He is from Himyar." This strengthens that he is Al-Sa'b and that he is other than Alexander the Macedonian, builder of Alexandria. This is Greek and that is Arab, and both ruled a great kingdom. Understand this, for it is the truth from which there is no deviation. Abu Al-Fida verified it in his history, so refer to it when mentioning the Second Class of Persian Kings. The Arabs mentioned him in their poetry, boasted of him, and counted him among the kings of their people, calling him Al-Sa'b. It is understood from most poets that the name of Dhu al-Qarnayn is Al-Sa'b among the Arabs. Mention of Dhu al-Qarnayn also occurred in much Arab poetry: in the poetry of Imru' al-Qais, Tarafa, Daws, Madhhij, and others. In the book "Nashr al-Mahasin al-Yamaniyah" there is much that would take too long to quote. These poems are an indication that Dhu al-Qarnayn is this one and not the Macedonian. Then his son Abraha bin Al-Sa'b Dhu al-Qarnayn, mentioned previously, ruled after him. It is mentioned that he stood firm on the testament of his father Dhu al-Qarnayn Al-Sa'b, acted upon it, and preserved it. He was the first to set up flags and build milestones and signs on the roads and watering places; therefore, he was named Dhu al-Manar (Owner of Lighthouses/Signs). They mentioned that he struck into the rebellious lands from their east to west to conquer them and take their tribute. In some books, Khurasan is the brother of Fars, and their brother is Kerman and the Elder Kuraz (?), and their father is Japheth bin Noah, peace be upon him. As for the First Romans, they are from the children of Aram bin Shem bin Noah. Their brothers are the Slavs, Khazars, Lat (?), Kabul, China, Sindh, and India. All of these were conquered by Abraha after his father Dhu al-Qarnayn Al-Sa'b. Then Abraha Dhu al-Manar advised his son Amr Dhu al-Adh'ar, saying to him: "O my son, the Kingdom is a crop, and the King is the custodian of that crop. If the custodian excels in his care for it by watering it when needed, removing alien plants from it, and tending to it with protection from harmful beasts and birds, its harvest thrives, the custodian is praised, and the land is honored. If the custodian is otherwise, does not inspect the crop, and does not tend to it with protection and preservation, thirst weakens it, birds eat it, and beasts trample it; so neither the crop grows, nor the land is inhabited, nor the custodian is praised." He said: Then Amr Dhu al-Adh'ar took the Kingship after his father and went out inspecting works in the east and west of the lands. No people heard of him but they turned on their heels fearful and terrified (Madh'urin); therefore, he was named Dhu al-Adh'ar (Owner of Terrors).

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: He is the father of the first Tubba'. Al-Masudi said: He ruled for twenty-five years and raided the lands of the Maghreb. Kayqalus son of Canaan, King of Persia, marched to him. He dueled him, the armies of Kayqalus were defeated, and Dhu al-Adh'ar captured him. Then Amr Dhu al-Adh'ar advised his two sons Tubba' and Rufaydah, saying to them: "Others are ignorant of the Kingdom, its politics, care, and welfare, and what the King needs of diplomacy, favoritism, and opposition. The Kingdom is but a millstone turning on a pivot; if another pivot is made for it, the millstone stops, does not turn, its causes are disrupted, and the hope of its people is cut off. This is so you know that the Kingdom is not suitable for two unless one is the leader and the other the follower. You have known that the crown does not fit two heads, nor do they gather in a crown ever, just as two swords do not fit in one sheath." He ordered his son Rufaydah to obey his brother Tubba', and this is the first of the Tubba' Kings to rule. Then Tubba' took the Kingship after his father and entrusted the Ministry to his brother Rufaydah. To Tubba' belonged what belongs to the King, and to Rufaydah what belongs to the Minister. They remained so for a long time upon their father's testament. King Tubba' walked among the people with the biography of his father Dhu al-Adh'ar, spread justice and beneficence in the land, was granted awe, and was given obedience such as no one before him was given. He said: The cities of their kings were Sana'a, and the kings from Kahlan were in Ma'rib, three stages away. In Ma'rib was the Dam built by Bilqis, a queen among their kings. It is a dam between two mountains built with rock and bitumen. She preserved the water of springs and rains with it, leaving it there according to what they needed for their irrigation. It is what is called Al-'Arim. It is said: The one who built it is Himyar, the father of the Yemeni tribes. It is said: The one who built it is Luqman bin Sinad the Elder. And it is said Saba bin Yashjub bin Ya'rub built it, which is more appropriate. He diverted seventy valleys to it and died before its completion, so the kings of Himyar completed it after him. These Tubba's, the number of their kings in successive eras and long epochs cannot be counted. They surpassed the kings of Yemen to further than them in Iraq, India, and the Maghreb. Then his son Hassan took the Kingship after Tubba'; he is Malik Karib, the second of the Tubba's. It is mentioned that he advised his son Afriqis, saying to him: "O my son, the Kingdom is a craft, and the King is a craftsman. If the craftsman performs his duty towards his craft, people deem it good for him, and his matter in it becomes firmly established, gaining wealth and prestige for it, and it becomes a provision and treasure for him. If he disdains it and does not perform his duty towards it, the craft goes from his hand, its benefits are cut off from him, and he earns blame for himself and deprivation. Every soul has what it earned and bears what it acquired." It is said: This Hassan is the killer of his brother. He is known as Aqran. He died in the land of the Maghreb after ruling fifty years, having possessed the regions. Then his son Afriqis took the Kingship after him. When the Kingdom stabilized for him, he raided the lands of the Maghreb with the Arab tribes. He built a city there and named it after himself, Afriqiyah (Africa). He drove the Berbers to it from the land of Canaan and killed the King Jirjir (Gregory). It is said he is the one who named the Berbers by this name; because when he conquered the lands of the West and heard their gibberish, he said: "What is this? How much is their babbling (Barbarah)!" So they were named Berbers. The word Barbar in the language of the Arabs means the mixing of unintelligible sounds. When he returned from the raid of the Maghreb, he left there from the tribes of Himyar: Sanhaja and Kutama, and they are there to this day. Al-Tabari, Al-Jurjani, Al-Masudi, Ibn Al-Kalbi, and all genealogists said this. This is the third of the Tubba's. Then Afriqis advised his brother As'ad Abu Karib Al-Kamil, saying: "You have known what our father advised us from what his father entrusted to him of the testaments of fathers and grandfathers, and the politics of this Kingdom which we were given to the exclusion of others. So you must hold fast to what you found me upon of spreading justice, manufacturing men (winning loyalty), outwitting the enemy, forgiving when able, blocking frontiers, and repairing breaches."

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Then Tubba' took the Kingship after his father and entrusted the Ministry to his brother Rufaydah. To Tubba' belonged what belongs to the King, and to Rufaydah what belongs to the Minister. They remained so for a long time upon their father's testament. So you must hold fast to what you found me upon of spreading justice, manufacturing men (winning loyalty), outwitting the enemy, forgiving when able, blocking frontiers, and repairing breaches. [Note: The text repeats the previous paragraph almost identically due to source error].

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: They mentioned that As'ad Al-Kamil Malik Karib is the fourth of the Tubba's. He took the Kingship after his brother and walked among the people with the biography of the ancients among his fathers and grandfathers. He possessed lands no other possessed, and was given justice and equipment no other king was given. It is mentioned that As'ad fell ill once and was on the verge of death from it, and that was after his return from his journey in which he entered the Sea of Darkness. He had a son called Hassan the Younger; he named him after his father. They mentioned that he did not rule and died before his father; he is the one whom his father As'ad Al-Kamil mentioned in his poetry. They mentioned that Hassan died before his father, so no one was more entitled to the Kingship after As'ad Al-Kamil than his grandfather (or ancestor) Al-Mu'ammar (The Long-Lived), known as Qarmal; he is Tubba' bin Zayd bin Rufaydah, the fifth of the Tubba's. He said to him advising him: "There is nothing but has a foundation and basis. The foundation of the Kingdom and the basis is Men. The basis of Men is beneficence towards them. Whoever does good to Men, they obey him and listen to him. And whoever Men listen to and obey, the lands and those in them submit to him. And whoever the lands and those in them submit to is their owner after Allah. Its owner, the Kingdom does not last for him in it except with justice and beneficence, for there is no obedience for one who has no justice, and no kingdom for one who has no beneficence." Then he preserved his testament and acted upon it, so his conduct was good, and he possessed what the ancients among his fathers and grandfathers possessed. Then he advised his son Yasir, the sixth of the Tubba's, saying: "O my son, the Kingdom is a lamp, and the King is the lighter of that lamp. If he protects it from a wind that extinguishes it, or a wick that does not absorb oil, or a stoker who betrays him, that lamp lasts for him and its light and brightness remain safe. If he distances himself from it and does not perform his duty towards it properly, the wind extinguishes it. If it is safe from the wind, it is not safe from the burning of the wick. And one is not safe, when the wick burns in the lamp holder, from the stoker going astray. So neither is the light shining, nor the stoker correct; neither is the wick safe, nor the lighter praised." This Yasir is called Yasir al-Ni'am (Yasir of the Blessings). He took the Kingship after his father Tubba' bin Zayd bin Rufaydah bin Amr Dhu al-Adh'ar. He preserved the testament of his father Tubba', stood firm on it, and acted upon it in the politics of the Kingdom between him and the people, and did not transgress the biography of his ancestors. He is the one who trod the land of Iraq, Persia, and the Romans and conquered their cities, and struck the city of Safad and the Valley of Jayhun (Oxus). His reign was one hundred and sixty years. Some narrators mentioned that he ruled the land of the Romans and appointed Mahan over them; Mahan perished, and his two sons Qayus and Yasir ruled after him. Then Yasir took the Kingship after his father Tubba', stood firm on his testament, preserved it, and acted upon it in the politics of the Kingdom between him and the people, and did not transgress the biography of his ancestors and the traditions of his ancients. He advised his son Shamir saying to him: "O my son, manage the Kingdom, for management is its stability; beneficence is its policy; justice is its sustenance; men are its glory; wealth is its succor; and the clan is its equipment. There is no kingdom for one who has no management; no stability for one who has no beneficence; no beneficence for one who has no justice; no justice for one who has no sustenance; no sustenance for one who has no men; and no men for one who has no justice." It is mentioned that Shamir Dhu al-Janah took the Kingship after his father. He was one of the greatest kings in authority. He is the one called Tubba' the Great. He is the one who traveled in the Sea of Darkness after As'ad and reached the interruption of the earth, seeking in it what Dhu al-Qarnayn sought. As'ad is the one who built the city of Samarkand and it is attributed to him. He wrote on the Gate of Merv the inscription that is known. He has monuments he is famous for to this day. Likewise, he wrote on the Gate of China when he conquered and possessed it, and wrote on the Gate of the Land of the Maghreb beyond which is only sand whose waves crash like the waves of the seas and flow as floods flow in their valleys. He found no passage in it. Some of his companions crossed and did not return. So he ordered a statue of copper to be set up on the edge of the valley and wrote on its chest in the Himyaritic Musnad script: "There is no passage behind it; let no one burden himself, go, and perish." End quote. Hisham Al-Kalbi said: Di'bil bin Ali Al-Khuza'i mentioned that, saying in his poetry: 'And they nailed Samarkand with their spears... And they planted with their hands a treasure. And they wrote the book at the Gate of Merv... And at the Gate of China they were the writers.'

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: He said: Then Tubba' took the Kingship; he is Abu Karib. He was the first to give glad tidings of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, after Saba and after As'ad Al-Kamil. He performed Hajj, circumambulated the House for a week, sacrificed camels, clothed the Kaaba, and made a door and a lock for it. It is mentioned that this Tubba' is the one who arranged the kings and the sons of kings from his people in the tribes of the West and Non-Arabs, and their cities and metropolises. For every tribe of the Arabs, there was a king from Himyar and Kahlan who was listened to and obeyed. Then he gathered the kings, the sons of kings, the princes (Aqyal), and the sons of princes, and said to them: "O people, time has exhausted most of it, and only the least of it remains. The abundant, if it decreases, is closer to deficiency than to increase. You are treading the path of fathers and grandfathers and will come to what they came to. Every day passes from a man's life. For every time there are people; and for every cycle a cause. This interval, whoever is mighty in it will be mighty by the appearance of a Prophet through whom Allah will strengthen His religion, singling him out with the Clear Book after a despair of Messengers, a mercy to the believers, and a proof against the disbelievers. Let that be with you and your sons, century after century, and generation after generation; to expect his appearance, believe in him, and strive to support him over all living things, until people return to the command of Allah Almighty." They mentioned that the kings and sons of kings from Himyar and Kahlan did not cease expecting the appearance of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, advising obedience to him, belief in him, Jihad with him, and standing in his support from that era until the appearance of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. So when he was sent, they were among the keenest people to support and obey him. Among them were those who heard and believed, and those who saw him, supported him, and strove in the path of Allah in his defense until certainty (death) came to him. The Clear Book spoke of that in His saying, Exalted is His matter: (And those who settled in the Home and [accepted] faith before them love those who migrated to them) to the end of the verse. And the Almighty's saying: (O you who have believed, whoever of you reverts from his religion - Allah will bring forth a people He will love and who will love Him) to the end of the verse. It is said: They are Hamdan and Tujib. They mentioned that when the Kingship transferred to Yusuf Dhu Nuwas, envy appeared towards him from some of his people, and biting words reached him that they uttered regarding his affair. He turned to them and said: "O people, no leader bore a grudge and succeeded, nor did one seek a matter and rush into it and succeed. Enough with the one who says 'Yusuf Dhu Nuwas possessed this matter while he is not of its heirs nor of the sons of those who held it before him.' The matter is not as claimed and asserted. But the Kingdom has a foundation; whoever possesses it possesses the Kingdom." It is said this Dhu Nuwas is the one who dug the Trench. He followed Judaism. Yemen followed Judaism since the era of Tubba'. Christianity appeared in Najran and some of Yemen when Faymiyun came to them; his cause and news are too long to explain. They mentioned that Dhu Ru'ayn, named Buraym bin Zayd - and it is said he is from Kahlan - took the Kingship, improved conduct, and ruled a great kingdom. It is said: He turned to his household and children - having lived long until his sight weakened and hearing dulled - and said to them: "O my sons, I have preserved the testaments of the ancients among my ancestors, and ruled the kingdom of my fathers and grandfathers. Age and gray hair have benefited me with manners and increase in knowledge of what rectifies a man's world and livelihood and revives exploits and virtues, more than what fathers and grandfathers bequeathed to me." They mentioned that his sons and cousins preserved this testament and acted upon it, and their conduct was praised. They mentioned that when Dhu al-Anfar took the Kingship and managed it, he turned to his clan and said: "Two, even if their affair is small, are better than one, even if his affair is great. Unite and you will be mighty; do not divide or you will be humiliated." They mentioned that Hawal bin Harb bin Dhu Nafar took the Kingship and managed it according to the traditions of the ancients among his fathers and grandfathers; his name was Amer. They mentioned that he turned to his sons and brothers, saying to them: "Not every advisor reaches all he wants in his advice. Eloquence is a guide to hitting the positions of wisdom. O my sons: Obey the strongest among you and you will be mighty; do not disobey his command or you will be humiliated. Unite and you will be feared; do not divide, and cooperate. Be fair to people and be just in what is presented to you of their affairs, you will be praised. Improve your manners with them, you will lead. Honor is with praise wherever it is; might is with fairness wherever it appears; and obedience is with suzerainty." They mentioned that Manakh preserved the testament, acted upon it, conducted people according to their habits, and the matter lasted for him. Then he called his brothers and people from Banu Abd Shams and said to them: "A man does not lead except by his generosity, nor does he attain the utmost might except by his people. He is not granted people's love except by beneficence to them. He does not attain kingship except by spending money on the elite and commoners. And the Kingdom does not last for him except by his justice and beneficence."

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: They mentioned that Al-Hadhhad bin Sharhabil took the Kingship after his father. One day he went out hunting and saw a gazelle chased by a wolf, which had forced it into a tight spot with no escape. Al-Hadhhad charged at the wolf, drove it away from the gazelle, and singled it out to pursue it to see where its situation would end. He followed the trace of the gazelle and was cut off from his companions. While he was thus, a great city appeared to him containing everything: camels, goods, and types of fruits. He stood before it amazed. Suddenly, a man from the people of the town that appeared to him approached, greeted him, and welcomed him. Then he said to Al-Hadhhad: "O King, I see you amazed at what appeared to you." Al-Hadhhad said to him: "It is as you said. What is this city and who inhabits it?" He said: "This is Ma'rib, named after the name of your people. It is the city of Al-Aram, a clan of the Jinn." He said: While he was speaking with him, a woman passed by them. Seers had never seen a face more beautiful, a creation more perfect, a morning more radiant, nor a scent more pleasant than hers. Al-Hadhhad was captivated by her. The King of the Jinn knew that he loved her and was infatuated with her. He said to him: "O Ibn Sharhabil, if you desire her, I will marry her to you." Al-Hadhhad thanked him and said: "Who will guarantee that for me?" The Jinni said: "I guarantee what I offered of marrying her to you and reconciling between you in the easiest and most complete way. Have you recognized her?" Al-Hadhhad said: "I have not seen her before this day of mine." The Jinni said: "She is the gazelle you saved from the wolf. We will reward you for your beautiful deed by gifting her to you. Prepare to enter upon her, for I marry you to her with the testimony of Allah Almighty and the testimony of His angels. If you wish that, come to us with the elite of your people, their kings, and your household to witness her engagement and wedding feast. Your appointment is the coming month of Rajab." He said: Al-Hadhhad bin Sharhabil departed, and the city disappeared from him. He found his companions striving in search of him. They said to him: "Where were you? We have been searching for you since you left us, and we left nothing of these wildernesses but turned it over seeking you." He said to them: "I did not go far from you." He proceeded walking with them reciting poetry: 'Wonders of time do not cease their marvels... And man, as long as he lives, is not free of wonder. I did not think the earth was inhabited... By other than non-Arabs in the horizons and Arabs. I used to be told of the harsh Jinn and... I returned their news only to lies. Until I saw lofty palaces built... For the Jinn, with doors and veils struck. Crops and water surround them... With laden trees of palms and grapes. From Jumada, and after it comes Rajab... And I will travel to the appointment in Rajab. Until I meet the best of Jinn from Aram... That is Ibn Sa'b the youth known as Yalab.' Then Al-Hadhhad bin Sharhabil went out for the appointment of his in-laws from the Jinn with the elite of his people and servants, until he met them. He and those with him found a palace they built for them in a desert of the land, surrounded by palms, grapes, crops, and fruits, with flowing water running in it. The people marveled at that greatly and saw a great kingdom. They stayed with him in the palace on carpets the likes of which they had never seen. Tables were brought near them with layers of food and colors they had never eaten anything better in taste or purer in scent. They drank a drink they had never drunk anything more digestible, delicious, wholesome, or lighter. They stayed with him three days. His wife, named Al-Harura daughter of Yalab bin Al-Sa'b Al-Aram, King of the Jinn, was wedded to Al-Hadhhad. Al-Hadhhad permitted his people and elite to return to their places. Then the King stayed with the Haruris for a time, and she bore him Bilqis. The palace the Jinn built for him became the house of his kingdom. Her father King Al-Hadhhad died, and her mother did not remain long after him. Bilqis remained with her maternal uncles from the Jinn. Her father's cousin, Shamir bin Ghash, sat in the Kingship; people listened to him and obeyed. Then he sent to Bilqis proposing to her. She accepted on the condition that he would not oppose her in anything she wanted or anything she disliked. He guaranteed that for her and married her.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: They mentioned that when he saw her competence, care for the Kingdom, preservation, and good management of it, he would not command or forbid anyone other than her according to the custom established for her. Then he died, and no one knew of his death except in the days of Solomon son of David, peace be upon him. Her story with the Prophet of Allah is famous. Then the Kingship transferred from the clan of Bilqis to Zur'ah bin Ka'b, who is Himyar the Younger; his father is Abd Shams, and Abd Shams is Saba the Younger. They mentioned that when Zayd Dhu al-Kala' took the Kingship, he turned to his sons, brothers, and cousins and said to them: "O assembly of brothers, sons, and cousins, if the Kingdom were to last for anyone, it would have lasted for your ancestors who ruled the lands, improved conduct among its people, took for the weak from the strong, secured the roads, humiliated the tyrants, enjoined good, forbade evil, and developed the earth: its east and west. You have their news, and I am not more knowledgeable than you to narrate to you of their news, exploits, and glories what would suffice you for what comes after." Then they mentioned that he became King, one whom Himyar and Kahlan agreed upon obeying, following, and accepting from in command, prohibition, war, and peace. They mentioned that he advised his sons, saying to them: "O my sons, Himyar and Kahlan did not unite in obedience to me, following me, and accepting from me because I am from the noblest house among them, nor more entitled to the Kingdom among them than others. But they weighed the famous men and saw me as the most weighty in opinion when commanding and forbidding, so they entrusted me with their affair and preferred me with the Kingdom over others." These are the testaments of the preceding kings in summary. As for the Tubba's, they had no record, and most of their news is lost. Abu Sa'id mentioned and quoted from the books of eastern historians that the first of the Tubba' Kings was: Al-Harith, who is Al-Raish, then his son Al-Sa'b Dhu al-Qarnayn, then his son Abraha Dhu al-Manar, then Amr Dhu al-Adh'ar. In Al-Tijan: Himyar deposed him and made Sharhabil king, then Al-Hadhhad, then his daughter Bilqis, then Malik bin Amr, then Shamir Mar'ash - named Mar'ash for his trembling, and he is the one who destroyed the land of Samarkand. Then Sayfi bin Shamir ruled after him, then his brother Afriqis. Then the Kingship transferred to Banu Kahlan, and they were in Ma'rib, while the kings of Himyar were in Sana'a. Then the Kingship went to the tribe of Amr bin Amir. Then Himyar gathered after the ruin of the Dam under Abu Karib As'ad bin Sayfi; he went out against the Kings of the Factions (Muluk al-Tawa'if) and overcame them. Then his son Hassan, who killed Tasm and Jadis whose homes were in Jaww al-Yamamah. Then his brother Amr killed him, then his brother Abd al-Kilal succeeded him. Then Tubba' bin Hassan ruled after him, then Wali'ah bin Murshid, then Al-Sabah bin Wali'ah, then Abraha bin Al-Sabah, who had a biography and stories. After him Dhu Qayfan, after him Al-Hanifah Dhu Shanatir, after him Dhu Nuwas. Then the Abyssinians killed him and seized Yemen. Then Sayf bin Dhu Yazan liberated it from them; his kunya is Abu Murrah bin Aslam bin Zayd bin Al-Ghawth bin Sa'd bin Awf bin Adi bin Malik bin Zayd bin Shaddad bin Himyar bin Saba bin Ka'b bin Zayd bin Sahl bin Imran bin Qays bin Muawiyah bin Jashm bin Abd Shams bin Wael bin Al-Ghawth bin Qatan bin 'Arib bin Zuhayr bin Ayman bin Al-Hamisa' bin Himyar bin Saba bin Yashjub bin Ya'rub bin Qahtan bin Hud, peace be upon him. Then when Sayf liberated it from the Abyssinians with the help of Chosroes (Kisra), the Kingdom stabilized for him. The Arabs came to him congratulating him on the Kingship. It happened that when Abd al-Muttalib bin Hashim and Umayyah bin Abi Manaf came to him, Abd al-Muttalib asked permission for himself and those with him to reach him. He permitted them to enter. They entered upon Sayf bin Dhu Yazan. It was said to him: "If you are of those who speak before kings, I have permitted you." Abd al-Muttalib stood before him while surrounding him were kings and sons of kings, and on his right and left were princes (Aqyal) and sons of princes. Abd al-Muttalib said: "Allah has placed you, O King, in a high, difficult, impregnable, lofty, towering station. He has grown you in a plantation whose root is good, whose base is mighty, whose origin is firm, and whose branch is tall in the noblest mine and best homeland. You are the House of Glory and the Head of the Arabs, whom you led, their pillar upon which is the support, their stronghold to which servants take refuge, and their spring by which lands become fertile. Your predecessor was the best predecessor, and you are for us the best successor. The mention of one whom you are the predecessor of will not fade, nor will one whom you are the successor of perish.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: O King, we are the people of Allah's Sanctuary and the custodians of His House. What brought us to you is what delighted us of lifting the distress that burdened us: So we are the delegation of congratulation (or condolence/calamity - text says 'Razziya' which means calamity, but context implies 'Tahni'a' / congratulation for victory over Abyssinians, or perhaps referring to the calamity of Abyssinian rule lifted). He said: Which of them are you, O speaker? He said: I am Abd al-Muttalib bin Hashim. He said: Are you our sister's son? He said: Yes. He said: Come near me, O Abd al-Muttalib. Then he turned to him and the people and said: Welcome, a greeting, an easy kneeling place, and a spacious king who gives abundant gifts. The King has heard your speech, known your kinship, and accepted your means. You have the night and day; honor is yours as long as you stay, and generosity when you depart. Then they departed to the guest house and stayed a month; they could not reach him nor did he permit them to leave. Then he paid attention to them, sent for Abd al-Muttalib, brought him near, cleared his assembly, and then said: "O Abd al-Muttalib, I am confiding a secret to you regarding a matter. Had it been other than you, I would not have revealed it to him. But I found you to be a mine (of trust), so I will inform you of it. Let it be kept folded with you until Allah permits it. I found in the Hidden Book and the Stored Knowledge, which we chose for ourselves to the exclusion of others, grave news and great import. In it is the honor of life and the virtue of loyalty for people in general, for your clan entirely, and for you specifically." Abd al-Muttalib said to him: "What is it, O King? One like you keeps secrets and does good. What is it, may the people of hair (Bedouins) and clay (city dwellers) be your ransom, group after group?" The King said:

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: "When a boy is born in Tihama, having a sign, to him belongs the Imamate (Leadership), and to you through him belongs the sovereignty, until the Day of Resurrection." Abd al-Muttalib said to him: "May you refuse the curse; you have returned with the best of what a delegation of people returned with. If the King sees fit to inform me clearly, he would have clarified for me some clarification." He said: "This is the time in which he is born. His name is Muhammad. Between his shoulders is a mole (Shamah). His father and mother die, and his grandfather and uncle sponsor him. Allah sends him openly and makes for him helpers from us (Ansar). Through them, He honors His allies and humiliates His enemies. Through them, He strikes people generally and makes permissible for them the best parts of the earth. He worships the Most Merciful, defeats Satan, breaks the idols, and extinguishes the fires. His speech is decisive, his judgment is just. He enjoins good and does it, and forbids evil and nullifies it." He said: Abd al-Muttalib fell prostrate. He said to him: "Raise your head. Have you sensed anything of his affair?" He said: "Yes, O King. I had a son I admired, so I married him to a noble woman of the nobles of my people, named Amina bint Wahb bin Abd Manaf. She came with a boy I named Muhammad. His father and mother died, so I sponsored him, and perhaps tomorrow his uncle. Between his shoulders is a mole, and in him is everything you mentioned of signs." He said: "By the Lord of the House and the Veils, and the Signs on the Monuments, you, O Abd al-Muttalib, are his grandfather without a lie. What I told you is what I told. So preserve your son and beware for him from the Jews, for they are his enemies, but Allah will not give them a way against him. Keep what I mentioned folded from this group with you, for I am not safe from envy entering them, regarding you having the leadership, so they plot evils against you and set traps for you. They and their sons are doers of that. Were it not that death sweeps me away before his mission, I would have marched with my cavalry and infantry until I come to him in Yathrib, the abode of his kingdom. For I find in the Speaking Book and Preceding Knowledge that Yathrib is the place of his command, in it are the people of his support, and the place of his grave. Were it not that I protect him from calamities and guard him against blights, I would have announced my youthfulness (new era?) of his affair. But I am dispensing this to you without falling short with those with you." Then he ordered for every man one hundred camels, ten slaves, ten bondmaids, ten pounds of silver, and a tripe full of ambergris. He ordered for Abd al-Muttalib multiples of what he gave the people. Then he said: "Bring me his news and what becomes of his affair at the turn of the year." Sayf bin Dhu Yazan died before the year turned. Abd al-Muttalib used to say: "O people, let none of you envy me for the King's abundant gift, for it is towards depletion. But envy me for what remains for me and my descendants after me of his honor and pride." If it was said to him: "What is that?" He would say: "You will know later." Himyar consisted of clans and thighs. In Al-Iqd Al-Farid: Himyar bin Saba had children: Malik, Al-Hamisa', Zayd, Aws, Arin, Wael, Darmi, Amr Karib, Masruh, and Murrah, the clan of Ma'dikarib bin Nu'man. From the clans of Himyar are Banu Ma'dan bin Jashm bin Abd Shams bin Wael bin Al-Ghawth bin Qatan bin Ya'rub. Milhan is a clan: Milhan bin Amr bin Qays bin Muawiyah bin Jashm bin Shams bin Wael, the clan of Amir Al-Sha'bi the Jurist. He said: Milhan and Shi'an were counted in Hamdan; whoever of them is in Yemen is Himyarite. Among the clans of Himyar: Banu Shar'ab, who is Shar'ab bin Qays bin Jashm bin Abd Shams; to him Shar'abi spears are attributed. Among the clans of Himyar are Al-Duruz, also called Al-Azr, and called Ramdad. From them are Banu Fuhayd, Abd Al-Maklal, and Dhu Al-Kala', who is Yazid bin Al-Nu'man. From them is Dhu Ru'ayn bin Amr. Dhu Asbah is a clan from Asbah bin Malik bin Zayd bin Al-Ghawth. From them is Abraha bin Al-Sabah, King of Tihama; his son Shams was killed with Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, on the day of Siffin. From them is Rushd bin 'Arib bin Abraha bin Al-Sabah, who was the master of a tribe in Sham in the time of Muawiyah. From them is Zayd bin Mu'arrid the poet. From Banu Asbah is Imam Malik, Imam of the Abode of Migration (Medina), Al-Asbahi, may Allah have mercy on him. From the clans of Himyar: Dhu Yazan; from them is Al-Nu'man bin Qays bin Sayf bin Dhu Yazan. It came in the Hadith from the Prophet, peace be upon him: That he bought jewelry for twenty odd young camels and gave it to Dhu Yazan. To Dhu Yazan Yazani spears are attributed. From the clans of Himyar: Dhu Jadan, who is Al-Alas bin Al-Harith bin Zayd bin Al-Ghawth. From his descendants is Alqamah bin Sharhabil. Dhu Qayfan is a clan of Himyar, from Banu Adi bin Malik bin Zayd bin Sahl bin Amr bin Muawiyah. From them is Shu'ayb bin Dhu Hadam, peace be upon him, whom his people killed, so Allah empowered Nebuchadnezzar over them and he killed them, leaving no one. It is said this verse was revealed about them: (And when they perceived Our might, behold, they fled from it) to His saying: (extinguished/silent). He said when the swords of Nebuchadnezzar began on them, they were called by a terrible voice from the sky: "O Vengeance for the Prophets!" The grave of the Prophet Shu'ayb was in a mountain called Tin; there is no mountain in Yemen containing salt other than it. In it is the Prophet of Al-Rass from Qahtan of the Arabs. From the clans of Himyar: Al-Aqra'

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: and Bani Abyan, a clan of Himyar. Banu al-Sakasik, a clan from Dhu al-Kala' of Himyar. Banu Takalim, a clan of Himyar. The Kings of Himyar, a clan of Himyar. Nu'aym is a clan; from them is Nu'aym the origin of Oman, and Nu'aym the origin of Qatar and Bahrain; most of Nu'aym are in Yemen. Banu Yakhsub is a clan from Zayd al-Jumhur. Banu Shayban is a clan from Zayd al-Jumhur; Shayban bin Awf bin Amr bin Malik bin Zayd al-Jumhur bin Sahl bin Amr bin Qays bin Muawiyah bin Jashm bin Abd Shams bin Ghawth bin Qatan bin 'Arib bin Zuhayr bin Al-Ayman bin Al-Hamisa' bin Himyar bin Saba. From this Shayban are the people of Shayban known in Barqa of Otaybah (Utaybah). It was mentioned in 'Wills of the Kings' that Barqa are from the Arabs of the Dam; they moved from the Dam within the tribes of Azd and settled in Al-Sarah. Al-Sarah is between Abwa' and Ta'if, and they are there to this day. Barqa of Otaybah and the people of Shayban are from Himyar and settled in Al-Sarah, which is closer. The Shayabin are clans. From their clans are Al-Fuhaydat clan, Dhawi Abd clan, Banu Mu'ayti, Al-Damukh, Dhawi Jafil clan, Dhawi Ghulayamah, Al-Shaddam, Al-Arum clan, Al-Qarfah, Al-Zayalqah clan, Al-Umur clan, and Al-Shafqah. They are from Thaqif, allies of the Shayabin. End. Section: On Quda'a bin Malik bin Himyar bin Saba bin Yashjub bin Ya'rub bin Qahtan bin Hud, peace be upon him. Malik bin Himyar had ruled Oman, then his son Quda'a, then his son Ilhaf, then Malik bin Ilhaf. Then war broke out between Malik and Al-Saksak the Himyarite, so he drove them out of Oman, and they settled with Banu Kahlan. It is mentioned in the book 'Wills of the Kings' that Amr bin Haritha bin Ma' al-Sama' dispatched the clans of Quda'a to Al-Sham by the command of King Al-Qatat bin Amr the Himyarite. He appointed Zayd bin Aslam bin Amr bin Ilhaf bin Malik bin Ilhaf bin Quda'a bin Malik bin Himyar over them, tied the banner for him, and ordered them to listen and obey. This Zayd is the father of Juhaynah bin Al-Layth bin Sud bin Zayd, and the father of Udhrah, Nahd, Midhah, Ahmar, and Asmah.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Amr bin Haritha bin Ma' al-Sama' wrote him a letter to Al-Sham saying in its opening poetry... They mentioned that when Zayd went out from the clans of Quda'a to Al-Sham and marched to Hijaz, talk, enthusiasm, and envy occurred between him and his clan, so they separated. Some returned to Yemen and their offspring are there; they are Khawlan bin Amr bin Ilhaf bin Malik bin Zayd, and Adwan bin Zayd. As for those of Quda'a who proceeded to Al-Sham, they are Amilah bin Malik bin Rabi'ah bin Quda'a and their brothers. In Al-Sham, the most numerous, powerful, and mighty of them were Banu Aklab bin Wabrah. Among them is Janab, containing the 'Ama'ir (clans); among them Adi, Uways, Aym Allah, Sa'd Allah, Wahb Allah, and Zayd Allah. These are the sons of Rufaydah bin Nuwayr bin Kalb. Among them is Tanukh, Al-Qalays, and Kinana the Greater. These are the protectors of Al-Sham and its Bedouins, who have protection rights (khafarat) over the villages and cities of Al-Sham. Quda'a consists of clans and thighs. Among their clans is Banu Udhrah. From Banu Udhrah is Banu Rifa'a. From the clans of Udhrah is Banu Kathir. Banu Ahramah is a clan of Udhrah. From Udhrah is Banu Kahil; from them is Humayrah bin Al-Nu'man bin Hud. Banu Zuhrah is a clan of Udhrah; he is Zuhrah bin Zayd bin Sa'd bin Kahil. Banu Kahil is a clan of Udhrah; they are the clan of Urwah, companion of Afra bint Mu'asir bin Malik. Banu Hind is a clan of Udhrah; from them is Wahb the Jurist. From Udhrah and Kinana Udhrah are those from whom Rizah, brother of Qusay bin Kilab, comes. He is Rizah bin Rabi'ah, brother of Qusay bin Kilab through his mother. Rizah is the one who expelled Khuza'a from Mecca and made his brother Qusay bin Kilab king over Mecca. The dwellings of Quda'a were Al-Sirr known in Najd. He is the one saying in his march poetry: 'We marched the march from Ashmadhayn... And from Kilab we gathered a tribe.' His saying Al-Sirr is the Sirr known in Najd, and Ashmadhayn is known as Al-Washiyayn near Sajir. When Rizah returned from the raid of Khuza'a and appointing his maternal brother Qusay bin Kilab over Mecca, there was some grudge between Rizah and Hutakah bin Aslam bin Ilhaf bin Quda'a, and between Nahd bin Zayd bin Aslam bin Ilhaf bin Quda'a. So he expelled them from their lands, Najd and Al-Sirr, and attached them to Yemen. Qusay said blaming him: 'To whom is the messenger from me to Rizah... For I have blamed you regarding two.' From the clans of Quda'a are Banu Wabrah, brother of Kalb bin Taghlib bin Wabrah. From the clans of Quda'a are Banu Al-Dhi'b (The Wolf) bin Usayd. It is said the Dhibah, the clan known in Otaybah, are from them. From Al-Dhibah are the Dhawiyah, chiefs of Banu Amr in Masruh of Harb. Banu Usayd is a large clan. Banu Al-Qayn is a clan from Usayd bin Wabrah. From Banu Al-Qayn is Al-Qunayni, the clan known in Abbad. Banu Ka'b is a clan from Usayd bin Wabrah. Banu Malik is a clan from Wabrah; he is Malik bin Ka'b bin Jadm bin Ka'b bin Sa'd bin Ka'b bin Hakam bin Sa'd bin Wabrah. Banu Kalb is a clan from Quda'a. Abu Sa'id said: A large multitude of them is on the Gulf of Constantinople; some are Muslims and some Christians. From the clans of Kalb is Al-Khazraj. From Kalb bin Wabrah, from the clans of Kulayb bin Wabrah is Banu Ashab clan. From the clans of Quda'a is Banu Thawr; he is Thawr bin Kalb bin Wabrah bin Taghlib bin Imran bin Ilhaf bin Malik bin Ilhaf bin Quda'a bin Malik bin Himyar. They are the clan known in Sabi' Hamdan. From Banu Thawr is Uraynah. This Uraynah is a clan from Banu Thawr, the Uraynat known in Subay'. From them are Al Suwaylim people of Riyadh, the Uraynat people of Raghbah, the Uraynat people of Unayzah, and the rest of Uraynah of Subay' are from these. From this Banu Thawr are Al Sulaym people of Unayzah, Al Suqayr, and Al-Jad; these are from Banu Thawr. Also Al-Thunayan and Al-Barrak people of Al-Khubra, Al-Bukayriyah, Al-Aqil, Al-Dakhil people of Al-Rass - from whom is Mihmas Al-Dakhil in Medina - and Al-Shibala from whom is Al-Shibli; these are from Subay'. From the clans of Quda'a is Janab, a clan from Wabrah. From them is Zuhayr bin Janab bin Hubal bin Abdullah bin Kinana bin Bakr bin Awf bin Udhrah Al-Kalbi, one of those whom Quda'a united upon. He was called Al-Kahlana. He lived two hundred and fifty years, and it is said four hundred and fifty years. He fought two hundred battles in it, and was a brave, victorious, auspicious man. The reason for his raid on Ghatafan bin Baghild bin Rayth bin Ghatafan was when they left Tihama entirely. Sada, a tribe of Madhhij, confronted them, fought them, defeated Sada, and took their wealth. When Ghatafan saw their wealth had increased, they said: Let us take a sanctuary (Haram) like Mecca, where no game is killed nor its refuge seeker harmed. So they built a sanctuary, and Banu Murrah bin Awf assumed its guardianship. When their action and consensus reached Zuhayr bin Janab, he said: By Allah, it shall not be. Then Zuhayr bin Janab raided Ghatafan with his people Quda'a and the rest of the Arabs. He fought Ghatafan, defeated them, disabled that sanctuary, and captured their women and wealth. His story is famous; we abbreviated it.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Banu Amir is a clan from Udhrah. Banu Al-Ubaydi is a clan from Udhrah. Banu Awf is a clan from Udhrah; he said they are a large clan. Bakr is a clan from Udhrah. Banu Aws is a clan from Udhrah. Banu Junayb is a clan from Kinana Udhrah; from them is Al-Aswad bin Usayd bin Adi. Banu Umayth is a clan from Kinana Udhrah. Banu Adi is a clan from Kinana Udhrah; Abu Ubayd said: In them is the Kingship and the House (Bayt); from them is Layla mother of Abd al-Malik bin Marwan. Banu Damdam and Banu Husayn are clans from Banu Adi bin Kinana Udhrah. Banu Zuhayr is a clan from Kinana Udhrah; Abu Ubayd said from them is Sayyar bin Amr. In Al-Ibar: From them is Jandal bin Nin. Banu Haritha is a clan from Kinana Udhrah. Banu Abdullah is a clan from Kinana Udhrah. Banu Jabir is a clan from Kinana Udhrah. Banu Ulaym is a clan from Janab Kinana Udhrah; from them is Usayd bin Haritha Al-Ulaymi the Companion, may Allah be pleased with him. In Janab are the 'Ama'ir: Banu Al-Hasad Al-Asi is a clan from Al-Jamarisah from Kinana Udhrah. Banu Firas is a clan from Al-Jamarisah from Kinana Udhrah, mentioned by Al-Hamdani in his book.
