Banu Ubayd is a clan from Kinana Udhrah; from them is Imru' al-Qais bin Humamah, who is from Hubal bin Abdullah bin Kinana. Banu Samhah is a clan from Kinana Udhrah. From Banu Asjamah are Al-Sahamah, the clan known in Qahtan. Ubaydah mentioned and Al-Sahamah entered into Madhhij, and Allah knows best. Al-Rawashid is a clan from Kinana Udhrah. From them is Al-Rashud, the group of Ibn Mani', the clan known in Al-Manasir. From the clans of Kinana Udhrah are Al-Jamarisah. Al-Hamdani said they are Banu Humran. From them is Al-Humran, the clan known in Harb: Al-Ahamidah. They are a clan from Al-Jamarisah from Kinana Udhrah. It is said Al-Ahamidah is a clan from Tayy. Banu Sinan is a clan from Kinana Udhrah. Banu Asna' is a clan from Kinana Udhrah, from Rabad bin Habulah who captured the wife of Akil al-Murrar, so Amr bin Rabi'ah Al-Namari killed him. Banu Khushayn is a clan from Quda'a; from them is Abu Tha'labah Al-Khushi the Companion, may Allah be pleased with him. Banu Al-Na'ayim is a clan from Udhrah; from them is Ibn Adham the poet. From the clans of Quda'a is Banu Jarm. Banu Qudamah is a clan of Jarm Quda'a; from them is Qudamah bin Kinana who satirized Amr bin Ma'dikarib Al-Zubaydi. Jarm is the son of Ziyan bin Hulwan bin Imran bin Ilhaf bin Malik bin Quda'a. It is a large clan. From them is Banu Rasib clan, Banu Ashmakh clan, and Banu Salih clan. From them is Al-Ubayd bin Al-Abras bin Imran bin Al-Ashbah bin Salih. Banu Al-Ubayd is a clan from Salih bin Quda'a; they are among the nobles of the Arabs, as stated by the author of Nihayat Al-Arab. Al-A'sha refers to them saying: 'I am not of the nobles Banu Al-Ubaydi.' He said they had a kingship they inherited in Al-Hasin in the desert of Sabkhar in the Jazira Euphrates region until their last was Al-Dayzal bin Muawiyah Al-Ma'idi and Al-Ashraf. From them is Al-Qurfusah Banu Al-Ahwas bin Amr bin Tha'labah, who is the one whose daughter Na'ilah Ibn Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, married. From them is Zuhayr bin Janab bin Hubal bin Abdullah. Among their predecessors in Islam is Dihyah Al-Kalbi, in whose form Gabriel, peace be upon him, used to descend. Among the noblest of Banu Al-Qayn is Da'ji bin Kashif who captured Ibn Haritha Al-Murri. From them are Malik and Aqil, the boon companions of Jadhima Al-Abrash; they are the sons of Farij. From them is Sa'd bin Amr, head of Banu Al-Qayn and their master. Tanukh is a clan from Quda'a; they are three clans. From them is Taym Allah bin Asad bin Wabrah. From them is Malik bin Zuhayr bin Amr bin Fahm bin Taym Allah bin Tha'labah bin Malik. From them is Jadhima Al-Abrash. From them are the Kings of Iraq, the last being Jadhima. From them is Udhaynah about whom Al-A'sha says poetry: 'He removed Udhaynah from his kingdom... And drove Dhu Yazan out of his palace.'

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From them is Jarm bin Amr, and he was noble. From them is Isam bin Tabha bin Al-Harith, and he was a poet. Jarm had three children: Qudamah, Malkan, and Najiyah. From Banu Qudamah is Suraym who used to exchange satire with Amr bin Ma'dikarib, and Wa'lah bin Abdullah who killed Al-Harith bin Al-Madan. From them is Banu Shan, and they are in Al-Yamamah, entered with Banu Hazzan bin Anazzah. From them is Banu Qilabah Abdullah bin Zayd. From them is Al-Musawir bin Sawar, governed the police of Kufa for Muhammad bin Sulayman. From Banu Jaddah bin Jarm is Banu Rahib. From Banu Salih mentioned previously are Al-Damaji'ah, kings of Al-Sham before Ghassan. From Banu Al-Namir bin Wabrah is Banu Ghadirah clan, and Banu Atibah clan; they are sons of Salim bin Mansur bin Al-Namir. From Banu Aktham bin Al-Namir is Banu Shaj'ah bin Al-Ghawth, from whom is Muawiyah bin Hujayr, who is called Qarib, who killed Dawud bin Habulah Al-Salihi. Malik bin Al-Yahz bin Amr was from Banu Al-Namir. The children of Al-Yahz: Al-Hawd, Qasit, Abdah, Qass, and Adi. From them is Qays and Shabib, two great clans; from them is Al-Miqdad bin Amr, companion of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and he is other than Al-Miqdad bin Al-Aswad Al-Kindi. Section: From the clans of Quda'a is Bali bin Amr bin Malik bin Ilhaf bin Malik bin Quda'a. They are clans and thighs. From their clans is Banu Sa'd clan of Bali; Abu Ubaydah said: They are the ones called Sa'd Alah (Sa'd of God?). Banu Faran from Bali. Banu Wa'ilah clan of Bali; they are Banu Wa'ilah bin Haritha bin Dubay'ah, mentioned by Abu Ubaydah. From them is Al-Nu'man bin Asr, who witnessed Badr with the Prophet, peace be upon him. Banu Fadalah clan of Bali; their dwellings are with their people between Egypt and Aqaba. Banu Nab clan of Bali, mentioned by Al-Hamdani. Banu Hazm clan of Bali, said Al-Hamdani. Banu Qasmil clan of Bali, mentioned by Al-Hamdani. Their dwellings are above Upper Egypt to Aqaba. From Bali is Al-Mujadhdhar bin Ziyad, killer of Abu Al-Bukhturi. From the clans of Bali is Banu Rashid bin Amir. From them is Ka'b bin Ujrah Al-Ansari, may Allah be pleased with him, companion of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and Sahl bin Rafi', owner of the Sa', may Allah be pleased with him. Among them is Banu Al-Ajl bin Al-Harith; from them is Thabit bin Aqram, may Allah be pleased with him, witnessed Badr. From the clans of Bali is Banu Waqisah. Among the chiefs of Bali now are Ibn Rifa'ah and Manqarah. Section: From the clans of Quda'a is Mahra, and they are Banu Al-Mahriyah. The province of Mahra is known on the coasts of Yemen; there is a large multitude of them there, and most of them are with Quda'a in Najd, Hijaz, Al-Sham, and elsewhere. From the clans of Mahra is Al-Ibri clan. From them is Al-Azhar, one of the commanders of Banu Ja'far Al-Mansur. From them is Banu Al-Uaydi clan of Mahra; Al-Uaydiyah camels are attributed to them. From Banu Al-Uaydi is Hubayrah bin Fursum, who came as a delegation to the Prophet, peace be upon him. From Mahra is Banu Al-Ghaffar, a clan of Quda'a; Abu Ubayd said they are the Ghaffaris. From the clans of Mahra are Al-Sama'inah. From the clans of Mahra is Al-Salman clan, and Al-Batratat clan; their dwellings are with their people Mahra in Quba. From the clans of Mahra is Kuraz, and Raw'an from Banu Al-Nasim, who went to Amr bin Ma'dikarib bin Halbah. From them is Fursum who came as a delegation to the Prophet, peace be upon him, who wrote a letter for him and returned him to his people. From Banu Mahra is Banu Khalid clan of Mahra. From Mahra is Banu Sayyar clan, and Al-Awayim clan of Mahra, mentioned by Al-Suwaydi. From Banu Mahra is Al-Daghalibah, the clan known in Barqa; they are thighs of Al-Mahari from whom is Al-Mahri. Section: On Juhaynah. Juhaynah: He is Juhaynah bin Zayd bin Layth bin Sud bin Ilhaf bin Malik bin Quda'a bin Malik bin Himyar. Their lands are Yanbu, Al-Ays, and Radwa. They are settled and Bedouin, clans and thighs. Among their clans is Banu Al-Humays bin Amir bin Tha'labah bin Mawda'ah bin Juhaynah, called Al-Hurqah (The Burning). They were named so because they burned Banu Murrah bin Awf bin Sa'd bin Dhubyan with arrows. Banu Salamah is a clan of Juhaynah; they are Banu Salamah bin Nasr bin Malik bin Adi bin Nasr bin Ghatafan bin Qays bin Juhaynah. From the clans of Juhaynah is Banu Dargham bin Malik from Al-Hurqah; they are the clan of Jawsah bin Shihab. It was said regarding that: He was asked, "What is your tribe?" He said, "Dargham." "And what is your dwelling?" He said, "Laza (Hellfire/Flame)." It was said to him, "We think your family has burned," and it was said they burned. From the clans of Juhaynah is Banu Suwayd bin Imran bin Jadhima bin Sabrah bin Khadij bin Malik bin Ghatafan bin Qays bin Juhaynah. Among them is honor (Sharaf). From the clans of Juhaynah existing now are Al-Marawinah clan, Urwah clan, Banu Kalb clan, Banu Rifa'ah clan, Al-Zawa'idah and Al-Alayishah clan, Al-Dhiban clan, and Al-Mash'ali clan. Section: On Banu Nahd.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: He is Nahd bin Zayd bin Layth bin Sud bin Aslam bin Ilhaf bin Malik bin Ilhaf bin Quda'a. From the clans of Nahd is Banu Khuzayma clan; Abu Ubayd said: They entered into Tanukh. Banu Zawa is a clan of Nahd; from them is Qays bin Abdullah the poet. Abu Ubayd said: Among them is honor. From the clans of Nahd is Al-Tul clan. From Banu Nahd is 'A'idh clan. Banu Hanzala is a clan of Nahd; from them is Banu As'ad, Banu Mas'ud, and Banu Sabah, all clans of Nahd. From them is Abdullah bin Al-Ajlan who died of love. Banu Shababa is a clan of Nahd; most of them entered into Tanukh. From the clans of Shababa is what is mentioned in Harb, Juhaynah, and Otaybah. For in ancient times, if the Hajj season arrived and a man claimed he was from Shababa, Otaybah, Harb, and Juhaynah would gather around him (support him). From these tribes are clans, some from others. Shababa includes Qufah, a clan in Juhaynah and a clan in Harb. Al-Mahyawi is a clan in Juhaynah and a clan in Barqa of Otaybah. Al-Samrah is a clan of Juhaynah and a clan in Al-Ruqah of Otaybah. Al-Ghubaywi is a clan in Juhaynah and a clan in Al-Ruqah. Al-Ghanimi is a clan in Juhaynah and a clan in Harb. The master of Nahd was Al-Sa'iq, who is Jashm bin Amr bin Sa'd; he was short, black, and ugly. Al-Nu'man had heard of his nobility, so he came to him. When he looked at him, he said: "To hear of the Mu'aydi is better than seeing him." Al-Sa'iq said: "May you refuse the curse; a man is but by his two smallest things: his heart and his tongue. If he speaks, he speaks with clarity, and if he assaults, he assaults with a brave heart (Janan)." He said: "You spoke the truth." Then he asked him: "How is your knowledge of matters?" He said: "I hate the accepted of them, solidify the unraveled, and manage them until they transform. He is not a master of them who does not look into consequences." From them is Rad'ah bin Amr, owner of Subays (?). Among those attributed to Shababa bin Nahd are Al-Rawsan in Barqa of Otaybah; they are thighs, called Al-Marawihah. Among them is Dhawi thigh, Bani Umayr thigh, Al-Muqahisiyah and Al-Murabidah thigh, and Al-Habur thigh. From Nahd are Al-Shuhayl, inhabitants of Al-Mubarraz in Al-Ahsa; they are Shuhayl, Ahmad, and Muhammad, sons of Ali from Shuhayl. From Nahd are Al-Mukhaylid, Al-Zurayq, Al-Marzuq, and Al-Rashid, all in Al-Ahsa. From the clans of Quda'a is Banu Hutakah bin Aslam bin Zayd bin Ilhaf. Section

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From the clans of Quda'a is Banu Zayd. He is Zayd bin Suwayd bin Zayd bin Suwayd bin Zayd bin Haram bin Abi Suwayd bin Zayd bin Nahd bin Zayd bin Aslam bin Layth bin Sud bin Ilhaf bin Malik bin Ilhaf bin Malik bin Quda'a bin Malik bin Himyar bin Saba bin Yashjub bin Ya'rub bin Qahtan bin Hud, peace be upon him. From this Zayd branch clans and thighs; some in Yemen, some in Iraq, some in Balqa, and some in Najd, scattered settlers in Al-Quway'iyah, Al-Sha'ra, Al-Dawadimi, Shaqra, Al-Bukayriyah, and other Najdi villages. The famous ones among them are two clans: Atwi and Atiyah. As for Atwi, born to him were Fayyad and Baladi. To Fayyad were born Salih and Harqus. As for the family of Salih (Al Salih), they are clans and thighs. Famous among them are Al-Majrin thigh, Al-Qawzah, Al-Majyul thigh, Al-Muhanna, Al-Salih thigh, and Al-Yabis thigh. As for Harqus, they are clans and thighs. Famous among them are Al-Bawarid thigh, Al-Mani' thigh, Al-Bishr thigh - from whom is Sheikh Uthman bin Abdullah, inhabitant of the town of Jalajil, author of "Unwan al-Majd fi Tarikh Najd" - and Al-Rawajih, a clan whose land is Al-Bukayriyah; from them are Al-Rawajih inhabitants of Al-Barbar in Al-Ahsa. Al-Hammad thigh, from whom is Al-Yahya people of Al-Ahsa. Al-Munaf thigh, from whom are some in the town of Zulfi. From them are Al-Dhikri in the town of Sudair, and Al-Fantukh and Al-Huwaymil in Al-Quway'iyah. As for Baladi bin Atwi, brother of Fayyad, he had children: Ghayhab, Sadhan, and Thaqib. As for Ghayhab, from him are thighs. From their thighs: Al-Subyan, who are the children of Abdullah bin Ghayhab. Also Al-Abd and Al-Zayd; these are a thigh. From their thighs are Al-Yahya (Al-Jamhah), children of Ghayhab thigh, Al-Bukur thigh, Al-Awadin thigh, Al-Bu Zayd thigh, Al-Maqaribah thigh, and Sultan thigh. From them are Al-Sultan, Al-Muhanna, Al-Abdullah, and Al-Muhammad. Al-Muhammad are two thighs: Al-Hadlaq thigh and Al-Sa'dan thigh. From them are Al-Uthman thigh, family of Sheikh Sulayman. As for Al-Sadhan, Atwi unites them. As for Atiyah, brother of Atwi, from him are three clans: Al-Rashid, Al-Sulayman, and Al-Ali. From them are Al-Salman people of Al-Quway'iyah. As for Al-Rashid and Ali, they are clans and thighs. From their clans are Al-Isa. Al-Isa are thighs; famous among them are Al-Abdullah thigh, Al-Jammaz thigh, Al-Bu Ubayyat and Al-Rabi'ah thigh, and Al-Rabi' and Al-Hassan people of Humayrun thigh. From their clans are Al-Jubayrin people of Al-Quway'iyah and those attached to them. From their clans are Al-Mas'ud people of Al-Sha'ra, and from them Al-Duwayan thigh. These are the famous ones of Banu Zayd. From the clans of Quda'a is Al-Sudah; they are Banu Suwayd bin Nahd bin Zayd bin Aslam bin Layth bin Sud bin Ilhaf mentioned previously. They are clans and thighs. From their clans are Al-Dhukur clan and Al-Qurayshat clan. As for Al-Dhukur, from them are Al-Masha'ibah and Al-Shammasat. From Al-Shammasat are Al-Qababina. From Al-Qababina are Al-Majalli. Al-Qababina are in Dharma; from them is Al-Muhallaq bin Al-Suhul. From the clans of Al-Sudah are Al-Makahilah, Al-Masha'ibah, Al-Mahmid Al-Suhul, Al-Zaqa'in, Al-Ubayd, Al-Manjal, and Al-Sanadilah. As for Al-Qurayshat, they are clans and thighs. From the clans of Al-Sudah are Al-Sudan, people of Bahrain and people of Basra. This ends what we mentioned of Himyar in summary. Section: On the Clans of Hadhramaut bin Qahtan.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Al-Sadif is a clan; they are Banu Aslam bin Zayd bin Malik bin Zayd bin Hadhramaut, who conquered Egypt with Amr bin al-As, may Allah be pleased with him. Al-Quda'i said they settled in Egypt. From them is Jash'am Al-Khalil, the Companion, may Allah be pleased with him, one of those who pledged allegiance under the Tree; the Prophet, peace be upon him, clothed him. In Al-Isti'ab: Banu Bakal is a clan from Hadhramaut, and it is said from Himyar; from them is Manuf Al-Bakka', companion of the Prophet, peace be upon him. Al-Jawhari said: Most of them went and entered Kinda. Al-Jurjani the Genealogist said: There were kings among them approaching the Tubba's in high fame and renown. The first of them to rule was Amr bin Al-Ashnab bin Rabi'ah bin Iram bin Hadhramaut. Then his son Namir Al-Azj ruled one hundred years and fought the Amalekites. Then Kurayb bin Al-Azj ruled one hundred and thirty years. Then Marfad and Marwan, sons of Kurayb, ruled one hundred and forty years. Then Alqamah Dhu Qayfan ruled thirty years. Then his son Dhu 'Ayl bin Dhu 'Ayl ruled twenty years; he lived in Sana'a and raided the land of China, killed its king, and took his sword. When Sinan desired to raid China, Dhu 'Ayl moved to Sana'a. His grip intensified; he was the first of the Yemeni kings to raid the Romans (Rum) and the first to introduce silk and brocade to Yemen. Then his son Bad'at ruled in Hadhramaut forty years. Then his son Bad'il ruled, built fortresses, and left monuments. Then after him, Hammad bin Bad'il ruled in Hadhramaut, built his fortress Al-Mu'aqrab, and raided Persia in the time of Sabur Dhu al-Aktaf (Shapur II); rule lasted for him eighty years. He said he was the first of their kings to adopt screening (Hijab). Then Yashrah bin Dhu Dubb bin Dhu Hammad bin 'Ad ruled one hundred years; he was the first to arrange salaries and build bridges. Then Mun'im bin King Dithar bin Jadhima ruled, then Yashrah bin Jadhima bin Mun'im, then Namir bin Yashrah, then his son Sajin. In his days, the Abyssinians overcame Yemen. From Hadhramaut is Wael bin Hujr to whom the Prophet, peace be upon him, wrote. From his lineage is Ibn Khaldun, author of the History, whose name is Abd al-Rahman bin Muhammad bin Al-Hasan bin Muhammad bin Jabir bin Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Abd al-Rahman bin Khaldun Al-Hadhrami; his lineage connects to Wael bin Hujr. Hadhramaut has dispersed in all regions. In their land, Hadhramaut, are many tribes, as well as in Hijaz and elsewhere. This ends what we summarized of their lineage. Section: On Jurhum bin Qahtan. Jurhum were in Hijaz; they were clans and tribes, and among them were kings. They were inhabitants of Honored Mecca, and they were in Yemen. When Ya'rub bin Qahtan ruled, he appointed his brother Jurhum over Hijaz and made him king. Then his son Abd Yalil bin Yalil ruled after him, then Al-Madan, then his son Badilah bin Al-Madan, then his son Abd al-Masih, then his son Madan, then his son Abd al-Masih, then his son Al-Harith bin Madan, then his son Amr, then his brother Layth bin Al-Harith. They continued as kings until Ishmael, peace be upon him, settled in Mecca. They settled with him, he married from them, learned Arabic, and Al-Khalil (Abraham) came to him. They built the House (Kaaba), and its guardianship was in his hand and some of his sons. Then Jurhum seized the House. Then the Arab tribes were dispersed by the Flood of Al-'Arim. Khuza'a settled upon them and expelled Jurhum from Mecca. They have poems regarding that reason for their expulsion from Mecca, including the testament of Qusay bin Haritha bin Amr bin Amir to his sons: 'A land where the fearful have safety... And birds and beasts in it are safe. In it are the rites and signs which... The Honored Prophet Al-Khalil described. And the House is the House of Allah and the Sanctuary which... Without it is that well of Zamzam. And blood will be shed from them and from... The tribes of Jurhum, O my sons, the furthest blood.' It is said this testament was the reason Khuza'a expelled Jurhum from Mecca, may Allah guard it. Khuza'a preserved the testament, seized the House by it, and expelled Jurhum from Mecca to Yemen. It is said their remnants are there to this day. They have poems and news regarding that which we have no need for. Section: On the Lineage of Kahlan.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: He is Kahlan bin Saba bin Yashjub bin Ya'rub bin Qahtan bin Hud, peace be upon him. It is said in Al-Ibar: Numbers were greater in Kahlan than in Himyar; they used to rotate the Kingship with Himyar. It is said in 'Wills of the Kings': When their father Saba divided between Himyar and Kahlan, he assigned politics to Himyar and the reins of horses and dominion of Outskirts and Frontiers to Kahlan. Mention of them preceded in the beginning of the book. Himyar and Kahlan remained upon that, as did their children and children's children. Himyar had the right of obedience and sufficiency in assigned tasks upon Kahlan. Kahlan had the right of money and succor upon Himyar. The Stationary Kings in the House of Kingdom were from Himyar. The Kings in the Outskirts and Frontiers were from Kahlan. The seat of Himyar kings was Sana'a, and the seat of Kahlan kings was Ma'rib, which Saba, father of Himyar and Kahlan, dammed. Then when Kahlan took charge of the Outskirts and Frontiers and their works, and his matter stabilized on that, he said to his brother Himyar: "I have resolved to send armies to the Outskirts and Frontiers, so order the interests for that." Himyar ordered money, horses, camels, food, and water skins, and obligated the people of his kingdom to comply with what Kahlan indicated. Then Kahlan dispatched Jurhum to the land of Hijaz, appointed over them a man called Hayy bin Bayy bin Jurhum bin Al-Ghawth bin Shaddad bin As'ad bin Jurhum bin Qahtan, ordered them to listen to him and obey, and distributed horses, equipment, and weapons among them. He gave them guides. He wrote with Hayy bin Bayy to the inhabitants of Hijaz from the Amalekites regarding hearing, obedience, and remitting tribute to him. They mentioned that Hayy bin Bayy went out to Hijaz among his people Jurhum and their followers, resided there as governor over it, and overcame the Amalekites. He said: When he settled among them from Najd, he and his followers possessed it, took its tribute from its people, and executed it to Kahlan. Then Kahlan called Amr bin Jahdar, a man from Thamud - it is said he is the grandfather of the Prophet Salih, peace be upon him - and dispatched him to the Valley mentioned by Allah Blessed and Exalted: (And Thamud, who hewed out the rocks in the valley). He ordered his people Thamud to march with him, hear, and obey. He wrote a letter for him to the inhabitants of the Valley, who were a people called Banu Zuhrah bin Imliq. He said: So Amr bin Jahdar marched to the Valley among his people and clan, Thamud, with camels, horses, and equipment, and drove the inhabitants of the Valley out of it until they listened to him and obeyed. Then Kahlan turned to his son Zayd after the death of his brother Himyar, saying to him: "O my son, the Uncle has passed, and the Father is at the end of life." They mentioned that Zayd bin Kahlan preserved his father's testament, stood firm on it, and Al-Hamisa' entrusted him with what his father Kahlan was entrusted with for his brother Himyar. Then Zayd sent to his father's governors in the Outskirts and Frontiers renewing the covenant with them for him; they listened to him, obeyed, and paid him the tribute they used to pay his father. Then Zayd dispatched his son Amr - who is the father of Judham and Lakhm - to Midian and its surroundings. He tied the banner for him, gave him horses, equipment, and men, and ordered them to listen to him, obey, and pay tributes to him. Then Amr bin Zayd bin Kahlan marched to Midian as governor over it until he settled in it, possessed it, its people obeyed him, and he took its tribute. It is said Shu'ayb the Prophet, peace be upon him, is from his lineage. Then Zayd bin Kahlan, when Al-Hamisa' bin Himyar died, turned to his son Malik advising him in poetry. Then Malik bin Zayd bin Kahlan preserved his father's testament and took charge of what his father took charge of regarding Frontiers, Outskirts, and managing armies, in obedience to King Ayman bin Al-Hamisa' bin Himyar. Malik wrote to his father's governors, and they responded with hearing, obedience, and remitting tribute to him. Then Malik bin Zayd dispatched his son Rabi'ah, grandfather of Hamdan; he gave him horses, equipment, and men, tied banners for him over those with him, and wrote a letter for him to the inhabitants of Al-Ajwaf: the people of its plains and mountains from the remnants of 'Ad the Younger whose graves and ruins are known in the mountains and plains; his letter was poetry. Then he dispatched his son Udad bin Zayd bin Kahlan - who is the father of Tayy and Madhhij - to Al-Aghrad and Al-Asrar, from Najran, Tashlab, Bisha, Al-Khawa, and their surroundings of inhabited lands. He gave him horses, equipment, and flags. He wrote to their inhabitants, who were remnants of Aram bin Shem bin Noah; their ruins are clear and their graves known as Al-Iramiyat, being in the shape of hills and domes. Then Udad bin Zayd bin Kahlan marched until he settled among them as governor over them. They listened to him, obeyed, and paid him tribute. Mention of those related to Udad will come in the middle of this book, God willing.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Then Malik died, and his son Nabt took the Kingship in obedience to King Ayman bin Al-Hamisa' bin Himyar. He said: Then Nabt advised his son Thawr, father of Kinda, and Al-Ghawth, father of Al-Azd. They mentioned that Al-Ghawth bin Nabt preserved his father's testament, acted upon it, stood firm on it, and assumed his father's works of Outskirts and Frontiers in obedience to Zuhayr bin Ayman. He wrote to the governors, and they listened to him, obeyed, and paid tributes to him. Then Al-Ghawth dispatched his son Al-Azd to the tribes of Ma'rib and its surroundings, ordering them to listen and obey him. They mentioned that Ma'rib listened to Al-Azd and obeyed him after his father Al-Ghawth. He took charge of what his father Zuhayr bin Ayman took charge of regarding Outskirts and Frontiers. Tribute was raised to him and collected for the governor of the House of Kingship. For every King of the Outskirts and Frontiers, there was a worker from its workers who assumed his work, the most rashid (guided/capable) then the most rashid of his children, brothers, and cousins, raising tribute, listening, obeying, and collecting fees like the affair of those before him in obedience to whoever assumed the Outskirts from Kahlan. Then Ma'rib bin Al-Azd took charge of the Outskirts and Frontiers after his father Al-Azd. 'Arib bin Zuhayr had died, and his son Qatan took the Kingship after him. Then Ma'rib bin Al-Azd swore allegiance to Qatan bin 'Arib when he died, in verses he said. Then Ma'rib bin Al-Azd dispatched his brother Nasr bin Al-Azd to Al-Shihr with horses and equipment. They mentioned that Nasr bin Al-Azd marched to Al-Shihr until he settled it, and they paid him the tax (Kharaj). From his offspring is Al-Julanda bin Karkar bin Al-Sa'bar bin Mas'ud, King of Oman, who used to take every ship by force. The Kingdom remained established in the family of Julanda; what was collected for Al-Julanda was collected for them in their house of kingdom. They mentioned that Ma'rib bin Al-Azd advised his son Tha'labah bin Ma'rib bin Al-Azd in verses of poetry. Then Tha'labah bin Ma'rib bin Al-Azd preserved his father's testament, stood firm on it, obeyed King Qatan bin 'Arib, and assumed the works his father Ma'rib assumed. He wrote to his governors in the Frontiers and Outskirts, and they listened to him, obeyed, and paid tributes to him. Then Tha'labah bin Ma'rib dispatched Ahmas bin Awf bin Anmar bin Arash bin Al-Ghawth bin Nabt bin Malik bin Zayd bin Kahlan to Al-Tur, which is the land called Al-Sarah between Bawa, Ta'if, and Jarash. Then Ahmas and those of Himyar and Kahlan who followed him settled in Al-Sarah and possessed it. He said in 'Wills of the Kings': He asked Abu Ali Al-Hajari about who went out from Anmar bin Arash. He said Aqil bin Anmar, and their remnants are Shahran, Kuf, Nahis, Al-Aws, and Ma'd bin Bajila bin Anmar bin Arash. These tribes are known as: Bajila and Khath'am. Quhafah is a clan of Shahran. Then Tha'labah bin Ma'rib preserved his father's testament and stood firm on it. Then Tha'labah advised his son Imru' al-Qais. Then Imru' al-Qais bin Tha'labah bin Ma'rib bin Al-Azd preserved his father's testament, stood firm on it, and took charge of the Outskirts and Frontiers after his father, in obedience to King Al-Ghawth bin Qatan bin 'Arib. Then he entrusted his son Haritha Dhu al-Ahsab. It is said Al-Ghitrif bin Imru' al-Qais entrusted him with the Frontiers and Outskirts which he used to assume in obedience to the kings of Himyar. Then Haritha took charge of the Outskirts and Frontiers during his father's life and after his death in obedience to King Amr bin Jashm bin Abd Shams, and in obedience to King Al-Qatat bin Amr. Haritha lived over three hundred odd years. Then he advised his son Amir bin Haritha. They mentioned that Amir bin Haritha stood firm on his father's testament, and his sons and the sons of his people acted upon it. He assumed what his father Haritha assumed of Outskirts and Frontiers. They mentioned that Amir is the one Arabs call Ma' al-Sama' (Water of the Sky). This Ma' al-Sama' is the one who dispatched Zayd and the clans of Quda'a to Al-Sham and tied the banner for him. The news of Zayd preceded in the beginning of this book in his lineage in Quda'a. They mentioned that Ma' al-Sama' Amir bin Haritha Dhu al-Ahsab lived three hundred and sixty odd years. He took charge of the Outskirts and Frontiers for some kings of Himyar: Al-Qatat, then Abraha bin Shaddad, then Afriqis bin Abraha. They mentioned that he advised his son Al-Muzayqiya son of Ma' al-Sama', who is Amr bin Amir. Then Amr bin Amir preserved his father's testament, stood firm on it, and took charge of the Kingship after him for the kings of Himyar regarding the Outskirts and Frontiers. He wrote to his father's governors in every land; they listened to him, obeyed, and paid him the tributes they used to pay his father. They mentioned that Amr bin Amir was the wealthiest of the people of his time, having the most money, numbers, and estates. He owned two-thirds of the Garden of Ma'rib. He lived a long life, was blessed with a group of children, and lived until he saw seven generations (fathers) from his offspring, his sons' offspring, and his sons' sons. They mentioned he assumed the Outskirts and Frontiers for the kings of Himyar: Amr bin Abraha, Sharhabil bin Amr, and Al-Hadhhad bin Sharhabil, in-law of the Jinn, father of Bilqis.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: They mentioned that at that time, a soothsayer informed Amr bin Amir of the ruin of Ma'rib and warned him of it, saying to him: "Be cautious in saving yourself from its harm, for you are in the time of the loss of these two gardens." Then Amr bin Amir used a trick on his people. He held a feast gathering his household and clan. He advanced to his son Tha'labah - it is said to Wada'ah, his youngest son - and said to him: "O my son, you know what we are on the verge of regarding the ruin of this Dam and the loss of these two gardens. I have resolved to sell what I own in them, and no one will buy it from me except by a trick I devise. I will exchange words with you in the presence of the notables of the clan from Himyar and Kahlan. Whenever I speak a harsh word to you, reply with similar or harsher. If you see me intending to raise my hand to strike you, raise your hand so people see you intended to strike me, so that I may swear to sell my property in the land of Ma'rib of the two gardens and others, and my exit from it, and people will see I intend good by that." When people gathered at his place for the feast from Himyar and Kahlan, finished eating, washed their hands, and drink was brought near, Amr bin Amir turned to his son Wada'ah and spoke to him with harsh words. Wada'ah replied with words like his and fiercer. Amr raised his hand against his son Wada'ah to slap him. He returned his hand against him and said: "By Allah, if you slap me, I will slap you." At that, Amr bin Amir swore an oath with no expiation to sell all his property in the land of Ma'rib of the two gardens and others, and to leave it. He called out: "Is there a buyer?" When people saw he was serious about selling, they approached him and said: "Do you permit us to bargain with you for your properties?" He said to them: "I have permitted you, so bargain." They said: "We have taken half of what you have for one hundred loads of everything." He said: "It is yours for what you asked." They paid him one hundred loads of everything. The second half was safe for him, and he found no buyer for it, so he left it. He went out from Ma'rib with all his children, family, and clan entirely. He proceeded with numbers known only to Allah of horses, camels, and other types of wealth and grazing livestock. His people and all those with him did not reach a water source but drained it, nor intended a land but made it barren. They sent scouts into the lands seeking water for them. One of their scouts was a man from Banu Amr bin Al-Ghawth; he went out for them guiding to their brothers Hamdan. He saw a narrow land whose pastures and waters would not suffice their livestock. Among their scouts was also 'A'idh bin Abdullah bin Nasr Al-Azdi; he went out scouting and saw a land that could carry them, but its waters and pastures would not suffice their livestock given its large population. So they stayed in Azal and Baridah and their surroundings; their horses, camels, and livestock grazed. Climbing the mountains suited them, and they descended from them into Tihama and overcame Ghafiq there. They stayed in Tihama for some time, then marched to Hijaz. They dispersed from Hijaz into groups; every thigh marched to a land. Some settled in Al-Sarah, some stayed in Mecca and its surroundings, some marched to Mudar then to Iraq and Al-Sham, and some marched to Oman. He said: As for those of Azd who settled in Oman: Yahmad, Al-Haddab, and Malik. As for those who settled in Iraq: Jadhima bin Al-Waddah and the children of Abdullah bin Al-Azd. As for those who settled in Al-Sham: Jafna. As for those who settled in Medina: Aws and Khazraj. As for those who settled in Mecca and its surroundings: Khuza'a. As for those who settled in Al-Sarah: Bajila bin Anmar bin Arash bin Khath'am bin Anmar bin Arash. From Azd are Al-Hijr, Lahb, Narah, 'A'idh, Bariq, Al-Sawam, Haritha, Sinjar, Ali, Oman, Daws, Al-Namir, Hawalah, Al-Buqum, Barqa, Shahran, Amr, and Alma'. All these are from the tribes of Azd and the rest of Kahlan. Then when Amr bin Amir went out with the entirety of his people, Azd, from the land of Ma'rib, Kinda became occupied with the works Amr bin Amir used to handle of Outskirts and Frontiers. Likewise, Madhhij and Hamdan became occupied with the lands and works in their hands. Lakhm and Judham sat, and their lands became occupied with the hardships of Outskirts and Frontiers in them. The children of Nasr bin Al-Azd ended up in the land of Fars and Jua bin Shajar, which is the clan of Al-Julanda bin Karkar. Quda'a spread in Al-Sham, the shoulders of Hijaz, and Najd. Udhrah settled in Hijaz from it, and Juhaynah settled in Radwa. The children of Amr bin Amir advanced on the lands; they did not enter a land but overcame the people of that land. Khuza'a overcame Jurhum in Mecca. Aws and Khazraj overcame the Jews in Medina. Al-Mundhir overcame the people of Iraq there. The family of Jafna overcame the people of Al-Sham there. As for the children of Amr bin Amir bin Haritha, when death approached him, he gathered his sons, his sons' sons, and the sons of his people, addressed them, and advised them. He had eight hundred children; four hundred of them were noble lords, and four hundred were kings.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: In the book 'Wills of the Kings', he said to them in his testament when they attended: "The caller has made you hear, the proof is binding upon you, and the command has reached you... No one is in greater calamity or affliction in his affair than one who wastes certainty and is deceived by hope. Permanence is only after annihilation. We have inherited from those before us, and those after us will inherit from us. Departure has come from a fleeting place and shifting shade. An obscene time and grave matter have cast a shadow upon us. So rectify what you are advancing to, and be content with the Everlasting as a successor to the perishing. Be moderate in seeking livelihood. Endure calamities, for by reckoning (reward with God) you attract blessings. Seek the continuance of honor by gratitude before transfer and the shifting of blessings. Days are turns (states), and you are in them prey to calamities and perils. So desist and leave aside the paths in this deceptive world cut off from its people. In every sandy hill is a height, and with every morsel are choking fits. You do not attain a blessing except by parting with another. You are the successors after the predecessors; ages and days annihilate you, and you are the deaths upon yourselves. In your livelihoods are the causes of your deaths. Nothing prevents you from it, and nothing avails you in it; in every cause among you is a fallen one. These night and day do not raise anything but they put it down; they are worthy of scattering what you gathered. O people: Seek good and its people, and beware of evil and its people. Know that better than good is its doer, and worse than evil is its doer." When Amr bin Amir died, the Arabs continued to preserve the testament he bequeathed in a poem we did not mention, act upon it, conduct their affairs according to it, and advise with it in Jahiliyyah and Islam. They have poems regarding it which Arabs recite in their assemblies and gatherings, and in meeting enemies, honoring the guest, protecting the refuge seeker, and repelling the aggressor. It is mentioned in 'Wills of the Kings' that Qusay bin Amir, who is the father of Khuza'a, advised his sons saying to them: "O my sons: The scout does not lie to his family, and the knowledgeable one does not approve of his ignorance. O my sons, wisdom is a planting in the hearts, like grain in the earth; whatever you plant in noble soil, its vegetation grows and its harvest thrives. Whatever you plant in lying salty soil, its vegetation is bad and its harvest does not thrive. This is so you know that the good only accepts the good, and the good only grows with its like. O my sons: Strive in five things by which you will be mighty and stable: Strive in removing the enemy, supporting the friend, honoring the guest, manufacturing the clan (winning loyalty), protecting the refuge seeker, and attaining what is hoped. I command you with that, and forbid you from what opposes it." They mentioned that the news of Khuza'a expelling Jurhum from Mecca, may Allah guard it, was in preservation of the testament of their father Qusay. They acted upon it until they seized the House to the exclusion of Jurhum, and exiled Jurhum from Mecca to Al-Asdar. It is said remnants of Jurhum exist to this day. They mentioned that Amr bin Amir Al-Khuza'i advised his sons: Ka'b, Adi, and Mus'ad, saying poetry. They mentioned that Al-Harith bin Tha'labah bin Amr bin Amir, who is the father of Aws and Khazraj, turned to his sons saying poetry. It is mentioned in 'Wills of the Kings' that Aws and Khazraj memorized all that their father Tha'labah advised them, stood firm on it, as did their children after them. Their seeking of might and the command by which they would lead others of the Arabs did not cease until the appearance of the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him. So from them came what came of support and Jihad before him, and standing in the face of all Arabs. Then he mentioned that Jafna bin Tha'labah bin Amr bin Amir turned to his sons saying to them: "O my sons, compete in noble deeds and avoid what diverts you from them. I imagine you kings excluding other people. A king is not a king until he is fair, just, giving of wealth, brave, wise, knowledgeable, intelligent, forbearing, neither tyrannical nor oppressive. I have seen you, O my sons, possessing these qualities I enumerated for you. Then by Allah, I know you by them excluding other people. I was given glad tidings of your kingship before you were born. O would that he who witnessed me of my paternal and maternal uncles on that day were existing to this day of mine." Jafna is the first of Ghassan to rule Al-Sham. To him represent the kings of Banu Ghassan whom Hassan bin Thabit mentioned saying: 'To Allah belongs a group I drank with... One day in Jillaq (Damascus) in the first time.'

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: To the end of the poem in which he mentioned Maria their grandmother, wife of Tha'labah bin Amr. She is the daughter of Shamir bin Ghash, King of Himyar, and she is the mother of Al-Harith the Elder. They mentioned that his son Amr bin Al-Harith the Elder advised his son saying poetry. It is mentioned that Amr preserved the testament of his father Al-Harith, stood firm on it, and possessed what his father possessed of the land of Al-Sham and Arab tribes. They mentioned that he prescribed for himself every night a virgin girl he must have from the captives his horses raided from the rebels. That remained his habit until the sister of Amr bin Al-Sa'iq Al-Adwani fell into captivity with him. He said: Amr bin Al-Harith did not notice, having ordered her to be brought, until a youth knocked on the door of the assembly he was in. Amr opened the door and looked out, and lo, a horseman saying poetry: 'O daring King, do you not see... Morning and night, how they gather? Know and be certain that your kingdom is fleeting... And know that as you judge, you shall be judged.' He said: So Amr bin Al-Harith called out and said to him: "Allah has secured you regarding who was with me of yours, or of all people regarding who fell to them of captives." Then he ordered that no captive woman remain but be carried and returned to her family, and released to her whatever was among the prisoners from her family. Then Amr bin Al-Harith advised his son Al-Harith, whom the Arabs call Al-Harith the Lame (Al-A'raj). It is said Amr had a soothsayer informing him of events, warning and cautioning him. Then Al-Harith the Lame preserved his father's testament, stood firm on it, and after him his son Amr bin Al-Harith possessed what he possessed of lands and Arab tribes. Then Al-Harith the Lame advised his son Abu Mundhir Amr bin Hind the Burner (Al-Muharriq) in verses of poetry. Then Amr bin Hind, son of Auf the Shaybani (mother?), preserved his father's testament, stood firm on it, and possessed what his father possessed of Arab lands and others. He was named Al-Muharriq (The Burner) because his maternal uncle, who was being wet-nursed among Banu Tamim, was killed by a man from Al-Barajim. Al-Barajim is a clan of Tamim. He went out to them, killed a great slaughter among them, then took one hundred men alive and burned them in fire; therefore he was named Al-Muharriq. Al-Farazdaq Al-Tamimi mentioned him in his poetry, and Al-Tirimmah Al-Ta'i in his poetry. It is mentioned that Amr advised his son Al-Ayham in verses we did not mention. Then Al-Ayham preserved his father's testament, stood firm on it, acted upon it, and possessed what his father possessed. Then Al-Ayham advised his son Jabala, saying: "O my son, you are the owner of Al-Sham after me, and the master of my affair to the exclusion of my children. You are in the time of possessing this matter which we were given to the exclusion of others. If you see that, look to yourself for what adorns it, and to your people for what protects them." Jabala remained a king obeyed among his people Ghassan; the tribute of Al-Sham came to him. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was sent while Jabala was King of Al-Sham. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, died while Jabala was King of Al-Sham. Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, sat and remained in the Caliphate as long as he did, while Jabala was King of Al-Sham. When it was the time of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, Jabala converted to Islam and came to Medina with five hundred horsemen from the kings of his people, wearers of crowns. He marched as a pilgrim until he entered Honored Mecca. He was circumambulating the House one day of the Hajj days, wearing an Izar and Rida'. A man from Fazara stepped on his Izar. Jabala slapped him a slap that crushed the Fazari's nose. He came with blood flowing on his chest until he stood at the door of Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, and said: "O Commander of the Faithful, give me justice against this tyrant; for he slapped me and left me in this state." Umar said: "Why did you slap the man?" Jabala said to him: "He stepped on my Izar." Umar said to him: "As for you, you have confessed. Either you ransom yourself from him, or you give him the slap (retaliation)." Jabala said: "I will do nothing of what you said." He intended to stir up sedition between him and Umar. They entered upon him and spoke to him, so some of what was in him calmed. People asked him not to make it a sedition, so he agreed to that. When it was some days later, he went out and proceeded to Al-Sham. Then he departed to the land of the Romans with those of Ghassan who followed him. He entered upon Heraclius, King of the Romans, while angry, and converted to Christianity along with his followers. Then he regretted leaving Islam and entering Christianity: 'The nobles became Christian for the sake of a slap... And there was no harm in it had I been patient with it. Obstinacy and pride cost me for it... And substituted the sound eye for the one-eyed. Oh, would that my mother had not borne me, and would that I... Had returned to the saying Umar said. Oh, would that I were herding camels in a wasteland... Or were a prisoner in Rabi'ah or Mudar.' Banu Ghassan are clans. They were named Ghassan after a water at Al-Mashal called Ghassan; whoever drank from it of Azd is Ghassani, and whoever did not drink from it is not Ghassani.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Ghassan is from Banu Amr bin Mazin. Among them are Suraym and Banu Nufayl, who are the Sabr (Patient Ones), named so for their patience in wars. From Banu Suraym are Banu Shaqran clan, and Nimran clan from Ghassan. Banu Numayr is a clan from Amr bin Awf bin Amr bin Adi bin Amr bin Mazin. From them is Al-Harith bin Abi Shamir Al-A'raj Al-Ghassani Al-Jafni; he is not Jafni (paternally), but his mother is from Jafna. From Banu Amr bin Mazin is Abd Al-Masih bin Amr, companion of Khalid bin Al-Walid. From them is Abd Al-Masih Al-Jahid. From them is Satih the Soothsayer, whose name is Rabi'ah. From Banu Ghassan are Banu Jafna mentioned previously; they are from Banu Mazin bin Al-Azd. From them are the Kings of Ghassan in Al-Sham. Al-Iqd Al-Farid says: They are thirty-seven kings who ruled for six hundred and sixteen years, until Islam came. From the tribes of Azd are the Ansar (Helpers), who are Al-Aws and Al-Khazraj, sons of Haritha bin Tha'labah bin Amr bin Amir, and their mother is Qaylah. From the clans of Aws and Khazraj: Banu Amr clan, he is Amr bin Awf bin Malik bin Aws; they are Banu Al-Sam'iyyah, known from Awf as a clan, and from Tha'labah as a clan. Lawzan bin Amr bin Awf bin Malik bin Al-Aws is a clan. From the clans of Aws is Dubay'ah bin Amr bin Awf bin Malik bin Al-Aws. From them is Zayd bin Asim, Al-Ahwas bin Abdullah the Poet, Hanzala the Washed by Angels (Ghasil al-Mala'ika), Abu Sufyan Al-Harith, and Abu Mulayl Al-A'azz. From the clans of Aws is Banu Jayb bin Amr bin Awf bin Malik bin Al-Aws. From them is Suwayd bin Al-Samit, killed by Al-Mukhtar bin Ziyad in Jahiliyyah. From the clans of Aws is Abd Al-Ashhal bin Jashm bin Al-Harith bin Al-Khazraj bin Amr bin Malik bin Al-Aws. From them is Sa'd bin Mu'adh, for whose death the Throne shook, Amr and his brother Sa'd, Al-Harith bin Anas, Ammar bin Ziyad, Usayd bin Al-Hudayr bin Simak, and Rabi'ah bin Zayd. From the clans of Abd Al-Ashhal is Rabi'ah. From them is Rifa'ah bin Qays, Salamah bin Salamah bin Waqsh and his brother Amr, and Rafi' bin Zayd. From the clans of Jashm is Zamjur bin Jashm bin Al-Harith bin Khazraj bin Amr bin Malik bin Al-Aws bin Malik bin Al-Tayhan, and his brother Utbah bin Al-Tayhan. From the clans of Aws: Banu Khatmah, he is Abdullah bin Jashm bin Malik bin Al-Aws. From them is Adi bin Kharashah, Amr bin Kharashah, Aws bin Khalid, Khuzayma bin Thabit Dhu al-Shahadatayn (Owner of Two Testimonies), and Abdullah bin Zayd Al-Qari who governed Kufa for Ibn Al-Zubayr. From the clans of Aws is Waqif bin Malik bin Imru' al-Qais bin Malik bin Al-Aws. From them is Hilal bin Umayyah, Haram bin Abdullah Al-Sulami, and Sa'd bin Khaythamah. From the clans of Aws: Banu 'Amirah, who are the people of Rabikh bin Murrah bin Malik bin Al-Aws. From them is Wael bin Zayd, and Abu Qays bin Al-Aslat. From the clans of Khazraj: Tha'labah bin Amr bin Al-Khazraj. From the clans of Banu Al-Najjar: Ghanm bin Malik bin Al-Najjar. From them is Abu Ayyub Khalid bin Zayd, Thabit bin Al-Nu'man, Suraqah bin Ka'b, Umara bin Hamza, and Zayd bin Thabit bin Al-Nu'man. From the clans of Al-Najjar: Banu Mandal, named Amir bin Malik bin Al-Najjar. From them is Habib bin Amr, Abu 'Awlah - who is Abu Bashir bin Amr - Al-Harith bin Al-Sa'd, and Sahl bin Atik.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From the clans of Al-Najjar: Jadilah, who is Muawiyah bin Amr bin Malik bin Al-Najjar; their mother is Jadilah, and they are known by her. From them is Ubayy bin Ka'b and Abu Habib bin Zayd. From the clans of Al-Najjar: Ibn Muawiyah, who is Adi bin Amr bin Malik bin Al-Najjar. From them is Hassan bin Thabit bin Al-Mundhir bin Haram, poet of Banu Adi bin Al-Najjar. From them is Sulayman bin Milhan and Haram bin Milhan. From them is Surmah bin Anas, companion of the Prophet, peace be upon him, Muhriz bin Amir, Amir bin Umayyah, Abu Hakim Amr bin Tha'labah, Abu Kharijah Amr bin Qays, Thabit bin Khansa', Abu Al-A'war Ka'b bin Al-Harith, and Abu Zayd, father of the six who collected the Quran in the time of the Prophet, peace be upon him. From them is Banu Al-Has-has. From the clans of Al-Najjar: Mazin of Al-Najjar. From them is Habib bin Zayd, whom the Prophet, peace be upon him, sent to Musaylima the Liar, who cut off his hand. From them is Abd al-Rahman bin Ka'b and Qays bin Abi Sa'sa'a. From the remnants of Banu Al-Najjar existing today: Al Abd al-Qadir, residents of the land of Al-Ahsa; they are a house of knowledge and judiciary. From the clans of Khazraj: Banu Al-Harith Banu Al-Khazraj. From them is Abdullah bin Rawahah, Khallad bin Zayd, Sa'd bin Al-Rabi', Kharijah bin Zayd, Thabit bin Qays bin Shammas the Orator of the Prophet, peace be upon him, killed on the Day of Yamamah, Bashir bin Sa'd and his father Al-Nu'man bin Bashir, Zayd bin Arqam, Ibn Al-Itnabah the Poet, Zayd bin Al-Harith the Poet, Abu Al-Darda' Abdullah bin Zayd who saw the Adhan, Subay' bin Qays, and Muharim bin Ka'b the Poet. From the clans of Khazraj: Banu Khudrah bin Awf bin Al-Harith bin Al-Khazraj. From them is Abu Mas'ud, Abdullah bin Al-Rabi', and Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri. From the clans of Khazraj: Banu Sa'ida bin Ka'b bin Al-Khazraj. From them is Sa'd bin Ubadah, Al-Mundhir bin Amr, Abu Dujana Simak bin Aws, Sahl bin Sa'd, Abu Usayd Malik bin Rabi'ah, and Maslamah bin Mukhallad. From the clans of Khazraj: Banu Salim bin Awf bin Al-Khazraj. From them is Al-Zaman bin Zayd the Poet, and Malik bin Al-Ajlan. From the clans of Khazraj: Banu Al-Qawqal Ghanm bin Amr bin Awf bin Al-Khazraj. From them is Ubadah bin Al-Samit, Khalid bin Al-Rakhsh, and Al-Harith bin Al-Humah. From the clans of Khazraj: Banu Bayadah and Banu Zurayqah. From them is Ziyad bin Labid, Farwah bin Amr, and Khalid bin Qays. Also Amr bin Al-Nu'man, head of Khazraj, and Al-Ajlan bin Zayd bin Salim bin Awf bin Amr bin Awf bin Al-Khazraj. From them is Abdullah bin Fadlah, Ayyash bin Ubadah, Sulayk bin Badrah, Ismat bin Al-Husayn bin Wabrah, and Ibn Khaythamah Malik bin Qays Al-Hubla. They are clans from Ghanm bin Awf bin Al-Khazraj; named Al-Hubla (Pregnant) due to the greatness of his belly. From them is Abdullah bin Ubayy bin Salul, head of the Hypocrites, his son Abdullah, and Aws bin Khawli. Ibn Zurayq is a clan from Amir bin Zurayq bin Haritha bin Malik bin Ghadb bin Jashm bin Al-Khazraj. From them is Banu Lawzan bin Abd Qays, Abu Ubadah Sa'd bin Uthman, Uqbah bin Tamim, Al-Harith bin Tamim, Al-Harith bin Qays, Abu Abbas bin Muawiyah, Mas'ud bin Sa'd, Rifa'ah bin Rafi', and Abu Rafi', the first of the Ansar to accept Islam. From the clans of Khazraj: Banu Salama bin Sa'd bin Ali bin Asad bin Sharidah bin Jashm bin Al-Khazraj. From them is Jabir bin Abdullah, Mu'adh bin Al-Simmah, Kharash, Utbah bin Abi Amir, Mu'adh bin Amr bin Al-Jamuh who cut off Abu Lahab's leg, his brother Mu'awwidh, Abu Qatada Al-Nu'man bin Rib'i, Ka'b bin Malik the Poet, poet of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, Abu Malik bin Ka'b, Bishr bin Abd al-Rahman, Al-Zubayr bin Haritha, Abu Al-Khattab Abd al-Rahman bin Abdullah, Ma'n bin Wahb - these five are poets - and Abdullah bin Atik. This is the lineage of the Ansar and their clans, may Allah be pleased with them. Section: From the clans of Azd: Khuza'a. They are Banu Amr bin Rabi'ah bin Haritha bin Amr bin Amir, King of the Dam. They were called Khuza'a only because they separated (Inkhaza'u) from the children of Ibn Amir in their departure from Yemen; so they separated from their people and settled in Mecca, thus were named Khuza'a. They dispersed into the rest of Azd as we mentioned at the beginning of this book.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Amr bin Amir had children: Jafna, father of Banu Jafna; Tha'labah, father of the Ansar; Haritha, father of Khuza'a; Malik; Ka'b; Wada'ah, who is Al-Lattum, grandfather of Banu Zayid Al-Dawasir. It says in Al-Iqd Al-Farid: Wada'ah is in Hamdan. Also Awf, Dhuhl, Wael, Abu Haritha, and Imran. It is said that Abu Haritha, the family of Imran, and Wada'ah did not drink from the water of Ghassan; therefore, they are not called Ghassanids. All are from the children of Amr bin Amir. From the clans of Khuza'a: Banu Salul bin Ka'b bin Rabi'ah bin Haritha bin Amr bin Amir. From Banu Salul is Khalil bin Habshiyah, master of the House before Quraysh. From them is Al-Muhtarish bin Khalil bin Habshiyah who sold the key of the Kaaba. From Banu Habshiyah is Kurz bin Alqamah, who tracked the footsteps of the Prophet, peace be upon him, until he entered the Cave. From them is Tariq bin Bahilah the Poet. From the clans of Khuza'a is Numayr, a clan from Habshiyah bin Salul. From them is Bishr bin Sufyan to whom the Prophet, peace be upon him, wrote, and Jaljalah bin Amr mentioned by Al-Kindur in his poetry. From his descendants is Qabisah bin Dhi'b. Banu Dhi'b is a clan from Khuza'a; from them are Al-Dhibah, the clan known in Otaybah. Banu Kulayb is a clan from Habshiyah. From them is Abdullah bin Tahir Al-Khuza'i, minister of Al-Ma'mun bin Harun Al-Rashid, who undertook the war against Al-Amin until he was killed; he was a man of opinion and courage. From them is Al-Saffah the Poet, and Kharash bin Umayyah, ally of Banu Makhzum. From Banu Habshiyah is Hafs bin Hajir the Poet. It is said that Banu Hajir are from his descendants and not from Janb. From them is Urwah bin Iyas the Poet. Banu Iyas is a clan from Habshiyah of Khuza'a. It is said Banu Iyas are Banu Oman. Among those attributed to Iyas is Ibn Qabisah Al-Ta'i. From the clans of Khuza'a is Ma'bad. Banu Ma'bad is a clan. Ma'bad Atikah is the one whom the Prophet, peace be upon him, stayed with when he migrated to Medina. Ma'bad is a clan of Khuza'a; from their remnants is the clan known in Harb, the group of Ibn Asm. They are from Banu Salul bin Ka'b bin Talhah bin Abdullah bin Kurayz. From this Banu Kurayz are the Kurzan, the clan known among the people. It is mentioned in the book 'Wills of the Kings' that they are from the Arabs of the Dam who moved with Amr bin Amir and settled in Al-Sarah, they and Hawalah the clan from Azd. From the Kurzan mentioned are Kurzan of Al-Buqum, and the Kurzan in Barqa. It is said in 'Wills of the Kings' that Barqa are from the Arabs of the Dam who settled in Al-Sarah, containing clans and thighs. From Kurzan of Al-Muqatta'ah are six clans: Al-Masa'ibah, from whom are Dhawi Hamad clan; Al-Rawsan, group of Ibn Kabil clan; Dhawi Khudayr clan; Al-Alabiyah clan; Al-Qamzah, group of Ibn Khuthaylah clan; Al-Hawabid clan, from whom are Al-Jarafah; Dhawi Musay'id and Al-Khaljan clan. The rest of Al-Muqatta'ah are Al-Hawarinah clan and Al-Ghazaliyah clan; these are from Barqa and not in Kurayz. Al-Khanafirah clan; they are in Khanafir of Madhhij. From the clans of Al-Buqum are Al-Maraziq clan, Al-Sumyan clan, Al-Rahman clan - from whom is Al-Rahimi - Al-Numur clan, and Al-Kalbah clan, from whom are Fudul. From Al-Fudul are Al-Suwayd people of Al-Qasab, and Al-Uthman in Al-Bakriyah. Banu Talhah bin Abdullah bin Kurayz from Banu Aktham clan; they trace back to Aktham bin Abd Al-Ghawth. Sulayman bin Surad Al-Jawni; these are a clan from Talhah. From them is Mut'ib bin Al-Akwa' the Poet. Banu Anasir is a clan from Amr bin Habshiyah; from them is Imran bin Husayn, companion of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and Abu Jahfah Kuthayyir Azza the Poet, deeply involved in praise and satire. From the clans of Khuza'a is Banu Ja'dah; from them is Abu Al-Kind Abu Abd Al-Aziz. From the clans of Khuza'a is Banu Mulayh. From them is Abdullah bin Khalaf and his brother Sulayman; they were with Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, on the Day of the Camel. From them is Talhah, called Talhat al-Talhat (Talha of Talhas), the most generous Arab in Islam. From them is Abdullah bin Salim. From them is Budayl bin Warqa' to whom the Prophet, peace be upon him, wrote, and his sons Nafi' and Abdullah. From them is Muhammad bin Samrah who was noble. From the clans of Khuza'a is Luhayman bin Amr bin Sa'd bin Ka'b. From them is Matrud bin Ka'b, Abdullah bin Al-Hurr companion of the Prophet peace be upon him, Abu Malik Al-Qa'id bin Abdullah, Al-Husayn bin Naslah master of the people of Tihama, and Al-Harith bin Asad companion of the Prophet peace be upon him. From the clans of Khuza'a: Banu Al-Mustaliq, a clan from Sa'd bin Ka'b. From them is Juwayriyah bint Al-Harith, wife of the Prophet, peace be upon him.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From the clans of Azd: Banu Aslam bin Qusay bin Haritha bin Amr bin Amir. From them is Salamah bin Al-Akwa', companion of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and Buraydah bin Al-Husayn, companion of the Prophet, peace be upon him. From them is Banu Aqsa bin 'Amlaw bin Amir clan; from them is Dhu al-Shimalayn, Umarah bin Fahd, and Nafi' bin Abd Al-Harith who governed Mecca for Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him. From the clans of Aqsa: Banu Malik clan. From them is Uwaymir, and Harmad bin Rizah who was noble, and his father Burdah the Companion, may Allah be pleased with him. From the clans of Azd: Banu Bariq and Banu Al-Hajn clan. They are from Banu Haritha bin Amr bin Amir. From Banu Bariq is Suraqah bin Mirdas and Ja'far the Poet. Bariq and Al-Hajn are from Ghassan. Ghassan is water at Al-Mashal previously mentioned. Of Ghassan, there is a large multitude and abundant gathering in Balqa and Yarmouk, and a faction in Homs. Among the remnants of the Kings of Ghassan in Al-Sham is Emir Shakib. Of Ghassan, there are people in Syria, some Muslims and some Christians. From the clans of Khuza'a: Banu Al-Rab'ah clan; Abu Ubaydah said they entered into Zubaid. From Ghassan is Al-Samaw'al bin 'Adiya Al-Ghassani from Banu Al-Dayyan, a clan of Ghassan. His home was in Tayma. He followed Judaism in the Jahili century. He was counted among the faithful; Imru' al-Qais bin Hujr entrusted him with his family and armor. Al-Samaw'al chose the killing of his son over [surrendering] his deposits when the king of his time demanded them, having bound his son, saying: "We kill your son or you surrender the deposits." He chose the killing of his son. He is the one saying poetry: 'If a man does not sully his honor with meanness... Then every robe he wears is beautiful. And if he does not carry himself against injustice... Then there is no way to good praise.' From the clans of Azd: Alma', known as Rijal Alma', from Banu Amr bin Amir. From the clans of Azd: Al-Hijr, their dwellings are in Al-Sarah. From the clans of Al-Hijr: Banu Al-Harith. From them is Al-Shanfara; he was one of the counted horsemen of the Arabs, runners, and articulate poets. He is, as in Al-Jamharah and others, from Banu Al-Harith bin Rabi'ah bin Al-Aws bin Al-Hijr bin Al-Hun. Al-Hun is a clan from Azd. From the clans of Azd from Banu Mazin: Banu Imran bin Amr bin Amir. From them is Al-Muhallab bin Abi Sufrah and Yazid bin Al-Muhallab; Yazid was one of the most generous people of his time, in Basra. His son Makhlad bin Yazid had fame in generosity and was Emir over Khurasan. From Banu Imran: Banu Al-Atik clan. From them is Amr bin Al-Ashraf, and his son Ziyad who was noble. From them is Thabit bin Quhaytah the Poet. Banu Mazin from Banu Al-Atik clan; from them is Abu Shajarah bin Jahfah who migrated with the Prophet, peace be upon him. From them is Khalid bin Salamah bin Suraym bin Al-Atid. From the clans of Azd is Banu Masikhah bin Abd bin Malik bin Nasr bin Al-Azd; from them is Jamhah bin Al-Harith. From Azd is Zahran clan. From them is Banu Al-Namir bin Uthman bin Al-Nadr bin Zahwan. From them is Abu Al-Kind, companion of Mas'ud; he was killed on the Day of Fijar. From them is Abu Jahm bin Habib; Jahm is a clan of them. From them is Banu Jahm, the clan mentioned in Harb. Abu Jahm was a governor for Banu Ja'far. From them is Abu Buraym Hudhayfah bin Abdullah, bearer of the banner of Azd on the Day of Rustam. From them is Al-Buhruth bin Al-Husayn. From the clans of Azd is Zahwan clan and Banu Nahwah clan. From Zahwan is Ghamed clan of Zahwan. From the clans of Azd is Shanu'a; they are from Banu Muawiyah bin Shams bin Amr bin Ghanm bin Ghalib bin Uthman bin Nasr bin Al-Azd. From them is Banu Zahwan clan and Banu Hudan clan. From them is Banu Sabr bin Sulayman; Sabr was the head of Azd on the Day of the Camel. From Banu Nasr bin Al-Azd is the clan of Al-Julanda King of Oman. From them are Abd and Jayfar, King of Oman; the Prophet, peace be upon him, wrote to them. They are Banu Al-Julanda the Younger. From them are Al-Ghitrif the Elder and the Younger. From the clans of Zahwan are Banu Sibalah clan, Banu Hudruj clan, Banu Rasm clan, Banu Umar clan. From them is Banu Khath'amah bin Yashkur bin Asir bin Sa'b bin Dahman. From this Asir is Asir, the known tribe inhabitants of Abha and Al-Tur; among their chiefs are Al Mar'i. From the clans of Khath'amah is Rasib clan; from them is the leader of the Kharijites. It is said Rasib is from Quda'a. From the clans of Azd is Thumalah clan from Banu Awf bin Aslam bin Hajn bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Ka'b bin Abdullah bin Malik bin Nasr bin Al-Azd.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: The dwellings of Thumalah are near Ta'if; they are people of narration and intellect. From them is Ibn Yazid the Grammarian known as Al-Mubarrad. From the clans of Thumalah is Banu Mafraj, who is Mafraj bin Malik bin Hajn bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Ka'b bin Abdullah bin Malik bin Nasr bin Al-Azd. From them is Dhawi Mafraj, the clan known in Barqa. They are clans and thighs: Al-Jahad clan, Al-Harama clan, Al-Ghawasib clan, Al-Dara'in, Al-Majadilah clan, and Al-Harsah clan; these are the famous ones. From Thumalah is Banu Lahb clan; they are Lahb bin Bujayr bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Ka'b mentioned previously. From them is Al-Mahbalah, the clan known in Harb. From the clans of Azd is Banu Kurd bin Ali bin Amr, and Banu Amr bin Amir from Azd; from them are the Kurds of the people of Al-Sham. From the clans of Azd is Daws bin Adnan, and it is said Adnan is from Banu Abdullah bin Zahwan. From them is Banu Jamhah bin Al-Harith bin Rafi', who was the master of Daws in Jahiliyyah; he was one of the most generous Arabs and used to feed pilgrims in Mecca. From Daws is Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him; his name is Abd al-Rahman bin Sakhr. From Daws is Jadhima Al-Abrash; he is Jadhima bin Bakr bin Fahm bin Ghanm Daws, who was King of Iraq before the Lakhmids. From them is Jahdam clan; they are from Banu Awf bin Malik bin Fahm. Among them were kings mentioned previously, and that they are from Quda'a. From the clans of Daws are Al-Qasamilah clan, Al-Jaramizah clan, Al-Qaradis clan, and Al-Ashaqir clan. From them are from Banu 'A'idh bin Daws. From the clans of Zahwan is Akk, from Banu Abdullah bin Zahwan, and Qarn clan from Zahwan. It is said Zahwan is the brother of Daws, and it is said son of Daws. From them is Hakim bin Naqba, and Banu Hashim in Khurasan. From the clans of Daws is Al-Namir, and it is said from Shanu'a. From the clans of Shanu'a is Banu Lutb clan of Shanu'a; from them are the people of the House of Kufa, and from them Ibn Al-Lutbiyah Al-Azdi whom the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, employed. From the clans of Shanu'a is Al-Yahmad clan; from them is Al-Harith bin Husayn, one of the men of Hadith. From the clans of 'A'idh mentioned previously is Al-Dabab clan. From 'A'idh is Subyan bin Al-Azj, master of 'A'idh; he came as a delegation to the Prophet, peace be upon him. From the clans of Shanu'a is Ubaydah clan, and Janab bin Umayyah bin Khath'amah clan; from them is Imran bin Khath'amah, the first to build the wall of the Kaaba. Muslim is a clan from Shanu'a; from them is Aqil bin Umar who came as a delegation to the Prophet, peace be upon him. From the clans of Shanu'a is Barshan clan, Al-Lat clan, Salamah clan of Shanu'a, Judah clan, and Jahdam clan of Shanu'a; from them is Al-Hajjaj Al-Jahdami. Banu Ali is a clan from Shanu'a in Tihama; from them is Khuza'a and Al-Zahran Bani Ali. From the clans of Shanu'a is Al-Qayt clan, Banu Al-Qay clan - called Li'b Qafah, Banu Jarmuz clan, Abna' Abdullah clan, and Banu Masikhah clan, to whom Masikhi bows are attributed. These are Shanu'a. Section: From the clans of Azd is Al-Dawasir. Shihab Al-Maqri said in the book 'Al-Ta'rif': Al-Dawasir are from the Arabs in Yemen. He said in 'Nihayat Al-Arab': They are the children of Al-Azayid from Banu Wada'a bin Amr bin Amir, King of the Dam. In 'Al-Iqd Al-Farid': Wada'a bin Amr bin Amir entered into Hamdan. Al-Suwaydi mentioned them in Hamdan. In the commentary on the Diwan of Ibn Muqarrab: Wada'a is the youngest son of Amr bin Amir, and he is Al-Maltum (The Slapped One), not as mentioned previously in 'Wills of the Kings' that Al-Maltum is Tha'labah grandfather of Aws and Khazraj; for the correct view is that Al-Maltum is Wada'a grandfather of Zayid, and they mixed with Hamdan. The Dawasir are dispersed clans and thighs. Some are in Oman, Bahrain, Iraq, and Najd. Their lands are Al-Wadi and Al-Aflaj. They are settled and Bedouin. From their clans are Al-Wada'in. They are clans and thighs gathering in Ghanim bin Nasir bin Wad'an bin Salim bin Zayid bin Ziyad bin Salim bin Wada'a bin Amr bin Amir. From Al-Wada'in are Al-Husayn, Al-Shawish, Al-Duwayhi people of Al-Awda, Al-Hamad, Al-Mutrib, Al-Sultan, and Al-Abd Al-Muhsin, residents of the town of Al-Safra and Al-Qarinah. From them are Al-Shammas people of Al-Shamaliyah, and Al-Turqan people of Al-Zulfi. From Al-Wada'in are Al-Dayil in Marat. They are three thighs: Al-Hamad thigh, Al-Abdullah thigh, and Al-Ibrahim thigh, who are children of Sulayman. Attached to them is Al-Abd Al-Muhsin thigh. From the clans of Zayid are Al-Makharim clan, Al-Rujban clan - from them are Al-Jubayl residents of the village of Al-Taraf in Al-Ahsa; these are in Salim. Al-Ammar clan, Al-Farjan clan, Al-Harajin and Al-Shukrah clan, Al-Ghubayshat clan - from them is Al-Ghubayshah the clan known in Hamdan - Al-Hawamilah clan, and Al-Sakharibah clan.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: These gather in Suhayb bin Salim. From the clans of Zayid are Al-Badarin; he is Badran bin Salim. The Badarin are thighs, the most famous being Al-Sudara (Al-Sudairi). They are the children of Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Sulayman bin Fawzan bin Turki bin Abd Al-Muhsin bin Muhammad bin Khalid bin Ahmad bin Farij bin Nasir bin Abdullah bin Muljim bin Husayn bin Abd Al-Wahhab bin Amir bin Suwayd bin Sulayman bin Muhsin bin Zayd bin Amir bin Ghalib bin Muhsin bin Jawad bin Sudayr bin Shakir bin Hajjal bin Mushajja' bin Hamdan bin Ghayid bin Badr bin Khamis bin Amir bin Badran bin Salim bin Zayid bin Salim bin Ziyad bin Salim bin Wada'a bin Amr bin Amir bin Haritha bin Imru' al-Qais bin Tha'labah bin Ma'rib bin Al-Azd bin Al-Ghawth bin Malik bin Nabt bin Malik bin Zayd bin Kahlan bin Saba bin Yashjub bin Ya'rub bin Qahtan bin Hud, peace be upon him. From Al-Badarin are Ibn Al-Awamir. From Al-Badarin are Al-Habasa people of Al-Zulfi. As for the children of the mentioned Ahmad, they are six: Muhammad, Turki, Abd Al-Muhsin, Abd Al-Aziz, Sa'd, and Abd Al-Rahman who is the youngest. Their residence was Al-Ghat, the known town in Sudair in Najd. As for Ahmad bin Abd Al-Rahman, his residence is Al-Ahsa. Ahmad and his children are people of leadership, virtue, and generosity. Sulayman, grandfather of Ahmad, was famous for generosity. From the children of Abd Al-Rahman is Ahmad bin Abd Al-Rahman bin Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Sulayman. From the clans of Al-Sudayr are Al-Amir, who gather with Banu Khalid in Abd Al-Wahhab bin Sulayman bin Amir mentioned previously. Al-Sulayman and Al-Suwayd people of Jalajil gather in Suwayd bin Sulayman. Al-Sudayr residents of Al-Ramadi gather in Shakir bin Hajjal mentioned previously. Al-Fawzan residents of Al-Bir. From the clans of Shakir bin Hajjal are residents of Tunis. From Al-Mushajja' bin Hamdan mentioned previously, there is a faction in Oman, a faction in Zanzibar, and a faction from Amman. From Al-Badarin are Al-Hadban people of Jalajil, Al-Sa'id, Al-Umar, Al-Ghazi, Al-Imran, and people of Al-Awda. These are in Sudair. Al-Yahya in the town of Al-Bir. These are the Badarin. Attached to them are Al-Rujban, Al-Makharim, and Al-Wada'in in Salim bin Zayid. From the clans of Dawasir are Al-Hassan; they attach to them in Salim bin Zayid. Al-Hassan are clans. From their clans are Al-Farjan from the children of Faraj bin Hassan. Al-Hawamilah is a clan of Al-Hassan; from them are Hawamil of Mutayr residents of Mabayid, and from them are Al-Hawamil in Da'ajin of Otaybah, called Dhawi Rahmah. From the clans of Al-Zayid are Al-Masa'irah clan; from them is Al-Abu Siba'. Al-Harajin clan. Al-Ghayth clan; from them are Ghayathin of Al-Murrah. Al-Sharafa clan. From the clans of Banu Zayid are Al-Hanatish; attached to them are Al-Hanatish in Otaybah, group of Ibn Muhayya, and Al-Qaribah people of Al-Sawh near Al-Dahinah. From Al-Badarin are Al-Badarin, the clan known in Harb, group of Ibn Rajih. From the clans of Zayid are Al-Awamir, the clan known in Hamdan; from them are Al-Awamir who are with Badar Ibn Harb. These are the famous ones from the clan of Zayid bin Salim bin Wada'a bin Amr bin Amir mentioned previously. From this Wada'a are clans and thighs in the Arabs of Al-Sarah and in the Arabs of Hamdan. From Al-Badarin are Al-Akrad (Kurds) residents of Al-Mubarraz in Al-Ahsa, Al-Fazarah, Al-Sa'd bin Muhammad, and Al-Salim residents of the village of Al-Uyun in Al-Ahsa from Al-Shukrah. Section: On Anmar brother of Al-Azd. He is Anmar bin Arash bin Amr bin Al-Ghawth bin Nabt bin Malik bin Zayd bin Kahlan. Some genealogists used to attribute clans from this Anmar to Anmar bin Nizar, but Ibn Nizar had no offspring. Al-Kalbi mentioned that Anmar bin Nizar had no offspring except what is said in Bajila. It says in Al-Ibar: Bajila denies this and says that Arash bin Amr married Salamah daughter of Anmar bin Nizar, so she bore him Anmar bin Arash and she bore him Khath'am, named after a camel. The mother of Khath'am bin Anmar bin Arash is Hind daughter of Malik bin Al-Amir bin Al-Shahid bin Akk. Anmar bin Arash also married the daughter of Sa'b bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah, so she bore him Abqar, Al-Ghawth, Suhaybah, and Khuzaymah; their mother is Bajila, they were known by her. It says in Al-Ibar: The lands of Bajila along with their brothers Khath'am were in the Sarawat in Yemen, and in Hijaz up to Qabalah. Then they dispersed in the days of Islamic conquest, and only a few remained in their homelands. From Bajila is Jarir bin Abdullah Al-Bajali; he was beautiful. He is the one about whom it is said: 'Were it not for Jarir, Bajila would have perished; what an excellent youth and what a wretched tribe.' From the clans of Bajila is Al-Samhah; they are Banu Al-Samhah bin Sa'd bin Abdullah bin Tha'labah bin Muawiyah bin Zayd bin Bajila bin Anmar bin Arash. From them is Judge Abu Yusuf, companion of Imam Abu Hanifa, and Ya'qub bin Ibrahim bin Jaysh, counted among the Ansar.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From the clans of Bajila is Banu Amir, who is Amir bin Qadad bin Tha'labah bin Muawiyah bin Zayd bin Bajila. Abu Ubaydah said: This Amir is called Muqallad Al-Dhahab (The Gold-Adorned). From them is Amr bin Khasharim the Poet. From the clans of Bajila is Ahmas bin Al-Ghawth bin Bajila; his name prevailed over his sons, so they were called Ahmas. Hamasa means bravery. From them is Husayn bin Rabi'ah bin Amir Al-Azwar Al-Ahmasi, and Jabir bin Awf Al-Ahmasi, the two Companions. From the clans of Bajila is Kalb bin Umar bin Lu'ayy bin Dahn bin Muawiyah bin Aslam bin Ahmas mentioned. From them is Al-Hajjaj bin Dhi Al-Itq; Abu Ubaydah said he was noble among his people. From the clans of Ahmas bin Bajila is Banu Naqr clan of Bajila, and Banu Qays clan of Banu Al-Ghawth. From the clans of Bajila is Abqar mentioned previously; they are three clans: Banu Alqamah clan - from them is Jundub bin Abdullah Al-Bajali Al-Alqami the Companion; Al-Suru clan - in these is good Islam and tender hearts; and Banu Qasr - it is said with dotted Shin Qashr - clan. From Banu Qasr is Banu Nadhir clan. From the clans of Anmar is Al-Tabi' clan of Anmar, Banu Farak clan of Anmar, Banu Fasa clan of Anmar Uraynah. Banu Uraynah is a clan; he is Uraynah bin Nadhir bin Qasr bin Anmar bin Arash. From them is the group who came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and were afflicted with a disease, so he sent them to the charity camels to drink from their milk and urine. They recovered, killed the herders, and drove off the camels. He (peace be upon him) sent a party after them, so they were brought. He branded their eyes and left them in the Harrah asking for water but not given water. From Uraynah are thighs in Hijaz and Najd. From the clans of Bajila is Jarm, mentioned by Al-Hamdani but he did not connect their lineage to Bajila. From the clans of Bajila is Banu Awd clan of Qays Bajila. Abu Ubaydah said: Al-Ahtam is a clan of Bajila; they are Banu Ahtam bin Masbalah. Section: On Khath'am mentioned previously in Anmar bin Arash. Khath'am had a child Khalaf, and his mother was Atikah bint Rabi'ah bin Nizar. It says in Al-Ibar: Their lands are with their brothers Bajila as preceded. They are clans of Khath'am Banu Ufayr bin Khalaf. From Banu Ufayr is Banu Kalb clan of Khath'am. Abu Ubaydah said: It is said Aklab, from Rabi'ah bin Nizar. The correct view is that he is Aklab bin Ufayr bin Khalaf bin Anmar bin Arash, and upon him is the decision. From Banu Aklab is Bishr bin Rabi'ah who says poetry: 'I made my she-camel kneel at the Gate of Qadisiyah... While Sa'd bin Waqqas is Emir over me.' From them is Anas bin Mudrikah and Ibn Al-Dumaynah the Poet. From Banu Aklab are Al-Dammasin, people of Majas Al-Shifar (?), inhabitants of Bu Jalal. From Aklab are many clans in Bisha, settled and Bedouin. From them are Al-Mazayidah and Al-Janabah, group of Ibn Sahman, Al-Mani', Banu Sa'd, Al-Jabrah, Al-Bishr, Al-Samrah, Banu Julayh, and Banu Mubashir. These are Banu Aklab. From them and from the clans of Khalaf bin Khath'am is Nahish; they are with their brothers Shahran. From Nahish are Al-Muha (Al-Mawah) from whom are Al-Dawshan; they are clans of Alwa in Mutayr. From them are Al-Amarah, Al-Sa'anin, and Al-Rakhman. From them and their brothers is Shahran. From the clans of Nahish are Al-Badnah, and Al-Mahalisah in Burayh. From the clans of Shahran is the clan known in Khamis Mushait, their ancient lands; their elder is Ibn Mushait. In Shahran and Nahish is numbers and honor. From them is Banu Kud bin Afras clan. From the clans of Shahran is Banu Harb; he is Aws bin Wahb Allah bin Shahran. From them is Banu Arfajah bin Ka'b bin Malik bin Qahfah bin Amir bin Rabi'ah bin Amir bin Sa'd bin Malik bin Al-Nasr bin Wahb Allah bin Shahran. From Qahfah is Abdullah bin Malik, governor of Ta'if for forty years for Muawiyah and others. When he died, forty banners were broken on his grave. From them is Julayhah, Al-Rayth, and Mubashir. From them is Jashm bin Sa'd clan; he is Jashm bin Sa'd bin Amir bin Taym Allah. From the clans of Khath'am is Banu Munabbih clan, Muawiyah clan, Al-Mahdi clan, Al-Nasr clan, Banu Atim clan, Al-Mawrakah clan, and Banu Nazlah clan. Al-Hamdani said: And Banu Halimah clan, Banu Harz clan, Al-Asafir clan, Al-Shamr clan, and Yalus clan. All these are in Khath'am bin Anmar bin Arash. Al-Hamdani said: Their dwellings are Bisha. Attached to them are Banu Shahr, group of Al-Asbali, Banu Al-Ahmar clan, Banu Al-Asmar clan, and Banu Wada'a clan of Bajila. As for Wada'a, as we presented, he is from the offspring of Amr bin Amir. This ends what we mentioned of the lineage of Azd. Section: On Tayy. He is Tayy bin Udad bin Zayd bin 'Arib bin Yashjub bin 'Arib bin Udad bin Zayd bin Kahlan.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Udad had children: Tayy, Madhhij, A'r (Ash'ar?), and Murrah. They mentioned in 'Wills of the Kings' that Zayd bin Kahlan dispatched Udad to Al-A'rad and Al-Asrar of Najran, Tathlith, Sadum, Al-Hanu, and surrounding inhabited lands. He sent elephants and equipment with him, and wrote to their inhabitants, who were remnants of 'Ad bin Iram bin Shem bin Noah peace be upon him. Their ruins are clear, and their graves are known as Al-Iramiyat because they are in the shape of hills. The testament of Zayd to Udad has preceded in this book. It is mentioned that Tayy bin Udad took the Kingship after his father Udad and preserved his father's testament. They mentioned that Tayy lived a long life, exceeding four hundred odd years. They mentioned he advised his sons in verses of poetry. He said the dwellings of Tayy were anciently in Al-Jurf of the land of Yemen. They left following the departure of Azd from it and settled in Samira, it is said in the neighborhood of Banu Asad bin Khuzayma. Then they overcame them for Aja and Salma, two mountains in the land of Tayy known as the Two Mountains of Tayy, so they continued there and dispersed in the Islamic conquests. Abu Sa'id said: From them are many nations filling the plain and mountain of Hijaz, Najd, Iraq, and Sham. They are the owners of leadership among the Arabs to this day in Iraq and Sham. They are many clans. Tayy had children: Al-Ghawth, Qatrah, and Al-Harith. To Qatrah was born Sa'd; Sa'd married Jadila daughter of Subay' bin Himyar the Younger, so they were known by her. They are called Jadila after their mother's name. Tayy was two tribes: Jadila and Al-Ghawth. From the clans of Al-Ghawth is Banu Jarm; his name is Tha'labah bin Amr bin Al-Ghawth. From the clans of Jarm is Banu Jayyan clan; from them is Imam Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Malik the Grammarian, Al-Ta'i Al-Jayyani, author of famous works (Alfiyya). From Banu Jarm is Shamjan clan. From its clans is Jadhima mentioned by Al-Hamdani. From them is Banu Al-Udhrah clan of Jadhima; their dwellings are the land of Gaza. Banu Al-Ajilah of Jadhima of Jarm Tayy; their dwellings are with their people. Al-Abadilah clan of Jadhima of Jarm Tayy; their dwellings are with their people in the land of Gaza. From them are Abadilah of Al-Hijan. From them is An'am who is in the land of Jarash of Hijaz; they are a clan of Tayy. Al-Ahamidah is a clan of Jarm Tayy; their dwellings are in the land of Gaza. From Al-Ahamidah are the people of Al-Faqrah between Medina and Yanbu; they are counted in Banu Salim bin Harb. From the clans of Jarm is Banu Hani clan of Jadhima of Jarm Tayy. From them is Iyas bin Qabisah. Chosroes appointed him over Al-Hira after Al-Nu'man. He is the leader of the Arabs and Persians against Banu Shayban on the Day of Dhi Qar. Some scholars of Al-Ahsa mentioned to us that Banu Iyas people of Oman are from this Banu Iyas Al-Ta'i, reporting from their scholars. We have presented their mention in Iyas of Azd. From the clans of Tayy is Banu Amr bin Al-Ghawth bin Tayy. From them is Bulan clan; his name is Husayn. From Bulan are the three who established the Arabic script. From the clans of Amr is Nabhan clan of Tayy. From them is Banu Asdus clan, and Banu Asma' clan; he is Asma' bin Sa'd bin Nabhan. From the clans of Nabhan is Banu Na'il. From Banu Na'il is Zayd al-Khayl (Zayd of the Horses); he is Zayd bin Muhalhil bin Zayd bin Minhab Al-Ta'i.
