He came as a delegation to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and converted to Islam along with a delegation from Tayy. The Prophet, peace be upon him, named him Zayd al-Khayr (Zayd of Goodness) and said to him: "No one was described to me in Jahiliyyah and I saw him in Islam but he was less than described to me, except you; I saw you above what was described to me." The Prophet, peace be upon him, granted him Aja and Salma and lands with them. Zayd, may Allah be pleased with him, died, it is said, upon his return from the Prophet, peace be upon him. Zayd was a poet, orator, doer of good, brave, and generous. There was mutual satire between him and Ka'b bin Zuhayr. Zayd was tall and massive; he would ride a huge horse and his feet would drag as if riding a donkey. Zayd had a son named Urwah who was generous. From Banu Nabhan are Al-Humayd, the Emirs in the Caliphate of Banu Abbas in the Frontiers. From them are Muhammad bin Humayd, Qahtabah bin Humayd, Abu Nasr, Abu Sa'id Al-Nafari, and Abu Shuja'. These and their successors were among the most generous and brave people in their time. They were Emirs of the Frontiers; their death was by striking and stabbing on the withers of horses. Poets have praised them extensively. From the clans of Tayy is Banu Tha'l bin Amr bin Al-Ghawth of Tayy. They are known for proficiency in archery. Al-Jawhari said they are the ones meant by Imru' al-Qais in his saying: 'Many an archer from Banu Tha'l'.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Born to Tha'l was Jarwal. To Jarwal was born Rabi'ah. To Rabi'ah was born Ahzam and Amr. To Amr was born Aman, a clan of Tha'l. To Ahzam was born Adi, named Hazumah. From Banu Adi is Hatim Al-Ta'i. He is Hatim bin Abdullah bin Adi bin Sa'd bin Hashraj bin Imru' al-Qais bin Adi. His kunya is Abu Adi and Abu Saffanah. His son Adi reached Islam and converted. He said: "O Messenger of Allah, my father used to join ties of kinship and do good." He said: "Your father desired a thing and achieved it." His daughter Saffanah was brought among the captives of Ali to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. She said: "O Muhammad, the parent has perished and the provider is absent. If you see fit to release me and not let the Arab tribes rejoice at my misfortune, for my father used to free the captive, protect the honor, relieve the distressed, feed food, spread peace, and never turned away a seeker of need. I am the daughter of Hatim." The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "These are truly the qualities of believers. Had your father been Muslim, we would have prayed for mercy on him. Release her, for her father loved noble character, and Allah loves noble character." When the Prophet, peace be upon him, bestowed favor upon her, she prayed for him saying: "May a hand thank you that became poor after wealth, and may a hand not rule over you that became rich after poverty. May Allah hit with your favor its proper places, and not make you have a need for a miser, nor strip a blessing from a generous person except making you a cause for its return to him!" Ibn Al-A'rabi said: Hatim was one of the poets of Jahiliyyah. He was generous; his generosity resembled his poetry, and his saying matched his deed. Wherever he settled, his place was known. He was victorious; if he fought he overcame, if he took booty he plundered, if he raced he won, and if he captured he released. When the month of Rajab began, he would slaughter ten camels every day and feed the people, and they gathered around him. The first sign of his generosity was when his father left him with his camels while he was a boy. A group of poets passed by him: Abid bin Al-Abras, Bishr bin Hazim, and Al-Nabigha, intending Al-Nu'man. They said to him: "Is there any hospitality (Qira)?" They did not know him. He said: "You ask about hospitality while you have seen the camels and sheep? Dismount." So they dismounted. He slaughtered a camel for each one of them. He asked them their names, and they informed him. He distributed the camels and sheep among them. His father came and said: "What have you done?" He said: "I have collared you with the glory of time like the collar of a pigeon." His father said: "I will never blame you." He said: "Then I do not care." From his stories: He went out in the Sacred Month. When he was in the land of Anazzah, a prisoner of theirs called out to him: "O Hatim, captivity and lice have eaten me." He said: "Woe to you, I am not in the land of my people, and I have nothing to ransom you with." So he bought him from the Anazzis and stayed in his place in shackles until the ransom was brought. From his stories, Mawiyah, wife of Hatim, narrated saying: A drought befell people taking away hoof and claw (livestock). We spent a night in extreme hunger. We started distracting Adi and Saffanah until they slept from hunger. Suddenly a woman said: "O Abu Saffanah, I came to you from hungry children." He said: "Bring your two children, by Allah I will satisfy them." I said: "With what, O Hatim? By Allah, your children only slept by distraction." He went to his horse and slaughtered it. Then he kindled a fire. People came by its light, took to roasting and eating. He covered himself with his cloak and slept; by Allah, he did not taste it. His stories are famous. Here is a strange story: Muhriz mawla of Abu Huraira narrated saying: A group from Abd al-Qays passed by Hatim's grave and camped near it. A man called Abu Al-Yakhbari stood up to it and kicked his grave with his foot. One of them said: "Woe to you, do you not hear? Do you provoke a man who has died?" He said: "Tayy claims that no one stayed with him but he hosted him." Then night covered them at the grave and they slept. Abu Al-Yakhbari woke up terrified saying: "O my mount!" They said to him: "What is wrong with you?" He said: "Hatim came to me in sleep and hamstrung my she-camel with a sword while I was looking at him, and he recited poetry to me I memorized, which is this: Abu Al-Yakhbari and you are a man... Wronging the clan, reviling it. You came with your companions seeking hospitality... At a pit whose owl has screeched. Do you seek blame for me at the overnight stay... While around you are Tayy and its livestock? For we surely satisfy our guests... And the mounts come so we select them." He said: When they got up, the man's she-camel was hamstrung (hocked) and dying, so they slaughtered it and spent the night eating. They said: "Hatim hosted us alive and dead." He said: When they woke up, they let Abu Al-Bukhturi ride behind (someone) and marched. Suddenly a man riding a camel and leading another was saying: "Which of you is Abu Al-Yakhbari?" He said: "I am." He said: "Take this camel. I am Adi bin Hatim. Hatim came to me in sleep and claimed he hosted you with your she-camel, and ordered me to compensate you for it." To this incident Ibn Darah Al-Ghatafani referred praising Adi bin Hatim saying: 'Your father Abu Saffanah, goodness did not cease... With Shaybah until he died desiring good.'

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: 'Proverbs are struck by him in poetry while dead... And he was, when alive, a companion to it. His grave hosted the guests when they descended by him... And no grave before him ever hosted a rider.' The news of Hatim is famous. Adi, may Allah be pleased with him, converted to Islam and had fame in Islam. It came in the Hadith: When he came to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, as a delegate, he seated him on his mattress, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, sat on the ground. His story is famous in the Biography. He was with Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, on the Day of the Camel. He is of the noble ones, and his virtues are renowned. From the clans of Tha'l is Banu Muawiyah bin Banu Amr bin Tha'l bin Sanbis clan. Sanbis had children: Amr and Adi. Al-Hamdani mentioned a clan of them in the plains of Iraq, and a faction in Damietta. He said: They had significance in the days of the Fatimids. He counted three clans among them: Al-Khaza'ilah, Banu Ubayd, and Jumuh. Among them are people in the districts of Jazira around Sayyarah, stated in 'Nihayat Al-Arab'. He said: The Emirate in Al-Khaza'ilah is in Banu Yusuf, and their seat is in the city of Sinjara. From Banu Yusuf are Muhammad bin Yusuf and his sons whom Abu Tammam and Al-Buhturi praised in the Fatimid Caliphate. From the clans of Sanbis is Banu Rumayh; it is said Banu Rumayh the tribe in Bahrain and Qatar is from them. From the clans of Sanbis is Banu Labid clan, Banu Amr clan, Banu Adi clan, and Banu Aban clan; all are from Sanbis. From the clans of Tayy is Shammar. Ibn Al-Kalbi said: Shammar and Zuraykh are a clan from Tha'l; they are sons of Abd bin Jadhima bin Zuhayr bin Tha'labah bin Salaman bin Tha'l bin Amr bin Al-Ghawth of Tayy. Shammar today are the inhabitants of the Two Mountains Aja and Salma, the mountains of Ali. Shammar is three clans: Sinjara clan, Al-Aslam clan, and Abde clan. Abde is the largest tribe of Shammar. Sinjara are clans and thighs. From Sinjara is Al-Falih clan. Al-Ghufeilat clan is from Sinjara, from Al-Rammal. Al-Zumayl clan is from Sinjara. Al-Rab'ah clan is from Sinjara; from them is Sanad Al-Rabi' and from them Al-Rabi'at. From Al-Rabi'at are Al-Da'ajin, called Al-Bayin, group of Ibn Nukhaylan. From the clans of Sinjara is Al-Suwayd clan. From the clans of Al-Suwayd is Fadaghah clan of Sinjara. From Fadaghah is Al-Rumman people of Tayma, group of Ibn Rumman. From the clans of Ali is Al-Tuman, group of Al-Timbat. From the clans of Sinjara is Al-Sulayman clan, and Al-Shalaqan clan. From the clans of Sinjara is Al-Rakhis, a clan from Sinjara from the remnants of Banu Al-Nabhan; from them is Al-Bati', people of Hail. The Second Clan of Shammar is Al-Aslam. Al-Suwaydi said: Al-Aslam is a clan from Judham, entered with Banu Jadhima bin Zuhayr bin Tha'labah bin Salaman bin Tha'l mentioned previously. From the clans of Al-Aslam is Al-Mani' clan; from them is Al-Tawalah and Al-Fayid. From them is Al-Waj'a and Al-Mas'ud clan of Al-Aslam. Al-Ghaysam and Al-Salqah is a clan of Al-Aslam. Al-Ma'adid is a clan of Al-Aslam. Al-Ghurayr is a clan of Al-Aslam; they are remnants of Banu Adi, kin of Hatim Al-Ta'i. Al-Kharsah is a clan of Al-Aslam. Al-Thabit is a clan of Al-Aslam. Al-Hadab is a clan of Al-Aslam. Al-Amud is a clan of Al-Aslam. Al-Sayh is a clan of Shammar. They are clans and thighs, among them Al-Jarban. The Third Clan of Shammar is Abde. They are Banu Dhaygham bin Muawiyah bin Al-Harith bin Munabbih bin Zayd bin Harb bin Allah bin Al-Jald bin Madhhij, brother of Tayy. It is said Madhhij is Tayy. Muawiyah bin Al-Harith was from Janb, and the Kingship was in the house of Janb. He is the one whom Muhalhil brother of Kulayb sought refuge with, and he married Muhalhil's daughter named Ubaydah. Tribes from Janb are attributed to her. She bore him Dhaygham. From Banu Dhaygham is this Abde. They held the leadership over the tribes of Shammar from Tayy bin Ali. The leadership of the Two Mountains of Tayy was anciently Jadila, a clan of Tayy. Then it became in Banu Nabhan, then in Al-Jarban, then Abde became in Al-Ja'far. Abde was three clans: Al-Ja'far, Al-Fudayl, and Al-Mufaddal. From Al-Ja'far is Al-Ali thigh; they held leadership anciently. Al-Khalil clan; from Al-Khalil is Al-Rashid clan. From Al-Rashid is Al-Abdullah, Al-Ubayd, and Al-Jubayr. Leadership transferred from Al-Ali in Abdullah bin Ali bin Rashid to the children of Abdullah Talal, and among them is Ibn Talal bin Nayef bin Talal bin Abdullah bin Ali Al-Rashid. From Al-Abdullah are the children of Saud bin Abd Al-Aziz bin Mit'ab bin Abdullah. From Al-Abdullah is Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Ali bin Rashid who killed his nephew Bandar bin Talal when he killed his brother Mit'ab. Al-Ubayd: among them is Sulayman bin Ubayd bin Hamoud bin Ubayd bin Ali Al-Rashid. Al-Jabr are thighs: among them Sultan Al-Jabr, Fahd Al-Jabr, Rashid Al-Muhaisin Al-Jabr, and others from Al-Jabr in Rashid.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Al-Frata is a thigh from Al-Khalil. From the clans of Al-Khalil is Al-Raya, who are Al-Sabhan. From the clans of Ja'far is Al-Sharhan clan, Al-Waybar clan, Al-Khudayr clan, Al-Dhala'ibah clan, Al-Aqala clan, Al-Qash'am clan, and Al-Shumayl clan. From the clans of Al-Fudayl, among them is Aba Al-Mikh clan, Al-Shuraym clan, and Al-Ajl clan. As for Mufaddal, from them is Al-Jibrin clan, Al-Yahya clan, and Al-Husayn clan. Among those attributed to Al-Shalahi from Banu Abdullah are Abadil of Mutayr. From Shammar are Al-Mazid people of Al-Majma'ah, Al-Qudayr people of Al-Attar, Al-Huqayl people of Ahsa Sudair, and Al-Jarbu' people of Al-Qassim. As for Banu Zurayq bin Qays bin Shammar mentioned previously, they are clans and thighs. Among their greatest clans is Al-Subhiyun (The Subhis); they are Banu Subayh bin Zurayq bin Awf bin Tha'labah bin Qays bin Shammar. From the clans of Al-Subhiyun are people of Iraq; their elder is Ibn Ajran. From them is Al-Sha'lan and their elder is Muslat bin Sha'lan. From them is Al-Sha'lan people of Qasab. And Al-Sha'lan in the town of Harbhala (?). From Al-Sabaha are people of Al-Sirr, people of Al-Qassim, people of Al-Qara'in, Al-Huwaymil, and Al-Humayd in the town of Marat. From Al-Subhiyun are Al-Subh who are in Banu Khalid; from them is Al-Abu Aynayn, and Al-Khatir people of Qatar. From Al-Subhiyun are Al-Adbiyun and Al-Talhiyun mentioned by Al-Suwaydi; from them are Al-Adban. From Al-Subhiyun are Al-Tha'aliba, group of Ibn Ta'la people of Al-Mahani, and Al-Qada'isah people of Al-Dabt. As for Lawza', some of them are from Hamdan. These are counted in Al-Ruqah of Otaybah. As for Al-Talhiyun, they are a clan of Al-Subhiyun from Banu Zurayq, as mentioned by Al-Suwaydi; from them are Al-Talhah mentioned in Al-Ruqah. From the clans of Al-Subhiyun are Al-Zamut clan, Al-Bahabahah clan, Al-Sanadiyun clan, Al-Hasah and Banu Husayn clan. These are from Al-Subhiyun, a clan from Tha'labah Tayy. From the clans of Jarm Tayy is Banu Jadhima, Banu Miqdam clan, and Banu Raghu bin Humayd bin Jarm. From the clans of Jarm is Al-Nadil clan, Al-Baqarah clan from Jarm Tayy, Al-Isa clan from Raghu of Jadhima Tayy. Al-Muhammad clan from Jarm Tayy, Al-Raf'ah clan from Jarm Tayy. Banu Al-Buq'ah clan from Tha'labah Tayy, and Al-Habbaniyun clan from Tha'labah Tayy. From the clans of Sanbis are Al-Jawahir clan from Sanbis of Tayy, Banu Iyad clan from Sanbis Tayy, and Al-Hanabilah clan from Tha'labah Tayy. From them is Abu Hanbal, whose name is Mudlij bin Suwayd Al-Ta'i. He was counted among the loyal, and is proverbial: 'Better than the protector of locusts.' From his story as Ibn Al-A'rabi narrated from Al-Kulaybi: He said Abu Hanbal entered his tent one day and found people with their containers. He said: "What is your business?" They said: "Locusts fell in your courtyard, so we came to take them." He mounted his horse, took his spear, and said: "By Allah, no one of you touches them but I kill him. You have seen them in my protection." He kept guarding them until the sun grew hot and they flew and moved from his protection. He said: "Do with them as you wish." It is said his name is Haritha bin Murr bin Hanbal Al-Ta'i. He was from Tayy Amir bin Haritha. He was the first to establish hospitality. It is mentioned that Qays was one of the generous Arabs. It was said to him: "O Qays, have you seen anyone more generous than you?" He said: "Yes. We stayed with a Bedouin of Tayy. We stayed with a woman whose husband (came and) she said: 'A guest has come to you.' He brought a camel and slaughtered it and said: 'Help yourselves to it.' We stayed with him while the sky was raining. When the morrow came, he brought another and slaughtered it and said: 'Help yourselves to it.' We said: 'By Allah, we ate only a little of what you slaughtered for us last night.' We stayed with him for days while the sky rained, and he did this. When we wanted to depart, we left one hundred dinars and said to the woman: 'Apologize for us to him,' and we left. When the day rose high, the man shouted behind us: 'O mean riders, you gave us the price of your hospitality!' Then he caught up with us and said: 'You shall take your money or I will stab you with this spear.' So we took it and departed." From the clans of Tha'l: Buhtur bin Atud bin Salaman bin Tha'l bin Al-Ghawth bin Tayy bin Ali. From them is Al-Buhturi the famous poet. His kunya is Abu Al-Hasan; he is Al-Walid bin Ubayd bin Yahya bin Ubayd bin Shamlan bin Jabir bin Mus-hir bin Maslamah bin Al-Harith bin Jashm bin Abi Haritha bin Judayy bin Yadul bin Buhtur bin Atud bin Unayn bin Salaman bin Tha'l bin Amr bin Al-Ghawth bin Tayy. From them are clans all in Iraq, most of them city dwellers. Their lands are Manbij, Al-Zawra, and other villages of Iraq. Al-Buhturi was eloquent, virtuous, of good disposition and doctrine, pure in speech, naturally gifted, versatile in arts of poetry, such that when his death approached, he burned all satire he found. He was born in Manbij and grew up there. He was a leader for Tayy in Islam. From the clans of Tha'l is Tha'labah bin Darman; from them is Banu Wael clan. From them is Amr bin Adi bin Wael, whom Imru' al-Qais praised.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From the clans of Tayy is Banu Sakhr clan from Tha'l; their dwellings are in Tayma, Khaybar, and Al-Sham. From them are clans: Banu Harmas clan from Jadhima Tayy, Banu Amr clan from Darman of Tayy. From Tha'labah is Banu Sawadah clan from Tayy, and Banu Shibl clan from Tayy. Al-Hamdan are from the children of Nafi' bin Marwan Al-Ta'i. From them is Banu Jalhamah; it is said Jalhamah is Hayy bin Tayy. From them are Al-Jalahimah inhabitants of Halat Bu Mahir in Bahrain. Section: On Jadila. Jadila: Brother of Al-Ghawth, children of Tayy. Mention of Al-Ghawth has preceded. As for Al-Harith bin Tayy, his sons mixed with Jadila. Al-Ghawth and Banu Al-Harith are the clan of Abu Tammam the eloquent poet. From Jadila is Banu Sa'd bin Qatrah bin Tayy. They were named Jadila only because Sa'd bin Qatrah married Jadila daughter of Subay' bin Himyar the Younger, so they were named by her. She bore to Sa'd: Hawra' and Kharijah. Abu Ubaydah said: Banu Hawra' are plainsmen and not mountaineers; Banu Kharijah bin Jadila are mountaineers. In them is honor. To Hawra' was born Jundub. From the clans of Jadila is Banu Taym bin Tha'labah bin Jad'a' bin Dhuhl bin Darman bin Jundub bin Kharijah bin Jadila; they are called Al-Tha'alib (The Foxes). From Banu Taym is Al-Mu'alla whom Imru' al-Qais praised; he had stayed with him after his father Hujr was killed, and he protected him against kings and all people. From Banu Tha'labah is Al-Asif bin Sulay'. From them is Mas'ud bin Ulbah the Poet. From Banu Tha'labah bin Jad'a' bin Dhuhl bin Darman bin Jundub bin Kharijah bin Jadila; from them is Al-Hurr bin Mashja'ah bin Al-Nu'man, leader of Jadila on the day of the war of Musaylima the Liar. From the clans of Jundub bin Kharijah bin Jadila is Banu Kimad. From the clans of Jadila is Banu Tarif; they are from Banu Tarif bin Malik bin Jad'a' bin Dhuhl bin Darman bin Jundub bin Kharijah bin Jadila. From them is Al-Barrah bin Mus-hir. From them is Jubayl bin Rafi' the Generous. Banu Jubayl is a clan from Jadila from Banu Tarif bin Malik bin Jad'a', from Al-Jiblan known in Alwa of Mutayr. They are clans: Al-A'inna in Tayy. Al-Araqibah clan, Al-Aqimat clan, Al-Maqalidah clan. From Al-Jiblan is the clan known in Za'b. From Al-Jiblan is Al-Sha'wan. From the clans of Jadila is Al-Tha'alibah, and Banu Tha'labah; they are from Banu Dhuhl bin Darman bin Jundub bin Kharijah bin Jadila. Separating from Jadila from the rest of Tayy is Banu Raghu bin Jadhima; their dwellings are the land of Gaza. Al-Hamdani said: It is said they are from Jarm. From Sanbis is Banu Jaww clan from Sanbis, and Banu Radi'ah clan from Jadhima. Al-Ghayath is a clan of Al-Subhiyun from Banu Zurayq; their dwellings are on the outskirts of Egypt. From Banu Zurayq is Al-Qama'ah; they are a clan from Al-Ulaymiyun. Al-Awfah is a clan from Zurayq. Banu Suhayl is a clan from Jarm Tha'l; Al-Hamdani said: They were ambassadors between kings, and their land is Gaza; a people from Zubaid neighbor them called Banu Fuhayd. Al-Shamkhan is a clan from Jarm; from them is Jabala bin Malik bin Kulthum. Al-Numur is a clan. From Banu Zurayq is Al-Marawinah clan from Darman of Tha'labah Jadila. Al-Hamdani said: From Al-Ulaymiyun is Amr bin Usaylah who was known for knowledge, and Al-Buq. Al-Ma'diyun is a clan from Banu Zurayq. Al-Masafihah is a clan from Banu Zurayq. Al-Masahirah is a clan from Banu Zurayq. All these are from Tha'l in Jadila. From Tayy is Safi al-Din al-Hilli al-Ta'i, the famous poet. He was in the time of the Tatar domination over Iraq. He is the one saying, when Tayy rose to fight the Tatars and defeated them, and Tayy returned, poetry: 'Ask the high spears about our high ambitions... And call the swords to witness, did hope fail in us? Ask the Arabs and Turks what we did... In the land of the grave of Ubayd Allah with our hands. We marched and our resolves did not weaken... From what we desire, nor did our endeavors fail. On the day of the battle of Zawra' Iraq, we... Repaid the enemies with what they repaid us (judged them as they judged us). With lean horses we did not tether them branded... Except to raid with them those who spent the night raiding us. And youths, if we speak, they lend their ears... To our saying, or if we call them, they answer us. A people, if they quarrel, they are Pharoahs... One day, and if they judge, they are balances (of justice). They donned reason as a cloak, but if... The fire of war heated up, you would think them madmen in it. The starlings, when their rising one rose... Imagined they had become falcons. They emptied the mosques of our sheikhs and transgressed... Until we charged, so we emptied the Dewans (bureaus). Then we turned back, and our sharp swords remained... Rising in wonder, and the spears shaking for us.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: And for the blood on our clothes is a clot... Its scent suffices us from the fragrance of musk. We are a people whose morals refused, out of honor... That we begin harm against those who do not harm us. White are our deeds, green are our pastures... Black are our battles, red are our swords. Helplessness does not appear in us before attaining desire... Even if we saw deaths in our desires.' From the clans of Jadila is Banu Lam. They are clans and thighs. He is Lam bin Amr bin Tarif bin Amr bin Malik bin Amr bin Thumamah bin Malik bin Jad'a' bin Dhuhl bin Duman bin Jundub bin Kharijah bin Jadila bin Sa'd bin Tayy. Al-Hamdani said: The dwellings of Banu Lam are in the Two Mountains to Medina; they stay most of their times in the city of Yathrib. Then they multiplied and dispersed. Their clans separated from Haritha bin Lam, and his son Aws. They are the ones mentioned by Abu Tammam. Haritha bin Lam was one of the most physically complete people. From the clans of Lam is Banu Masruq clan, Banu Kindi clan, Banu Aws clan, and Atud clan. As for Aws, Ibn Al-Athir mentioned that he is Aws bin Khalid bin Haritha bin Lam. He was proverbial in virtue and generosity. His mother's name was Su'da bint Husayn Al-Ta'iyah; she was a lady, and Aws was a preeminent master. They mentioned that he and Hatim Al-Ta'i came as a delegation to Amr bin Hind, King of Al-Hira. He called Aws and said: "Are you better or Hatim?" He said: "May you refuse the curse; if Hatim possessed me, myself and my children, it would not be strange." Then he called Hatim and said to him: "Are you better or Aws?" He said to him: "May you refuse the curse; no one of his children is better than me. I was only mentioned because of Aws." Al-Nu'man bin Al-Mundhir had called for a robe, and he had a delegation of Arabs from every tribe. He said: "Attend tomorrow; I will dress the best and most noble of you in this robe." They all attended except Aws. It was said to him: "Why did you stay behind?" He said: "If another is intended, the most beautiful thing is that I am not present. And if I am intended, I will be sought." When Al-Nu'man sat, he did not see Aws. He said: "Go to Aws and say to him: Attend safe from what you feared." So he attended, and he dressed him in the robe. His people envied him, so they said to Al-Hutay'ah: "Satirize Aws and you shall have three hundred she-camels." He said: "How can I satirize a man when in my house there are no provisions or goods except from him?" Then he began to say: 'How can there be satire when a good deed... From the family of Lam continues to come to me in the unseen?' Then Bishr bin Abi Hazim from Banu Asad bin Khuzayma said to them: "I will satirize him." So they gave him the camels. Ibn Al-Athir said: So he satirized him and mentioned his mother Su'da. When that reached Aws, he raided him and swept away the camels. Bishr fled to Banu Asad. He would not seek protection from anyone but they said: "We grant you protection except from Aws." He took refuge with his clan Banu Asad, and they hated to surrender him to Aws. So Aws gathered his people Jadila and marched with them to them, catching them at the back of Al-Dahna. They fought a fierce battle, and Asad was defeated. Bishr fled and began not coming to a tribe seeking their protection except they refused. Then he stayed with Jundub bin Husayn Al-Kilabi. Aws sent to him demanding Bishr, so he sent him to Aws. When he was brought before Aws, his mother Su'da advised him to treat him well, return the camels to him, and pardon him. Aws said to him: "O Bishr, what do you see me doing with you?" Bishr recited verses of poetry praising Aws. So Aws returned his camels to him and gave him from his wealth one hundred she-camels. Bishr said: "No doubt, I will praise no one but you until I die." The virtue of Aws among the Arabs is famous. It is recounted that Al-Harith bin Awf Al-Murri, master of Dhubyan, said one day to his brother Kharijah: "Should I propose to anyone and he rejects me?" He said: "Yes, Aws bin Haritha bin Lam, master of Tayy." Al-Harith said to his servant: "Journey with us to him." So Al-Harith, his brother Kharijah, and his servant journeyed. He said: We went out aiming for the land of Tayy, the road raising us at times, until we came to the dwellings of Tayy. We found Aws outside the neighborhood. He welcomed us and said: "What brings you, O Haritha?" He said: "I came to you as a suitor." He said: "You are not there (not suitable/accepted)." And he turned away angry and did not speak to us, so we turned back returning.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Aws entered upon his wife angry. His wife was from Banu Abs. She said: "Who is the man who came to you but did not stay, and you did not welcome him?" He said: "That is Al-Harith bin Awf Al-Murri, master of Dhubyan." She said: "Why did you not ask him to dismount?" He said: "He considered me foolish, proposing (marriage) from me." She said: "Why did you not marry him to one of your daughters, this master of the Arabs?" She kept arguing with him until she said to him: "Rectify what came from you, catch up with him and bring him back. Say to him: You met me while I was angry about a grave matter before your arrival. So return, and you shall have what you liked." Aws caught up with him, and Al-Harith returned happy. He entered upon his wife. He said: "Call so-and-so, the eldest of his daughters." She came to him. He said: "O daughter, this is Al-Harith bin Awf, a master of masters, who has come to us proposing. I wanted to marry you to him, so what do you say?" She said: "Do not do it," and excused herself with words, saying: "There is some sharpness in my character. I am not his cousin so he might have mercy on me, nor a neighbor of yours so he might be shy of you." He said to her: "May Allah bless you. Call so-and-so, your middle sister." He called her and said to her what he said to her elder sister. She replied to him like her elder sister said, and said: "I am clumsy and my hand is not skilled. I am not safe from him seeing what he dislikes and divorcing me." He said: "Rise, may Allah bless you. Call your youngest sister Buhaysah." He said to her like what he said to them. She said: "It is up to you." He said: "I offered it to your two sisters." She said: "I am, by Allah, the beautiful in face, the skilled in hand, the gentle in character, the noble in father. If he divorces me, may Allah not replace it with good for him." He said: "May Allah bless you." Then he returned to Al-Harith and married her to him. He gave her a dowry from his wealth of one hundred she-camels. He said to him: "Do not spend the night single tonight." He ordered a tent to be set up for him, and she was brought in to him. Then Aws congratulated him and left. He said to her: "Have you finished your affair (prepared)?" She said: "No, by Allah." He extended his hand to her. She said: "Slowly! Among my father and brothers? This cannot be." Then he ordered departure, so they traveled. She said: "Go forward and turn us away from the road." He turned from the road and made the camels kneel. Then he said to her: "Have you finished your affair?" She said: "No, by Allah. As is done with the captured slave girl and the taken captive? No, by Allah, until camels are slaughtered, sheep are butchered, Arabs are invited, and what is done for the likes of me is done." So they traveled until they came to their land. He slaughtered camels and butchered sheep and entered upon her. He said: "Have you finished your affair?" She said: "No, by Allah." He said: "We have slaughtered camels and butchered sheep, and come near it." She said: "No, by Allah. You have mentioned of honor what I do not see in you. Go out to these people: Abs and Dhubyan, and reconcile between them." He went out until he came to the people and walked between them with peace until they reconciled. He bore the blood money (Diyahs), which was three thousand camels over three years. He returned with the most beautiful mention. Zuhayr bin Abi Sulma said poetry about that. Then she bore him sons and daughters after that. This Aws was the head of Jadila; they were in Aja and Salma, the Two Mountains of Tayy. Then war broke out between Jadila and Al-Ghawth, which is the Day of Al-Yahamim, also known as the Raids of Huq. The reason was that Al-Harith bin Jabala Al-Ghassani had reconciled between Tayy. When he died, they returned to their war. Jadila and Al-Ghawth met at a place called Gharathat. The leader of Jadila, Asba' bin Amr bin Lam - who is the uncle of Aws bin Khalid bin Haritha bin Lam, and some genealogists drop Khalid and say Aws bin Haritha bin Lam - was killed. Mus'ab, a man from Sanbis, cut off the ear of Asba' bin Amr bin Lam and stitched his sandal with it, saying: 'We stitch our sandals with ears from you... And drink unwillingly from you in skulls.' The two clans exchanged many poems about that. What Al-Ghawth did became grave to Aws. He had not witnessed the previous wars, neither he nor any of the chiefs of Tayy like Hatim and Zayd al-Khayl. So Aws resolved to meet in war himself. He began gathering Jadila. News of Aws gathering reached Al-Ghawth, so fire was lit on the peak of Aja; that was the first day. The tribes of Ghawth approached with their chiefs over them, including Zayd al-Khayl and Hatim. Jadila approached gathered under Aws. Aws swore not to turn back from Tayy until he settled with them in their two mountains: Aja and Salma. They met in raids and fought a fierce battle. He said: The war turned against Banu Kayman bin Jundub bin Kharijah bin Jadila.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Adi bin Hatim said: "I was standing on the Day of Al-Yahamim while the people were fighting, and Zayd al-Khayl was saying to his sons: 'Spare your people, for today is a day of annihilation. If these are paternal uncles, then those are maternal uncles.' I said: 'Did you hate killing your maternal uncles?' He said: His eyes turned red with anger, and he reached towards me, so I struck my horse and moved away from him. He remained waiting for his two sons. They came out like two falcons. Qays bin Azib charged at Bujayr bin Haritha bin Lam and struck him on his head a blow that made his horse stumble and he fled. So Jadila was defeated." Al-Ghalayini mentioned that victory was for Jadila over Al-Ghawth. Antara was in alliance with Jadila, and Al-Tha'alibah complained of him to Ghatafan. From Al-Mughira are clans of Banu Lam Al-Mughira. From them is Al-Mutirah bin Shaddad bin Aws bin Haritha bin Lam bin Amr bin Tarif bin Malik bin Amr bin Thumamah bin Malik bin Jad'a' bin Dhuhl bin Duman bin Jundub bin Kharijah bin Jadila bin Sa'd bin Qatrah bin Tayy. Al-Mughira was the most famous tribe of Tayy bin Lam, and the most numerous in clans. From them were famous kings; their last king was Ajl bin Hunaytam, discussion of whom will come. Then they moved from Najd to Iraq and Al-Sham. From them in Al-Jazira is Al-Ubayd, a clan of Al-Mughira. The chief of Al-Ubayd is Husayn Al-Ali; Al-Daylam joins them. From Al-Mughira are clans in the Arabs of Al-Amarah with their brothers from Banu Lam. From the clans of Al-Mughira are Al-Sumayt people of Iraq, and Al-Sumayt people of Qatar; they moved from it to Al-Najjah (?) in the land of Fars after they killed Ufayr. From their clans are Al-Maghayirah, the clan known in Al-Ruqah group of Ibn Hamad. From the clans of Al-Mughira are Al-Ashawin and those attached to them from Al-Abiyyat. We have transmitted from Khalid bin Du'ayj and Abdullah bin Zamil, people of Marat, that Al-Rifa'i bin Ashwan traces his lineage to this. Al-Mughira established themselves in Najd after Banu Hilal as we will mention when mentioning Banu Hilal. The last king of Al-Mughira was Ajl bin Hunaytam. His residence was the town of Al-Sha'ra in Najd; the ruins of Ajl's palace remain to now. It was mentioned in the time of Mas'ud bin Abd Al-Aziz, may Allah have mercy on him, in the year 1200, that a man from the people of Samir passed by Imam Mas'ud. Imam Mas'ud said to the man: "What is your age?" He said: "One hundred and twenty-four years." He said to him: "From which tribes are you?" He said: "From the strongest tribe in Najd." He said to him: "From Al-Mughira?" He said: "Yes, and the elder of the tribe was called Ajl." It is narrated that Banu Amir bin Sa'sa'ah imprisoned Ajl's brother, and they were at Al-Wafra. So he marched to them, killed them with a great slaughter, and freed his brother. It is said that Al-Bayhis was named by this name because of the abundance of horses and army in this raid that crushed (bahhasat) with their hooves and pads. It is said they were besieged in one of the raids, and the valley became narrow for them despite its wideness. From the clans of Al-Mughira among the settled people in Najd are Al-Suwalim, who are remnants of Ajl. From them are Al-Humud, inhabitants of the town of Dharma. They dispersed from it except for a few. Humud had a son Abdullah. To Abdullah was born Humud and Muhammad. As for Humud, he has remnants in Dharma. From them are Al-Ibrahim in the town of Riyadh. From them are Al-Rashid in Dharma. From them is Ali bin Humud and his brother Mas'ud, called Al-Aridi, inhabitant of the town of Hail. As for Nasir, brother of Rashid, his descendants are in Al-Sha'ra. The rest of Al-Humud are in Qasr Sa'b of the town of Al-Muzahmiyah. As for Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Humud, two sons were born to him: Hamad and Fuhayd. As for Fuhayd, he settled in the town of Al-Aflaj; Salih was born to him, and Fuhayd was born to Salih. From Fuhayd are the inhabitants of Al-Ammar; their thighs branched out from Fuhayd bin Salih. As for Ahmad, Muhammad was born to him. They used to be called in Dharma Al-Muhaymid. To Muhammad was born Hamad and Abdullah. From his descendants is Abdullah Al-Dablan, people of Al-Muzahmiyah. As for Hamad, Zayd was born to him. To Zayd was born Hamad. To Hamad was born Muhammad, so he settled in Sarat. To Muhammad was born Hamad and Zayd; they are Al-Zayd known in the town of Al-Sarat. From the clans of Al-Mughira is Al-Shukhayl. Their ancient dwelling was Al-Uyaynah, known in Wadi Hanifa. From Al-Shukhayl are Al-Musa, inhabitants of Al-Mubarraz in Al-Ahsa. The first to move from Al-Uyaynah were Abdullah and his brother Sulayman, sons of Musa bin Ahmad bin Husayn bin Imran Al-Shukhayl. They settled in Al-Ahsa in the year one thousand and eighty Hijri. To Abdullah was born Husayn. To Husayn was born three children: Salih, Salim, and Sulayman. To Sulayman was born: Abd Al-Latif and Muhammad, then they perished.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: To Salih was born Sheikh Abd Al-Aziz. To Abd Al-Aziz was born Sheikh Abd Al-Latif, whose client was Jawhar, grandfather of Al-Jawhar; then they perished. To Salim bin Husayn was born Abd Al-Latif, Abdullah, and Ali. To Abd Al-Latif was born Sheikh Abd Al-Rahman, Abd Al-Aziz, and Ahmad. To Sheikh Abd Al-Rahman was born Husayn, Abd Al-Latif, and Abd Al-Wahhab. To Abd Al-Aziz was born: Abd Al-Latif, Salih, and Muhammad. To Ahmad was born Muhammad. As for Abdullah bin Salim, Muhammad and Ahmad were born to him. To Muhammad was born Abd Al-Rahman, and Abd Al-Rahman had no male children. To Ahmad was born Abdullah bin Salim. To Salih was born Ahmad and Abd Al-Wahhab. As for the family of Ali bin Salim, whose clients are Al-Dhaman, they have perished. As for Sulayman bin Musa bin Ahmad bin Husayn bin Imran Al-Shukhayl, Mubarak was born to him. To Mubarak was born Sulayman. To Sulayman was born Musa. To Musa was born Muhammad and Sulayman. To Sulayman was born Abdullah. To Abdullah was born Muhammad. As for Muhammad bin Musa, Abd Al-Rahman was born to him. To Abd Al-Rahman was born Salih, Hamad, and Abd Al-Wahhab. These are Al-Musa Al-Shukhayl, a clan from Al-Mughira. From the thighs of Al-Shukhayl are Al-Sulaym; they inhabited the town of Marat, then moved from it to the town of Al-Uyaynah. From them are the descendants of Muhammad and Sulayman, sons of Musa bin Ibrahim bin Sulayman bin Sulaym bin Musa bin Imran Al-Shukhayl. These are a thigh. From the clans of Al-Mughira are Al-Jabbari; their dwelling is the town of Marat, and they were among its oldest inhabitants; they perished except for a few. From the clans of Al-Mughira are Al-Musa, inhabitants of the town of Ushayqir, and Al-Musa inhabitants of the town of Marat. From Al-Musa people of Ushayqir are Al-Sulayman, inhabitants of the town of Jalajil; among them is Abu Luhaywil, and Uthman inhabitant of Al-Jahra near Kuwait, from the mentioned Al-Musa. From the clans of Al-Mughira are Al-Bishr, inhabitants of the town of Al-Aflaj, from whom are Al-Safar; from them is Ibrahim bin Al-Safar inhabitant of the town of Yanbu in Hijaz. From the clans of Al-Mughira are Tarad and Al-Kulayb, inhabitants of the town of Al-Hulwah in Burayk and Ni'am. From the thighs of Al-Mughira are Al-Qahhazi, who are Al-Quhayz, their dwelling is Al-Kharj, and Al-Mubarrad, Al-Aradah, and Al-Isa inhabitants of Al-Kharj. From the followers of Al-Mughira among the clients (Mawali) are Al-Khattaf, inhabitants of Al-Kharj, Al-Washm, and others. Also Al-Hwaymid inhabitants of the town of Al-Qasab, clients of Al-Humud, and Al-Nabhan people of Diriyah, called Al-Ubayd. From Al-Mughira are Al-Jassas in the town of Al-Quway'iyah, and Al-Muraysis in the town of Al-Muharraq in Bahrain. From the clans of Banu Lam are Al-Fudul. It is said: Fadl, Mughira, and Kathir are brothers. From Al-Fudul are clans and thighs. Among their most famous clans are Al-Ghazzi and Al-Sallal. Their dwellings were in Al-Arid. Ibn Bishran mentioned in the eleventh century that their dwellings were in Al-Ma'ariyah and Abi Al-Kibash, known there as Al-Fudul and Al-Kathran, and in the rest of Al-Wasil. Al-Mughira and Al-Zafir were in Aqrabah, Al-Jubaylah, and their surroundings. Among them were Bedouins who used to inhabit Al-Qayz, then moved from it to Iraq, and none remained in Najd except settled people. From the clans of Al-Fudul are Al-Ghazzi. From the clans of Al-Ghazzi are Al-Bu Rummah. From Al-Bu Rummah are Al-Shamlan people of Al-Qassim; among them is a family in the town of Al-Zulfi. From Al-Bu Rummah are Al-Yahya. From them are Al-Ibrahim, who are the children of Ibrahim bin Abd Al-Rahman bin Ibrahim. Ibrahim had children: Sheikh Muhammad, inhabitant of the town of Hail, and his son Abdullah. From the children of Ibrahim is Abd Al-Aziz bin Ibrahim bin Abd Al-Rahman bin Ibrahim; he was famous for generosity, firmness, and politics. From the children of Ibrahim is Sa'd; his home was the town of Ranyah. And Jabr bin Ibrahim had several children: Salih, Abdullah, and Abd Al-Rahman. From the children of Ibrahim: Hamoud in the town of Hail. Attached to Al-Yahya are the people of Mulham, from whom are Abd Al-Aziz bin Yahya and Abd Rabbuh in the town of Al-Ahsa. From the clans of Al-Fudul are Al-Sheikh and Al-Hasan inhabitants of Mulham, Al-Du'aylij inhabitants of the town of Huraymila, and Al-Hisnan; from them are Al-Shabaka people of Tharmada and people of Kuwait. From the clans of Al-Fudul are Al-Murshid people of Sudair. From the clans of Al-Fudul are Al-Talib in the town of Al-Wata in Burayk and Ni'am, and the town of Riyadh. From Al-Fudul are Al-Shalal and Al-Fudayli from the inhabitants of Al-Qasab. From Al-Fudul in the town of Al-Ahsa are Saud Al-Ayidhi, and Al-Buwayt, inhabitants of the village of Al-Marah in Al-Uyun, north of Al-Uyun. From Al-Fudul is the family of Muhammad Al-Ahmad and Isa Al-Hasan, inhabitants of Al-Umran, which is one of the villages of Al-Ahsa. As for the Bedouin of Al-Fudul, their inhabitants are Al-Ghazzi, Al-Sallal, and Al-Majyul; they moved to Iraq into the Arabs of Al-Amarah, and from Banu Lam. Al-Armah in Najd was known as Armah of Al-Ghazzi and Al-Sallal.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From the clans of Banu Lam are Al-Kathran and Banu Khalid, who are Khalid of Hijaz. They are from Abi Ghanm bin Haritha bin Thawb bin Ma'n bin Atud bin Haritha bin Lam. This Ghanm had children: A'sur and Ubayy. Al-Suwaydi said: From the Banu A'sur is Amr bin Al-Masih, who was the best archer of the Arabs. Amr bin Al-Masih reached Islam and converted, being one hundred and twenty years old. From the clans of Banu Lam is Ibn Ghurab bin Jadhima bin Wadd bin Ma'k bin Atud bin Haritha bin Lam. From Banu Ghurab is Al-Miqdam the Poet. From Banu Ghanm bin Haritha is Banu Silsilah; they are a clan of Banu Lam. From them are Al-Silsilah mentioned in Otaybah. From the clans of Banu Lam is Banu Aflat bin Silsilah bin Amr bin Silsilah bin Ghanm bin Haritha bin Thawb bin Ma'rah bin Atud bin Haritha bin Lam. From them are Al-Faltah, the clan mentioned in Otaybah. From them is Banu Adi, a clan of Lam from Banu Amr bin Silsilah; from them is Anazzah bin Al-Akhras and his son Wasman, the two poets. Banu Daghash is a clan of Banu Lam. As for Ubayy, brother of A'sur bin Ghanm bin Haritha, he had children: Sayf, Mas'ud, and Haritha. A bondwoman named Ghazziyah nursed them, so her name prevailed over them, and they were called Ghazziyah. Al-Hamdani said: From them are people in Al-Sham, Iraq, Hijaz, Najd, and between them. He said: They are clans and thighs returning to two origins: Al-Batnan and Ajwad. From Al-Batnan are Al-Kathir, Al-Mas'ud, and Al-Tamim. From Al-Ajwad are Mani', Al-Sa'id, Al-Ibn Haram, Al-Ali, Musa'idah, Banu Humayd, and Khalid of Hijaz. Al-Hamdani said: Khalid of Homs is from Khalid of Hijaz, mentioned by Al-Suyuti. Al-Amr are from Ghazziyah. Al-Suwaydi mentioned clans for this Ajwad in Ghazziyah of Hawazin, which is a mistake by him; because the clans of Al-Ajwad today are in Banu Lam inhabitants of Iraq. The leader of Ajwad is Ghadban, head of Banu Lam in Al-Amarah. He said in Masalik Al-Absar: Among them is a faction on the Baghdadi pilgrim road; their waters are Al-Yahmum, Al-Ghayth, and Al-Ma'inah. The lands of Ajwad are Al-Rakhimiyah, Al-Dafinah, Lina, and Zarud. The lands of Al-Umar are in Al-Jawf, and it was called Jawf Al-Amr. The lands of their remnants are Al-Lasif, Al-Yahmum, Athlam, and Al-Ma'inah. Followed by the lands of Sa'idah from Al-Khadra to the desert of Zarud. Then Al-Khalid; their lands are Al-Tanumah, Hanidh, Abu Al-Didan, Al-Qari', Al-Kawarah, to Al-Rasuss, to Unayzah, to Waddakh, to Jabalah, to Al-Anjal, to Al-Sirr, to Al-Awrah, to Ashirah. End of the words of the author of Al-Masalik. From the clans of Al-Batnan are Al-Kathir, from Banu Ghazziyah bin Ubayy bin Ghanm bin Haritha bin Thawb bin Ma'n bin Atud bin Haritha bin Lam. They are clans and thighs, Bedouin and settled. Famous among them are two tribes: Al-Banhan clan and Al-Ghassan clan. They descended to Iraq in Banu Lam residents of Al-Amarah. They had kings and fame in ancient times. From them are Al-Aruj. It is said Al-Aruj are from Al-Ghazzi of Al-Fudul; they inhabited the town of Al-Ammariyah. Their last was Udayd bin Aruj, who led Banu Lam after Ajl. From Banu Kathir in Najd are Al-Kathran; they settled in the town of Al-Hariq, and some of them are in Riyadh. From Banu Kathir are Al-Shaqib in the town of Dharma, and Al-Samil in the town of Al-Muzahmiyah; from them are Al-Muzahim. From the clans of Al-Kathran are Al-Ajjaji. It is said they are from Al-Mughira, and their maternal uncles are Kathir. They are thighs; among them is a thigh in Al-Qassim, a thigh in the town of Dharma, and a thigh in the town of Huraymila. From Al-Ajjajat are Al-Sayf; Sayf's ancient town was Al-Uyaynah, then they dispersed from it. From Sayf Al-Ajjajat people of Al-Ahsa are Abd Al-Aziz and his children: Muhammad, Ibrahim, Abd Al-Rahman, and Hasan. From the mentioned Sayf is Abdullah brother of Abd Al-Aziz. From Kathran are Al-Mazhar inhabitants of Mecca and Dariyah in Upper Najd. From them are Al-Yahyan people of Al-Sarw. From the clans of Al-Kathran are Al-Du'ayj and Al-Mansur in the town of Marat. Al-Du'ayj are four thighs: Al-Abd Al-Rahman, Al-Abdullah, Al-Du'ayj, and Al-Ali. They are the descendants of Sheikh Ahmad bin Ali bin Ahmad bin Sulayman bin Abdullah bin Rashid bin Ali bin Ali bin Ahmad bin Ibrahim bin Musa bin Du'ayj, the known clan of Al-Kathran in Ghazziyah Tayy of Banu Lam. He was the judge of Al-Washm in the time of Imam Faysal bin Turki, may Allah have mercy on him, to Egypt and after his return. He was an eloquent poet. He has a poem praising Imam Faysal describing him with chastity and righteousness. From his poetry: 'I did not begin composing except out of love... And it was not my intent to seek gifts by it. Because the God of the Throne has blocked my poverty... And it is a shame to other than Allah that I humble myself. If a seeker of need comes for kindness... We give him above what he hoped for.'

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: 'If kindness comes before his request... Then there is no good in kindness after pleading.' From the clans of Al-Kathran are Al-Sanad, people of Tharmada; from them are Al-Muhattab in the town of Zubair. From the thighs of Al-Kathran are Al-Sanad, Al-Barkhil, and Al-Sahu mentioned in Sudair, and Al-Zamil in Jalajil. From Al-Kathran are Al-Hamaza and Al-Qabasha, people of Al-Hariq from the land of Al-Washm. From Al-Kathran in Al-Ahsa are Al-Kathir. They are the children of Muhammad, three: Salih, Abdullah, and Isa. From Isa was born Salih, who perished. From Abdullah, the descendant is Abd Al-Latif bin Abdullah bin Abd Al-Latif bin Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Uthman. From Salih were born: Ahmad and Abd Al-Rahman. As for Ahmad, he perished. From Abd Al-Rahman were born: Muhammad, Ibrahim, and Salih. To Muhammad was born Salih. To Ibrahim was born Muhammad and Abd Al-Latif. To Salih bin Abd Al-Rahman was born Amr, and to Amr was born Abd Al-Rahman. From the clans of Al-Batnan bin Ghazziyah are Al-Ruqah; a faction of them is in Al-Sham. Banu Taym is a clan of Al-Batnan from Ghazziyah. They mixed with the people of Al-Sawad in Iraq. Their remnants mixed with Tamim bin Murr bin Udd bin Tabikha. As for the clans of Al-Ajwad mentioned previously, some are in the Arabs of Iraq with Banu Lam. From the clans of Al-Ajwad are Al-Shammar clan, Al-Musafir clan, Al-Surayyah clan, Al-Rufay' clan, and Awlad Kafirah clan, mentioned in Masalik Al-Absar. From the clans of Ajwad are Masa'idah mentioned previously; among them is a clan with Al-Zafir, and from them are Masa'idah of Al-Zulfi from the clan known in Otaybah. From the clans of Ajwad are Banu Khalid, mentioned previously in the Arabs of Hijaz. A faction of them headed to Najd with Banu Lam in the ninth Hijri century. They are the Khalid mentioned in the biography of Ajwad bin Zamil, King of Al-Ahsa, in the poet's saying: 'And Najd, the shepherds of the Quarter (Rub') graze its spring... Despite the masters of Lam and Khalid.' Khalid refers to Khalid of Ghazziyah, from whom are Al-Jabur, Al-Janah, Al-Da'um, and the rest of the clans of Banu Khalid that will be mentioned. With them was the faction of Al-Humud mentioned in Ghazziyah. They migrated in the tenth century and ended up in the desert of Al-Kharj. The state of Uqayl Amir ended. The Turks seized Al-Ahsa. Then Al-Humayd wrested it from them in participation with Banu Khalid in the year one thousand and eighty. The first to rule among them was Barrak bin Ghurayr bin Uthman bin Mas'ud bin Rabi'ah. Rabi'ah is from Al-Humayd mentioned previously. With Barrak on that day were Husayn bin Uthman bin Mas'ud bin Rabi'ah, and Muhanna Al-Jabri from Al-Jabur. They attacked the Turkish gatekeepers and expelled them from Al-Ahsa and Qatif. Barrak died in the year one thousand and ninety-five. His brother Muhammad bin Ghurayr ruled after him and died in the year one thousand one hundred and three. His son Sa'dun ruled and died in the year one thousand one hundred and thirty-five. Then Al-Humayd disputed over leadership after Sa'dun's death; Dujayn bin Sa'dun disputed with his uncles Ali, Sulayman, and Ghurayr, and the children of Muhammad bin Ghurayr. Ali seized the command, and after him his brother Sulayman. Then Al-Mahashir from Banu Khalid betrayed Sulayman bin Muhammad bin Ghurayr and expelled him. He came to Al-Kharj and died there in the year one thousand one hundred and sixty-six. Then Ghurayr seized power; he is the son of Dujayn bin Sa'dun bin Muhammad bin Ghurayr, after killing his father's uncle Ghurayr bin Muhammad. The command fell to Ghurayr and his children, who are: Dujayn, Sa'dun, Majid, Muhammad, and Zayd. His son Dujayn took command after Ghurayr, then Sa'dun. Their rule over Al-Ahsa and Qatif was before the rule of Saud bin Abd Al-Aziz, and its end was the year one thousand two hundred and seven after the destruction of Diriyah. Then Majid, Muhammad, and children of Ghurayr took command in Al-Ahsa and Qatif after the rule of Al Saud. Then Imam Turki bin Abdullah, may Allah have mercy on him, wrested command from them in the year one thousand two hundred and forty-five. Al-Ghurayr are: Nayef, Faysal, and Badr; they are maternal uncles of the Crown Prince Saud bin Imam Abd Al-Aziz bin Abd Al-Rahman Al-Faysal Al-Saud. From Al-Humayd are Abdullah bin Ghurayr bin Uthman; from them are Barrak and Nahar. From Al-Humayd are Al-Husayn bin Uthman bin Mas'ud bin Rabi'ah; from them are Al-Hazza'. From them are Al-Ghurayr people of Shaqra, and Al-Sab'a - from whom is Abd Al-Rahman Al-Subay'i - and Al-Fadil, and Al-Ammar people of Al-Qara'in. These are in Ghurayr. As for Banu Khalid, they are three clans and have thighs. From their clans are: Al-Jabur, Al-Janah, and Al-Da'um. They were Al-Humayd then dispersed. From the clans of Al-Jabur are Al-Sayyar, called Al-Sayayirah; from them was Ibn Sayyar.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: They inhabited Al-Qasab. Then they dispersed from it, so only a few remained there, due to a battle that occurred between them at Umm al-Jamajim in Mazaj. From them is Uthman, grandfather of Al-Bulayhid. To Uthman was born: Saud, Abdullah, Salim, and Sulayman. Their seat was Al-Qara'in. As for Sulayman, Abdullah was born to him. To Abdullah was born Saud; he was a judge for Imam Turki in Al-Qassim. His descendants are in Al-Bukayriyah, Al-Shabḥiyah, and Al-Qar'a. From them is Sheikh Abdullah bin Bulayhid. As for Salim bin Bulayhid, from his descendants are Al-Salim people of Al-Qara'in. As for Abdullah bin Bulayhid the First, from his descendants are Al-Bulayhid people of Al-Qara'in: Muhammad and his brothers, and his cousins. He is Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Uthman bin Saud bin Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Bulayhid bin Uthman bin Bulayhid bin Abdullah bin Fawzan bin Muhammad bin Ayed bin Bulayhid bin Uthman the First who went out from the town of Al-Qasab. From them are Al-Hufayr people of Ushayqir. From Banu Khalid are Al-Ghannam and Al-Shabib people of Al-Qasab. As for Al-Suwayda people of Al-Qasab, and Al-Uthman, family of Sheikh Al-Shawi in Al-Bukayriyah, they are from Al-Balqum (Al-Buqum). From Banu Khalid are Al-Shuway'ir from Al-Da'um. From Al-Jabur are Al-Shaqri people of Riyadh. From Al-Jabur are Al-Falih people of the tribe of Rabiq in Raghbah. Al-Khalid in Thawaj (Thadiq?), Al-Duhaym in Huraymila, Al-Jarawi in Sudair and in Al-Ahsa, Al-Majid people of Al-Barrah, Al-Hamid in Tharmada, Al-Awshan in Shaqra, Al-Khalaf in Al-Sha'ra and Al-Quway'iyah. As for Al-Sayayirah, from them in the town of Dharma are Al-Sayf. From them are Al-Arfa in Al-Quway'iyah, and Al-Arfa people of Al-Muzahmiyah. From Banu Khalid in Al-Ahsa are the people of Waddi, Al-Ghunaym, Al-Baddah, Al-Sharish, Al-Du'ayj in the village of Al-Dashah, Al-Juwayd, Al-Far'in, and Al-Faris in Al-Mubarraz. From Banu Khalid are Al-Sahban people of the village of Al-Miqdam. From them are Al-Fayyad, Al-Dabil, Al-Safiyah, and Al-Badin in Al-Mubarraz. From Banu Khalid are Al-Qarshah; from them are Al-Bu Ayyash in Al-Mubarraz. From Banu Khalid are Al-Mahashir. From the clans of Al-Mahashir are Al-Nuwayran in the village of Al-Shaqif; they are the children of Salih bin Muhammad. To Salih was born: Muhanna and Muhammad. From the children of Muhammad bin Salih: Ahmad bin Sultan bin Muhammad mentioned. From the children of Muhammad: Salih bin Sa'dun bin Sultan bin Muhammad. As for Muhanna, from his children: Ahmad bin Sulayman bin Hamad bin Muhanna bin Salih bin Muhammad Al-Nuwayran. From the children of Muhanna: Abd Al-Aziz bin Abdullah bin Sahl bin Ahmad bin Muhanna. From the clans of Al-Mahashir are Al-Kulayb, Al-Thunayan, Al-Ujayl, Al-Ubaykah, and Al-Ali. These are Bedouins. In Al-Ahsa, from them are the children of Abdullah Al-Khatib in Al-Mubarraz, Al-Dughan in Al-Kut, and Al-Suwaykit in the town of Al-Kharj; these are from Al-Mahashir. From Al-Jabur are Al-Afrawi in the desert of Iraq. From Banu Khalid are Al-Shubat in Al-Mubarraz. From the clans of Banu Khalid are Al-Janah; their lands were Unayzah in ancient times. From Al-Janah are Al-Khuwaytir people of Unayzah. From them is the family of Al-Juffali, Al-Rabbad people of Buraydah, and Al-Dab'an people of Hail. From Banu Khalid are Al-Balla' people of Al-Ramas. Attached to Banu Khalid are clans, including Al-Ma'amirah, and Mayyas, clans from Banu Khalid. Al-Uljan are from Banu Khalid; from them is Sheikh Abd Al-Aziz Al-Ulji, inhabitant of Al-Salihiyah in Al-Hofuf. From Banu Khalid are Al-Maniha. From the clans of Al-Ajwad are Al-Abi Haram clan from Ghazziyah, Banu Malik clan, and Al-Ali clan. These are from Ghazziyah Tayy, mentioned by Ibn Fadlallah Al-Umari in the book 'Al-Ta'rif'. Al-Suyuti mentioned in 'Qala'id Al-Juman' from Ghazziyah Tayy: Banu Uqayl, Al-Barjis, and Ghalib; these are in Ghazziyah. From the clans of Banu Lam are Zafir. It is said Al-Zafir are from Al-Mughira. From their clans are Al-Samdah, Al-Askar - from whom are Askar of Al-Kharj - Al-Sawtah clan of Zafir - from whom are Al-Sawtah in Otaybah - and Al-Duwayhi clan. Leadership is famous in Al-Suwayt Duwayhi. Al-Sa'diyah is a clan of Zafir; as for Al-Sa'di, they are from Al-Asim. From the clans of Tayy: Banu Rabi'ah clan. This Rabi'ah appeared in Al-Sham in year five hundred and seventy-seven. He had four children: Fadl, Mira', Nabit, and Daghfal. Al-Hamdani said: He is Rabi'ah bin Hazim bin Ali bin Mufarrij bin Daghfal bin Jarrah bin Shabib bin Mis'ar bin Sa'id bin Harb bin Al-Rabi' bin Ghulfi bin Hawt bin Amr bin Khalid bin Sa'id bin Adi bin Amr bin Tha'l. It is said he is from Adi Banu Lam.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Banu Rabi'ah of Tayy inherited the land of Ghassan in Al-Sham. Leadership passed to the family of Isa bin Muhanna bin Fadl, rotating among them. The dwellings and stations of Al-Fadl were from Homs to Al-Ju'ayr, to Al-Rajbah, to the edge of the Euphrates, to the outskirts of Busra, overlooking Al-Washm. Joined with them from the rest of the Arabs were Khalid of Homs, Khalid of Hijaz - all from Ghazziyah Tayy - Al-Jabur, Al-Janah, Al-Da'um, Al-Dubaybat, Al-Qurshah, Al-Thuyut, Al-Ma'amarah, and Al-Aljat. Al-Maqri said: The family of Isa bin Muhanna are masters of people and kings of the land, far or near. The Arabs did not reconcile upon other than them. As for Al-Mira' from Rabi'ah. He said in Masalik Al-Absar: Their lands are from Al-Haydur to Al-Zaffa, to Busra, to the Harrah known as Harrah Kishb near Mecca, to Al-Hadb, to Sha'ya. Under their emirate enter Al-Mughira, Al-Ghazzi from Al-Fudul, Al-Zafir, Al-Barjis, and Al-Khurasan. From Ghazziyah are Al-Batnan. From the rest of the Arabs of the wilderness (Barriyah) are Banu Mudlij, Banu Sakhr, Banu Husayn Al-Sharafa, Mutayr, Anazzah, Khath'am, Adwan, Zubaid, Hauran, and others. From Rabi'ah Tayy are Al-Ali; they are from Banu Ali Haditha bin Ghadbah bin Fadl mentioned previously. He said in Masalik Al-Absar: Even if they are from Al-Fadl, they have separated from them until they became another faction. Their dwellings are Marj Dimashq (Damascus) and its Ghouta, to Al-Jawf, Al-Habbaniyah, and Al-Shikah, to Tayma. From the thighs of Al-Rabi'ah are Al-Faraj clan from Al-Fadl, Al-Nimran from Rabi'ah Tayy, Al-Tuma clan from Al-Mira', Al-Yankhar clan from Al-Mira', and Al-Bashar clients (Mawali); they are allies of Al-Fadl from Rabi'ah Tayy. Their dwellings are Aleppo, mentioned by Al-Hamdani. Al-Amir clan from Rabi'ah Tayy, and Al-Ahmad clan from Al-Mira', mentioned by Al-Hamdani. He said in Masalik Al-Absar: In them is the emirate of Al-Mira'. Banu Al-Jarrah is a clan from Rabi'ah Tayy; the Emirate in Banu Rabi'ah Tayy is in them. Among that is that the Emirs of Al-Rabi'ah Tayy gathered, including Sa'id bin Fadl the famous from Tayy, Mani' bin Haditha, Mas'ud Barik from Al-Sumayt of Al-Mughira, and Dahmash from Dahmash, who is Sanad bin Dahmash bin Ajwad. These are from the chiefs of Tayy. They gathered to raid Banu Uqayl bin Amir bin Sa'sa'ah, who are: Amir, Khafajah, and 'A'idh. And those who mixed with them from the tribes of Qays and Rabi'ah. They knew that Tayy wanted to raid them, so they sent to the Caliph Nasir al-Din. He sent to Prince Muhammad bin Husayn Al-Uyuni, who was then Emir over Hajar Bahrain and Qatif. He marched with all the Arabs of Hajar, Qatif, and Bahrain until he caught up with them in Iraq. The Arabs of Iraq from Al-Muntafiq, Ubadah, Khafajah, and 'A'idh joined him. A fierce battle occurred between them. Sa'id bin Fadl had famous events. This is the last of what we mentioned regarding Tayy. Section: From the tribes of Kahlan is Madhhij bin Azd bin 'Arib bin Azd bin 'Arib bin Zayd; he is the brother of Tayy mentioned previously. From Banu Madhhij is Janb; they are Banu Yazid bin Harb bin Illah bin Khalid bin Al-Jald bin Madhhij. This Khalid, from him is a great generation called Banu Khalid, mixed into Khalid of Hijaz, its house, and surroundings. Banu Yazid are clans. He had children: Hafnan, Shamran, Siman, Al-Fala, Munabbih, Al-Harith, and Sada'. They were named Janb only because they side-stepped (janabu) their brother Sada' and allied with Sa'd Al-Ashirah. Banu Hafnan is a clan of Madhhij from Janb; from them are Al-Sayahin who are in Otaybah, and from them are Al-Sirah Sayhan from Abiyat Mutayr. From the clans of Janb are Banu Raha, Banu Munabbih clan from Janb, and Banu Sada' clan. They are Banu Sada' bin Yazid bin Harb brother of Janb. Abu Ubaydah said: Sada' allied with Banu Al-Harith bin Ka'b. From them is Ziyad bin Harith Al-Sada'i; he came as a delegation to the Prophet, peace be upon him, who sent him to his people, so they converted. From the clans of Janb is Banu Muawiyah bin Al-Harith bin Munabbih bin Yazid bin Harb bin Nahlah bin Khalid bin Illah bin Al-Jald bin Madhhij. Muawiyah bin Al-Harith was the one in whom was the House and Kingship in Janb. He is the one whom Muhalhil brother of Kulayb sought refuge with. Muawiyah is the grandfather of Banu Dhaygham. From them is Abde, whose mention we presented in Shammar. From Banu Dhaygham: Al-Fagham and his group in Mutayr. From them are Al-Battal inhabitants of Riyadh. From Banu Al-Harith bin Janb: Banu Shaddad, a clan of Janb. He is Shaddad bin Qanan bin Salamah from Banu Al-Harith mentioned. From them is Al-Husayn Dhu Al-Fiddah bin Yazid bin Shaddad; he led Banu Al-Harith. From Shaddad are Al-Shaddadin Al-Shalawa with Banu Al-Harith. From the clans of Shaddad is Banu Muflih; they are clans. From the clans of Muflih is Al-Fahr, the clan known in Ubaydah, folk of Shaflut.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From them is Al-Jalayghim. From the clans of Muflih are Al-Da'ajin in Barqa; they are four clans: Al-Mallaniyah, Dhawi Khayut, Al-Ma'alibah, and Al-Hadaf. Attached to Al-Da'ajin are Al-Ghathamah, people of Hijaz, group of Al-Abbud. From the clans of Banu Shaddad are Al-Arjan. From Janb are Al-Sulayman, Al-Zaydan, Al-Zuhayr, Al-Masaridah, Al-Manadiyah, and Al-Kar'an. From the clans of Janb are Al-Hadar, and they are clans. From their clans are Al-Jaru, from whom are Duwayhi and Huday' the Brave. Al-Abs is a clan of Al-Saqr. From the family of Salih Al-Madawi, inhabitant of the town of Riyadh, Al-Quraysh, Al-Jarabiy, and 'A'idh from Al-Suqayr of Ubaydah. From 'A'idh are 'A'idh of Al-Kharj, from whom are Al-Mu'aydh, Al-Isa people of Al-Ahsa, Abd Al-Rahman bin Muhammad Al-Sahlawi, Al-Hariri, Al-Da'ij, Al-Isa people of Shaqra, and Al-Zamil people of Ushay of Al-Washm; they are Al-Abdullah and Al-Zamil. From 'A'idh are Al-Ufaysan people of Al-Kharj, Al-Shuhayl people of Dharma, Al-Batin in the villages of Najd, Al-Awwad, and Al-Salim in Diriyah. From the clans of Al-Saqr are Al-Jald, the clan known from Banu Al-Jald bin Madhhij. From the clans of Janb are Hamalah, the clan known in Ubaydah. From them is the clan of Al-Hamla in Al-Ahsa. From them are the children of Abd Al-Latif bin Musa bin Sulayman bin Muhammad Al-Hamla. From them are the children of Abdullah bin Salih Al-Hamla. From them are the children of Muhammad bin Khalifa, and children of his brother Khalifa bin Abdullah bin Ahmad Al-Khalifa. From their clans are Al-Mansur inhabitants of Al-Na'athil. These are from the clans of Hamalah. From the clans of Janb are Al-Harqan, the clan known in Ubaydah. From them are Al-Shashur people of Al-Hawtah. From the clans of Al-Harqan is Muqbil clan. From Banu Muqbil are Al-Dalabihah known in Otaybah. From them are Dhawi Asay thigh, Dhawi Sayfar thigh, Al-Hilal, Al-Suwayd, and Al-Hammadin. As for Al-Ghawaribah, they are from Judham. From the clans of Janb is Sharif, the clan known in Ubaydah. From them is the group of Ibn Dulaym; their lands are Khamis Ubaydah near Bisha. They are the most numerous of Qahtan. From them are the people of Jash and Tashlit. From the clans of Sharif are Banu Bishr, Banu Hajir, and Banu [...]. Clans and thighs returning to two origins: Al-Muhammad and Al-Makhdabah. From Banu Hajir is Al-Mayiqi, the clan known in Al-Manasir, from Banu Mansur bin Zahwan of Azd. It was mentioned that Banu Hajir are in the lineage of Azd. From Banu Hajir is Al-Hamzad, inhabitant of the town of Fadij. From the clans of Sharif is Al-Hamra clan. From Al-Hamra is the family of Ali bin Rashid, inhabitant of Al-Ahsa, and Muhammad bin Nasir Al-Dawud. From the clans of Sharif are Al-Dawud and Al-Hadan. From the clans of Madhhij: Ibn Maslamah bin Amir bin Amr bin Illah bin Khalid bin Al-Jald bin Madhhij. To Maslamah was born Kinana and Asad, sons of Maslamah. From Banu Kinana bin Maslamah are Banu Subh and Tha'labah, sons of Tashirah. Their mother is Hubabah, by whom they are known. From them is Banu Abi Rabi'ah bin Subh, called Abu Na'amah. From Banu Hubabah: Amir bin Isma'il the Leader, and Ibn Humamah the Jahili Poet. From Banu Hubabah is Al-Hubab, the clan known in Qahtan; from them is Al-Humaydani from the people of Sabha. From the clans of Madhhij is Banu Al-Harith bin Malik bin Rabi'ah bin Amr bin Uqbah bin Khalid bin Illah bin Khalid bin Al-Jald bin Madhhij. From Banu Al-Harith is Banu Rib'i bin Ubayd Allah bin Abd Al-Madan. From Banu Abd Al-Madan are the Kings of Najran. Abd Al-Madan is Yazid bin Al-Dayyan bin Qatan bin Ziyad bin Al-Harith bin Ka'b. They are a clan from Banu Al-Harith. From them is Dhawi Rib'i, the clan known in Otaybah, who are Al-Hafah. From them are Dhu Saqr, Al-Thuman thigh, Al-Tuwayq thigh, Al-Raqisah thigh, and from them Al-Yabbas. It says in 'Nihayat Al-Arab': From Banu Al-Harith are those inhabiting east of Ta'if in the region of Tajnub; they are Banu Al-Harith Al-Shalawa. From the clans of Banu Al-Harith is Banu Al-Hamas, mentioned by Abu Ubayd. From them is Al-Najashi and his brother Jada', sons of Amr; he was noble. In their people is Hamasa (bravery); Hamasa in language means bravery. From the clans of Al-Harith is Abd Al-Madan bin Al-Dayyan. It says in Al-Ibar: Leadership belonged to Banu Al-Dayyan in Najran. Kingship was in Banu Abd Al-Madan, ending before the Mission with Yazid bin Abd Al-Madan. His brother came as a delegation to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and converted. Ubayd said: From Banu Al-Dayyan is Al-Rabi' bin Ziyad, Emir of Khurasan in the time of Muawiyah, may Allah be pleased with him. From Banu Al-Harith is Banu Ziyad clan and Banu Zayid clan. From Banu Ziyad is Dhawi Ziyad, the clan known in Barqa. From them are Al-Raqban, Dhawi Al-Udul thigh, Al-Fars, Dhawi Ulayyan, Al-Maqati'ah thigh - called Dhawi Juwayr - and Al-Qatafin clan. From them are Dhawi Husayn, Al-Sab'ah, Al-Fasl, and Al-Ma'nayin. From them are Madayin of Harb. Al-Fuqaha are allies of Al-Sab'ah from Al-Warqah.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: These are Banu Ziyad. And Banu Za'idah in southern Najd. From the clans of Banu Al-Harith are Al-Marashid, sons of Salamah bin Al-Ma'qil bin Ka'b bin Rabi'ah bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith; they are called Al-Marashid. From the descendants of Amr bin Al-Harith is Al-Hajal bin Hazn clan. In Al-Ibar: Their dwellings are in the regions of Najran. Abu Abd al-Barr said: From them is Al-Harith, who came as a delegation to the Prophet, peace be upon him. He said to him: "Welcome. What is your name?" He said: "Al-Harith." He said: "Rather, your name is Bashir." They were in the regions of Najran, neighboring Banu Dhuhl bin Amr bin Muzayqiya. From Banu Al-Ma'qil bin Ka'b Al-Ma'mur bin Muawiyah, upon whom Madhhij united, from them is Al-Jallah who gouged the eye of Amir bin Al-Tufayl on the Day of Fayd Al-Rih. Ibn Hisham said: The delegation of Banu Al-Harith came to the Prophet, peace be upon him. He said to them: "By what did you overcome people, O Banu Al-Harith?" They said: "By three things: We used to unite and not separate, we never started injustice against anyone, and we were patient during encounter." From the clans of Madhhij is Udad bin Madhhij. He was a wise man in his time, and an obeyed master among his people. He lived for a long time, aged until his sight weakened, his hearing dulled, and his steps shortened. He advised his sons with verses of poetry we did not mention. In Al-Iqd Al-Farid: Udad and Sa'b are from the sons of Sa'd Al-Ashirah. Section: Sa'd Al-Ashirah is Mas'ad bin Madhhij. He was named Sa'd Al-Ashirah (Sa'd of the Clan) only because his sons and sons' sons reached three hundred men riding with him. If he was asked about them, he said: "These are my clan (Ashirati)," as protection from the Evil Eye. From the clans of Sa'd Al-Ashirah are Awd and Zubaid, whose name is Munabbih; they are sons of Sa'b bin Sa'd. From them is Zubaid the Younger. From Awd is Abu Al-Maghra' the Poet. From them is Al-Za'af: he is Amir bin Harb bin Sa'd bin Munabbih bin Awd. From them is Abdullah bin Idris the Jurist. From them is Al-Afwah the Poet, whose name is Al-Salat bin Amr. From them is Banu Ruman bin Ka'b bin Awd; from his descendants is Uqbah bin Zayd Al-Samid. From them is Banu Qarn; they have a mosque in Kufa. As for Zubaid, he is Munabbih bin Mus'ab bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah. Zubaid is in Yemen. From them is Zubaid the Younger: he is Zubaid bin Rabi'ah the Elder. From them is Zubaid of Hijaz, who entered into Masruh. Masruh is from Saba bin Yashjub bin Ya'rub bin Qahtan, mentioned in Al-Iqd Al-Farid. The name Masruh and the name Harb, grandfather of Zubaid the Elder, encompassed them. They settled in Hijaz between Medina, Usfan, and Najd. Al-Suwaydi said: They are Zubaid upon whom the pilgrims of Egypt pass from Al-Safra to Al-Juhfah to Rabigh. The people of Rabigh today are the group of Mubayrik, Emir of Rabigh. The name Harb and Masruh has encompassed dispersed nations from every district. From this Zubaid is Amir bin Al-Asqa' the Poet, and Muawiyah bin Qays bin Salamah Al-Afkal; they were noble. From them is Al-Harith bin Amr bin Abdullah bin Qays bin Abi Amr bin Rabi'ah bin Asim bin Amr bin Zubaid the Younger. From this Amr is Banu Amr, the clan known in Harb. From them is [Amr] bin Ma'dikarib Al-Zubaydi. He was one of the horsemen of the Arabs in Jahiliyyah and Islam; he converted, may Allah be pleased with him. In Al-Isti'ab: He came as a delegation to the Prophet, peace be upon him. He has good performance in Yarmouk and likewise in Qadisiyah. From the clans of Zubaid the Younger is Zubaid of Hauran, mentioned in Masalik Al-Absar. From Zubaid is Banu Nawfal; in Banu Nawfal is the Emirate. From the clans of Zubaid are Al-Safi and Al-Marja, mentioned by Al-Hamdani in the Arabs of Salkhad. From the clans of Zubaid is Al-Muhsin; they are in the Ghouta of Damascus, mentioned by Al-Hamdani. From them is Al-Hurayth clan, Al-Jahsh clan from Zubaid of Salkhad, and Al-Badrah clan from Banu Nawfal. From Zubaid is Sinjar; they are many clans. From Zubaid of Hauran are Al-Duruz. The mentioned Harb is divided into three clans: Masruh, Banu Salim, and Banu Abdullah. As for Banu Salim, we will mention them in Judham, God willing. As for Masruh: Zubaid (this one) is a clan, Banu Ali is a clan - they are people of Al-Awali, group of Al-Azm - Banu Amr is a clan, Awf is a clan, Al-Rahman is a clan, Al-Suhaylah is a clan, Al-Sawa'id is a clan, Al-Salibah, Al-Anshah, Al-Tarsan, Al-Hunud, Al-Hanahinah, Ruwaythah, and Al-Biladi. Masruh unites these. As for Al-Abdah people of Abu Dhiya', they are from Abde of Anazzah. As for Banu Abdullah, they are from Banu Al-Sa'b bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah. From them are Al-Sa'bah Al-Abadilah who are in Mutayr; they were anciently with their brothers Zubaid. Al-Abadilah are sections: Al-Rahimi, Qayshi, Mukhayfiri, Al-Sa'bi, Al-Qaffini, Uqayli, Ja'fari, Qab'ani, Dhabiti, Shalahi, Maymuni, Mishraqi, and Al-Sakan. The alliance unites these. From the clans of Sa'b bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah: Banu Zayd Allah and Banu Asad. His sons are called Banu Numayrah. He had children: Alma' and Salamah. Abu Ubaydah said: Numayrah entered into Murad. From them is A'idh Allah and Al-Hakam.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Al-Hakam is a large tribe. From them is Al-Barrah, owner of Khurasan. From them is Ibn Abdullah Al-Hakami, killed by the Turks in the days of Umar bin Abd al-Aziz. They are the clients (Mawali) of Abu Nuwas. From them is Umayr bin Bishr. Banu Bunduqah is a clan from Al-Hakam. The famous of Al-Sa'bakah mentioned previously are Al-Dahnah clan, and Al-Safi clan; from them is Abu Al-Safa and Al-Darwish. From the clans of Sa'd Al-Ashirah is Banu Ju'fi. From them is Banu Harran clan from Ju'fi; from them is Alqamah bin Al-Hurr and Al-Jarrah bin Hasan. Banu Wael is a clan from Ju'fi; from them is Dinar bin Badiyah the Poet. From the clans of Ju'fi is Banu Salamah bin Amr bin Dhuhl bin Harran; from them is Abu Dabrah, may Allah be pleased with him. From them is Banu Al-Harith clan from Banu Amr bin Dhuhl bin Marwan. From the clans of Marran is Banu Badda; they are from Banu Amr bin Awf bin Dhuhl bin Marran. Banu Harim is a clan from Ju'fi. From them is Banu Malik bin Harim clan. From them is Ju'fi Abu Al-Tayyib Al-Mutanabbi the Poet. From them is Abu Al-Ala Al-Ma'arri the Poet. From the clans of Ju'fi is Al-Jami' clan; they are from Banu Malik bin Amr bin Sa'd bin Awf bin Harim mentioned previously. From them is Mulayl, whose name is Salamah bin Zayd, and his maternal brother Qays bin Salamah; he came as a delegation to the Prophet, peace be upon him. From the clans of Sa'd Al-Ashirah is Al-Jamal, the clan known in Qahtan. From them is Al-Mas'ud; the emirate is in Al-Abbud. Attached to them are Al-Masa'id of Otaybah. It is reported from them that the separation occurred between them in the time of Ujayr bin Ghadib Al-Mas'udi and Ja'far bin Abbud, and their separation has a cause. From the clans of Al-Jamal are Al-Suwaydan and Al-Shalfan known in the town of Shaqra and Kuwait. Al-Haqbul people of Dharma; it is said they are from Nawasir of Tamim, and it is said they are from Muqbil mentioned previously in Ubaydah. From the clans of Jamal are Al-Ulayyan, Al-Mani', Al-Ayaf, Al-Shabwah, and Al-Ajarishah. From Al-Ayaf Ibn Jamal: Al-Afaliq. They inhabited Al-Khubra, Riyadh Al-Khubra, and Al-Bada'i from the land of Al-Qassim. From them in Unayzah are Al-Hasan. From Al-Hasan: Al-Khudayr, Al-Khamisi, and Al-Hammad. From them are Al-Abu Al-Hadi. From Al-Abu Al-Hadi: Al-Sukayt and Al-Dahama. From them are Al-Nuwaysir. From Al-Nuwaysir are Al-Uwayd. From them are Al-Udayb. From Al-Udayb: Al-Sultan and Al-Duhayman. From Al-Afaliq also are Al-Sahabin and Al-Sughayr. From Al-Sughayr are Al-Afaliq, inhabitants of Al-Mubarraz in Al-Ahsa. They are the children of Husayn bin Muhammad. From Al-Ayaf are Al-Ruways, inhabitants of Al-Yamamah. From the clans of Jamal: Al-Jamadirah and Al-Muhammad. It is said they are brothers, and it is said they are from Banu Jamal. They are many clans. Among their largest clans: Al-Sa'd, Al-Sahamah, Al-Atif, Al-Masha'ilah, and Al-Khanafirah. From them are Khanafirah of Al-Muqatta. From the clans of Muhammad are Al-Ruq and Al-Asim. As for Ruq, they are from Ruq mentioned previously from Tayy. As for Al-Asim, they are from Al-Sulayman. They are clans; among them Al-Udayb, group of Ibn Hashr, and Al-Nassar clan. From the clans of Al-Asim are Al-Asamah (Al-Asa'imah), the clan known in Barqa. They are clans: Al-Sha'fan clan - they are Al-Rawin, Al-Hamarin, Al-Samra', Al-Janab, Al-Ja'arin, and Al-Jalah. From them are Al-Naffarin, Al-Ababid, Al-Umariyah, Al-Samhan, and Al-Shaja'in - these are a clan. Al-Azdal and Al-Husaynat are a clan. Al-Alawiyah is a clan; Al-Alawiyah are from Alwa. Anciently they did not separate; the first of their separation was Ali bin Mashutah. From Al-Asim are Al-Sa'id who are with Al-Zafir. From Al-Sa'id are Al-Muqhim, Al-Qasim, Al-Mani', and Al-Hudayb; their dwellings are the town of Al-Qasab in Al-Washm. From them in Thadiq are Al-Nasir, people of Uthaythiya, from Al-Asim, from the family of Huwaydi. From the clans of Madhhij is Nakha'; he is Nakha' bin Amr bin Khalid bin Illah bin Khalid bin Al-Jald bin Madhhij. They are clans and thighs. From them is Banu Suhban clan. From them is Kumayl bin Ziyad, whom Al-Hajjaj killed. From Banu Suhban are Al-Suhbah who are in Mutayr; they are called Dhawi Awn. From them are Al-Jubayl clan, Al-Saqayin clan, Dhawi Shatit clan, Al-Kamahin clan, Dhawi Mizan clan, Al-Harsan clan, Al-Salayimah clan, and Al-Mala'ibah clan. As for the group of Al-Ghanam, they are from Dhaygham, and we have mentioned them previously. From the clans of Nakha' is Bani Hayl, Sharik bin Abdullah the Judge, and Banu Jadhima clan. From the clans of Nakha' is Banu Haritha clan of Nakha'; from them is Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i the Jurist, Al-Hajjaj bin Artah, and Al-Ashtar whom Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, appointed over Egypt, writing him a covenant which is the most eloquent of covenants. From Banu Jadhima and from their clans are Amir, Qays, and Ka'b. From them is Banu Ada, brother of the family of Kings from Kinda. From the clans of Nakha' is Banu Awf bin Bakr; Abu Ubayd said: They are Bakr of Nakha', from them is Yazid Al-Mukattif and Alqamah bin Abs. From the clans of Awf is Jashm, and from Jashm is Banu Amr clan.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From Banu Amr is Banu Hilal. From Banu Hilal is Al-Adnan bin Haytham bin Al-Aswad. From the clans of Madhhij is Banu Ans. From them is Sa'd the Elder, Sa'd the Younger, Malkan, Amr, Mukhasir, Muawiyah, 'Arib, Atik, Shihab, Al-Qariyah, and Ya'am. These are clans of Madhhij. From them is Malik bin Ans Al-Aswad bin Ka'b who claimed prophethood in Yemen. From Ya'am bin Ans is Ammar bin Yasir the Companion, may Allah be pleased with him. From Sa'd the Elder are the nobles of Ans, including: Amir bin Rabi'ah, who witnessed Badr with the Prophet, peace be upon him; he is an ally to Quraysh. From the clans of Madhhij is Murad. From the clans of Murad are Najiyah, Zahir, and An'am. From Najiyah bin Murad: Farwah Musayk, who was governor for the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, over Najran. From Banu Zahir is Murad, and Qays bin Hubayrah bin Abd Al-Ghawth. From Najiyah bin Murad is Banu Jamal bin Kinana; from them is Hind bin Amr Al-Jamali, killed by Abdullah bin Al-Nashri on the Day of the Camel. From Banu Zahir: Murad Qays bin Makshuh. From Murad is Hani' bin Urwah, killed with Muslim bin Aqil. From the clans of Zahir bin Murad: Banu Uqban clan. From the clans of Murad is Al-Rabs; from them is Safwan bin Assal. Abu Ubayd said: His reckoning is in Banu Jamal, kin of Amr bin Murrah. From Murad: Banu Qarn bin Najiyah clan. From them is Uways Al-Qarni; he is Uways bin Amr bin Malik bin Amr bin Sa'd bin Amr bin Imran bin Qarn bin Darhan bin Najiyah bin Murad bin Malik bin Madhhij. He is the one about whom the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Reinforcements from Yemen will come to you, among them Uways Al-Qarni. As many as Rabi'ah and Mudar will enter Paradise by his intercession." He was one of the Tabi'un, may Allah have mercy on him. From Qarn: Al-Qarniyah in Al-Shamir; they are thighs, among them Al-Dabbah. Among them are settled people in the villages of Najd. Among them are Al-Muhanna people of Al-Barrah. From the clans of Ubayd is Al-Yumna, residents of Al-Kharj and Al-Ahsa. From the clans of Dhaygham: Al-Shahwan in Banu Hajir mentioned previously. From the clans of Ubaydah is 'A'id; among them are some in Al-Kharj and in Al-Ahsa. From the clans of Kahlan is Al-Ash'ariyun (The Ash'aris), Banu Awd bin Zayd bin Kahlan. The Ash'aris are clans and thighs. Among them is Al-Ad'am clan, Al-An'am clan, Jaddah clan, Maratah clan, Manamah clan, As'ad clan, Sahl clan, Ukabah clan, Al-Shara'ibah clan - to whom Shar'abi spears are attributed - Al-Shataliyah clan, and Al-Da'alij clan. Their place was in Yemen, and they dispersed. From the Ash'aris: The people of Iraq, among whom is Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with him, companion of the Prophet, peace be upon him.
