He is the one who attended the watering place known as Hafr Al-Batin. From the Ash'aris is Al-Sa'ib bin Malik, who was governor of Al-Mukhtar's police, and he is the one who strengthened his command. From them is Malik Al-Ash'ari, whom the Prophet, peace be upon him, married to one of the women of Banu Hashim. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said to her: "Are you not pleased that I married you to a man who, he and his people, are better than what the sun rose upon!" He (peace be upon him) said: "O Banu Hashim, marry the Ash'aris and get married from them, for they are among people like a purse of musk, or like a citron; if you smell its outside you find it good, and likewise its inside." From the Ash'aris is Abu Amir [cousin of] Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with them both, who pursued those fleeing from Hawazin after the Battle of Hunayn. With him were a group of Companions. They met at Awtas and engaged in fighting. Abu Amir killed nine men of them in duel, calling each one to Islam. If he refused, Abu Amir would say: "O Allah, bear witness against him that I called him to Islam and he refused." He killed nine. When the tenth dueled him, he called him to Islam and he refused. He said: "O Allah, bear witness that I called him and he refused." He said: "O Allah, do not bear witness." So he held back from him, and he converted. The Prophet, peace be upon him, whenever he saw him, would say: "This is the fugitive of Abu Amir." From the clans of Awd is Khawlan; he is Khawlan bin Al-Harith bin Murrah bin Awd. From Banu Khawlan: Banu Sa'd clan, Banu Nabt clan, Al-Ashhab clan, Habib clan, and Amr clan. From them is Abu Idris Al-Khawlani. It says in Al-Ibar: Khawlan is in Yemen, and they dispersed in the Islamic conquests. There is a large multitude of them in Yemen. Section: On Amilah. Amilah is a clan from Kahlan. Most of them are in Al-Sham; the Mountains of Amilah are in Al-Sham. Amilah mixed with the people of Al-Jaza'ir. From the clans of Amilah: Banu Muawiyah, and Banu Mash'al. From them is Qu'aysis who captured Adi bin Hatim, then Shu'ayb bin Rabi' Al-Kalbi took him from him without ransom. From the clans of Amilah in Al-Sham: Banu Ajl and Banu Salamah. Section: On Lakhm. Lakhm is Lakhm bin Malik bin Adi bin Al-Harith bin Murrah bin Udad bin Zayd bin Kahlan. From the clans of Lakhm is Jazilah clan, and Namarah clan; from it the clans of Lakhm separated.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From Namarah bin Lakhm are the Kings of Al-Hira after Jadhima Al-Abrash. The first of them was Amr bin Adi, son of Jadhima Al-Abrash's sister. He is the one whom the Jinn snatched and Aqil and Malik brought him back. Al-Zabba' killed Jadhima bin Al-Abrash, and the Kingship of Al-Hira went to Amr bin Adi and his descendants after the killing of Jadhima. The number of kings from his descendants was twenty-six kings. Khalid bin Al-Walid, may Allah be pleased with him, wrested the Kingship from them after the Islamic conquest. The last of them was Al-Nu'man bin Al-Mundhir. From their clans: Banu Amir, Banu Habib, and Banu Hani'. From them is Qasir, companion of Jadhima, who cut off his nose and ears and used a trick to kill Al-Zabba'. Banu Thamilah: their clans are Ja'dah, Banu Ghanm, Banu Malik, Banu Mas'ud, Banu Al-Harith, Banu Al-Rab'ah, Banu Mulayh, and Banu Muawiyah. These are clans of Namarah. Among them is Hadas bin Idris bin Jazilah. From them is Malik bin Zu'r bin Hujr, who brought Joseph son of Jacob, peace be upon him, out of the well. From the clans of Jazilah are Banu Adhb, Banu Qabis, Banu Shukr, Banu Amr, Banu Hujr, Banu Arash, Banu Qays, Banu Fihr, Banu Karim, Banu Musnad, Banu Ali, Banu Sa'd, Banu Rashid, Banu Murr, Banu Hudan, Banu Majr, Banu Hudayr, Banu Habban, Banu Ru'aysh, Banu Hujrah, Banu Jarir, and Banu Salim, mentioned by Al-Suwaydi. From them are Banu Salim of Harb. In Najd from them are Wuld Salim (Children of Salim) and their elder is Ibn Naji. From Banu Salim are Al-Hawazim and Al-Hajlah. From Al-Hawazim are Hazman of Otaybah. From Banu Salim are Al-Yahyawi, Al-Zawahir, and Al-Ruhalah. From them are Wuld Ali (Children of Ali), who are Al-Hizban, Al-Jahla, and Al-Yasadah. As for their mix from Muzaynah and Subh, they are from Qays Aylan and from Adnan. From the clans of Lakhm: Banu Abd Al-Dar; they are the clan of Tamim Al-Dari, may Allah be pleased with him. Section: On Judham, brother of Lakhm. He is Judham bin Amr bin Malik bin Adi bin Al-Harith bin Murrah bin Udad bin Zayd. This Murrah is the brother of Tayy and Madhhij. From the clans of Judham is Jashm clan, Zayd clan, and Haram clan. From the clans of Jashm is Shanu'a clan, Banu Malik clan, and Banu Aslam clan. Al-Suwaydi said: Banu Aslam entered into Banu Jadhima bin Jarm bin Tha'l of Tayy. From the clans of Judham: Banu Atib clan. Abu Ubayd said: Atib are the ones attributed to Banu Shayban. Atib bin Awf is from Banu Shayban. They are from Judham, and the hollow of Atib (Jufrah Atib) in Basra is attributed to them. From the clans of Zayd bin Judham: Banu Ba'jah clan from Zayd. From the clans of Zayd is Halba clan from Ba'jah. From Zayd is Banu Na'il clan. Al-Hamdani said: They have the river known as River Na'il (in) the Euphrates. He said: From the descendants of Na'il is Muhanna bin Alwan bin Ali bin Zubayr bin Habib bin Na'il; he was generous and noble. From the clans of Haram is Banu Suwayd clan; from them is Banu Umara clan. From the clans of Haram is Banu Asir clan from Judham, Al-Sama'inah clan from Judham, Al-Salman clan from Judham, Al-Batrat clan from Judham, Al-Darrat clan from Judham, and Banu Ubayd clan from Judham. From them is Banu Mawhab clan. From Banu Mawhab is Banu Murrah clan. From Banu Murrah is Banu Uqayl clan; they are the Uqaylis. Their dwellings are between Iraq and Tayma. From Banu Zayd mentioned previously: Banu Mas'ud clan and Ziyad clan. From their clans is Banu Rudayni clan from Zayd bin Haram. From the clans of Judham: Banu Uqba clan; their dwellings are Al-Jawf. From Banu Uqba: Wasil clan from Uqba. Al-Suwaydi said: Wasil moved to Egypt, and a faction of them remained settling around the Two Mountains and other lands of Tayy. From them is Wasil the clan known in Mutayr. From Wasil are Al-Dayahin, the clan known in Mutayr; from them is Hilal Al-Mutayri, a resident of Kuwait. From Wasil are Al-Majalisah, and they have allies. From their clans are Al-Matarnah clan; from them the name Mutayr, the known tribe, is derived. From the clans of Judham: Al-Ghawarnah clan. From Al-Ghawarnah is the group of Al-Ghuwayri, in Al-Ghuwayriyah the thigh known from Dalabihah of Otaybah. From the clans of Judham: Al-Anatirah clan from Uqba, and Banu Ajramah clan, called Al-Ajarimah, mentioned by Al-Suwaydi. From Al-Ajarimah mentioned in Za'b are Al-Bakriyun clan from Judham, and Al-Da'ajiyun clan from Judham; from them are Al-Da'ajinah the clan known in Qahtan, around Bisha.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Banu Sakhr clan from Judham; they are the ones whose dwellings are Al-Jawf. Banu Al-Harith clan; their dwellings are Mara from the land of Gaza. Al-Hayadirah clan; their dwellings are Al-Bajuf (?). Banu Aziz clan, Banu Mahrisi clan, Banu Jawsh clan, Al-Maharibah clan, Al-Mashabitah clan, Al-Hafniyun clan, Banu Habib clan, Al-Asawirah clan, Al-Ma'diyun clan - their dwellings are Iraq. Al-Ya'aqibah clan, Banu Barda'a clan, Al-Ad'aba clan, Al-Ka'ub clan. From Al-Ka'ub are Al-Ka'ban origin of Qatar and Bahrain. Al-Najahibah clan, Banu Zuhayr clan, Banu Bardus clan, Al Ufayr clan, Banu Abd Al-Rahman clan, Banu Lu'ayy clan, Banu Ubaydah clan, Shamjan clan, Salim clan, Banu Habib clan, Banu Ayyash clan, Al Wabar clan, Banu Shabib clan, Banu Dawud clan, Tabiyah clan, and Awlad Jayyash clan. From them are Awlad Jayyash in Banu Al-Harith in Al-Shalawa; they are Al-Jayyashah. Al-Hamalat clan; it is said Hamalah the clan known in Ubaydah is from them. Banu 'A'idh clan, Al-Hammadiyun clan, Al-Haydiyun clan. From Judham are Al-Barajisah clan, Al-Jarasinah clan - from them Al-Jaraysiyun clan - Al-Jadhimiyah clan, Awlad Juwal clan, Al-Khanafis clan, Awlad Ghali clan, and Atiyah clan from Judham. Al-Suwaydi said: Al-Atriyun is a clan from Judham; their dwellings are Al-Balqa. From their clans are Awlad Ghanim clan from Atiyah. Atiyah in Otaybah is from them. They are clans and thighs: Among them Al-Ghananim. Al-Hadilah clan; they are the people of Ibn Shiluyh. Al-Qasami clan; they are the group of Al-Sallat. Al-Habardiyah clan, group of Bu Sunun. Al-Khararis clan, Al-Marashidah clan, and Al-Umayrat clan. Al-Suwaydi said: Among them in Al-Balqa are Al-Jumm. From the clans of Judham are Awlad Najib clan. From Al-Hammadiyin mentioned previously are Al-Hamamid the clan known in Talmah (Talhah?). From the clans of Judham are Al-Masa'id and Al-Arqan, mentioned by Al-Suwaydi. Al-Suyuti said in his Qala'id: They moved from Hijaz to Egypt, and of them remained in Hijaz Al-Masa'id and Al-Arqan. As for Al-Zarqan (Arqan?), they are in Hanatish of Talhah Otaybah. Al-Masa'id are those we mentioned previously in Jamal. From the clans of Judham are Banu Jabir clan; from them is Banu Jabir the clan known in Zubaid in Harb. End of lineage of Lakhm and Judham. Section: On Kinda. His name is Thawr bin Al-Raqi' bin Malik bin Zayd bin Kahlan bin Saba mentioned previously. Then Kinda advised his sons who are: Wathilah, Tujib, and Muawiyah, grandfather of the Crowned Kings of Kinda. He said: "Preserve yourselves from what disgraces it, and urge it to what adorns it. O my sons: No betrayer ever succeeded, no traitor led a day of time, the generous never lived but praised, nor died poor. I know nothing more humiliating than miserliness, nor weaker than the solitary individual." It is mentioned that Muawiyah the Elder, grandfather of the Crowned Kings of Kinda, advised his sons, saying: "O my sons, excel in befriending those who befriend you, and opposing those who oppose you. Be snakes in front of your enemy and behind him, and lions on his right and left. Raid him at night when it covers, and plunder him in the day when it reveals. For his leaving you is not out of pity for you, but waiting for an opportunity against you. As for the one who befriends you, tend to his night, preserve his day, be for him a shining morning and a preventing pillar. The least of his right you must fulfill is to prefer him with good over yourselves, and shield him from evil with yourselves." They have many poems on that, left for brevity. From the clan of Kinda is Al-Hujr bin Al-Harith Akil al-Murrar (Eater of Bitter Herbs) bin Amr Al-Maqsur. He is the father of Imru' al-Qais the Poet. He is Imru' al-Qais Al-Kindi son of Hujr from Amr Al-Maqsur mentioned previously. His mother is Fatima bint Rabi'ah, sister of Kulayb and Muhalhil the Taghlibis. The Kindis were in Yemen, then they ruled Najd and its people. Their last was Imru' al-Qais; his residence was mostly in Al-Mushaqqar. Al-Mushaqqar is a fortress in Hajar Bahrain, between the river of Ibn Salil and Mulahhim. Its wall width was twenty Kisra bricks, painted with red ochre (Shaqrah), so it was named Al-Mushaqqar. As for most news of the Kings of Kinda, and the most famous whose news is known, is Hujr Akil al-Murrar, grandfather of Imru' al-Qais. They mentioned that when Al-Harith was in Al-Hira in the land of Iraq, the nobles of Banu Nizar came to him and said: "We are in your obedience, and evil has occurred between us as you know. So send your sons to settle with us, to restrain us from each other, and take for the weak from the strong." So he distributed his sons over the tribes of Rabi'ah and Mudar as kings. Each of them had an established kingdom. Kinda had a quarter in Iraq. They consisted of dispersed clans and thighs. From their clans is Banu Muawiyah clan; he is called Muawiyah al-Akramin (The Most Generous). From them is Banu Zayd bin Qays, called Banu Hind. From the clans of Muawiyah al-Akramin: Al-Shahrat clan. From Muawiyah al-Akramin is Banu Muawiyah who are in Bisha and its surroundings.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From the clans of Kinda is Banu Imru' al-Qais clan. From Banu Al-Shahrat: Kathir bin Hani', killed by Banu Harith bin Ka'b Al-Madhhiji on the day Al-Ash'ath bin Qays Al-Kindi was captured. From the clans of Kinda: Hujr Al-Fard clan. He was named Al-Fard (The Unique) because he was unique in his era; rarely did anyone resemble him in good actions and morals. From this Hujr Al-Fard: Al-Fardah the clan known in Harb. From Kinda is the family of Al-Ash'ath bin Qays; they were among the nobles of Kinda and its masters, possessing generosity and kingship. This Al-Ash'ath is the one Al-Nu'man sent as delegate to Chosroes. From Kinda is Ma'dikarib and his sons; they are among the Kings of Kinda. From the clans of Kinda is Banu Muqatta' Al-Najd. From them is Al-Miqdad bin Al-Aswad. He counted him among the Ansar; a Companion, may Allah be pleased with him, called Al-Muqanna', and his name is Nur Amr bin Muawiyah. From them is Imru' al-Qais bin Abis, who came as a delegation to the Prophet, peace be upon him. From them is Raja' bin Hubab the Jurist. From the clans of Kinda is Banu Al-Jawn bin Mas'ud, mentioned by Abu Ubayd. Banu Hawth is a clan from Al-Jawn bin Akil al-Murrar; from them is Asma' Al-Jawniyah whom the Prophet, peace be upon him, married. From the clans of Kinda is Shakamah; he had children: Salamah, Rabi'ah, and Nasr. Their mother is Ghadirah bint Khuzayma bin Tha'labah bin Udd bin Asad bin Khuzayma. From the clans of Kinda is Banu 'Ayiz clan; from them is Abbad the Jurist. From Shakamah is Abu Kaydar; from them is the ruler of Dumat al-Jandal, to whom the Prophet, peace be upon him, wrote, so he cast off the idols and images. From the clans of Kinda is Tujib. It says in 'Nihayat Al-Arab': From them is Banu Samadah clan. From them is Banu Al-Ashras; they had a kingdom in Andalusia in the days of the Taifas (Factions), in Almeria. The first to rule among them was Ma'n bin Samadah Al-Tujibi in the year 444, and it remained in their hands until the Commander of the Faithful overcame them. From the clans of Kinda is Asbah; to them Al-Hizbiyah is attributed, said Abu Ubayd. Banu Murta' is a clan from Kinda. Banu Tawiyah is a clan from Muawiyah around Bisha. Banu Al-Shajarat is a clan from Kinda from Shajar; they have the Mosque of Kufa. Banu Murrah is a clan from Hujr; they have the Mosque of Kufa. Banu Al-Rayyis is a clan from Kinda from Banu Al-Harith bin Muawiyah al-Akramin; they are the ones Imru' al-Qais praised. From them is Al-Ash'ath bin Qays bin Ma'dikarib, and Al-Sabah bin Qays who captured Jubayl, governor of Homs. From them is Muhammad bin Ali bin Al-Adbar companion of Ali, whom Muawiyah killed in captivity. From Kinda is Dhu Al-Jadayn; from them is Qays bin Khalid Al-Kindi. He was proverbial, and they were of might and power. He is the one about whom the poet says: 'If my Lord willed I would have been Qays bin Khalid... And if my Lord willed I would have been Amr bin Murshid.' From them is Al-Aswad bin Al-Arqam, and Yazid bin Farwah whom Khalid bin Al-Walid, may Allah be pleased with him, granted protection on the day of cutting the palms of Banu Wali'ah. From the clans of Kinda is Muawiyah Al-Waqqadah; named so for his many dependents. From Hujr Al-Fard mentioned previously are the four kings: Mahus, Mashruh, Hamad, and Aydha'ah, sons of Ma'dikarib. From Banu Ma'dikarib is the clan known in Hamdan. From the clans of Kinda is Al-Sakun, a clan from Kinda. From them is Ibn Ashras. From them is Muawiyah bin Khudayj. From them is Al-Jawn bin Yazid who concluded the alliance between them and Bakr bin Wael. From the clans of Al-Sakun is Banu Adi clan and Sa'd clan; they are from Banu Ashras bin Shabib bin Al-Sakun. From them is Husayn bin Numayr Al-Sakuni. From them is the Commander of the Army after Muslim bin Uqbah, ruler of Al-Hira. From the nobles of Tujib: Banu Ghazalah the Poet, and Haritha bin Maslamah; he was over Al-Sakun on the day of Mahya until the day Muawiyah was killed. From Al-Sakun are Al-Sukkan, the clan known in Abadilah of Mutayr. From Kinda are clans and thighs between Bisha, Yemen, Iraq, and Al-Sham mixed with others. End. Section: On Hamdan. He is Hamdan bin Wa'ilah bin Malik bin Wa'ilah bin Rabi'ah bin Zayd bin Kahlan bin Saba bin Yashjub bin Ya'rub bin Qahtan bin Hud, peace be upon him. It says in the book 'Wills of the Kings': Hamdan lived until his sight weakened and hearing dulled. He turned to his sons glorifying and advising them. He said: "O my sons, time wrestled your father to test him, so its days and nights tested him with three states, like three stars following each other. As for boyhood and its prime, that is the first. As for youth and its moderation, that is the middle. As for descending gray hair and old age, that is the last. As for two, they have set with what they contained for me. The third has set with what it left for me." From the clans of Hamdan is Hamdan clan and Bakil clan; they are sons of Jashm bin Jiran bin Nawf bin Hamdan. Hamdan: the clans of Hamdan separated. From the clans of Hamdan is Banu Basham; he is Abdullah bin Sa'd bin Hashid.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From their clans is Na'iz clan; his name is Rabi'ah bin Murshid bin Hashid bin Jashm bin Hashid, the clan of Masruq bin Al-Ajda'. It says in 'Al-Iqd Al-Farid': Some people claim they are from Wada'a banu Amr bin Amir Al-Azdi, but they were attributed to Hamdanah. From the clans of Hamdan is Subay'. He is Subay' bin Sa'b bin Muawiyah bin Kathir bin Malik bin Jashm bin Hashid bin Jashm bin Jubran bin Nawf bin Hamdan. From Subay' is Sa'id bin Qays bin Zayd bin Harb bin Ma'dikarib bin Sayf bin Amr Al-Subay'i, and Al-Harith bin Umayrah whom Al-A'sha of Hamdan praised. From the clans of Subay' is Umayrah clan; they are Umayrah bin Al-Harith bin Yusuf. From the clans of Subay' is Banu Amr clan from Subay'. From them is Abu Ishaq Al-Subay'i, the famous jurist. They are from Banu Amr bin Subay' bin Sa'b bin Muawiyah bin Kathir bin Malik bin Jashm bin Hashid bin Jashm bin Nawf bin Hamdan. From the clans of Amr bin Subay' is Al-Sa'bah. From them is Al-A'izzah clan, Al-Jamalin clan, Al-Madariyah clan, Al-Ali clan, Al-Bulaydat clan, Al-Salt clan, Al-Labtah clan, and Al-Jabur clan. From Banu Amr is Al-Uraynat clan. From them is Al-Suwaylim people of Riyadh, and Al-Uraynat people of Al-Barrah, Raghbah, and Al-Attar. From them in Al-Ahsa are Al-Jabr, Al-Shams, Al-Azbin, and Al-Rashud. From them is Al-Rashud in Kuwait. We have mentioned Uraynah previously in Banu Thawr bin Quda'a. From the clans of Subay' is Banu Amir brother of Amir brother of Amr bin Subay'. From them is Ajman Al-Rakham clan, Al-Da'afah clan, Al-Qad'ah clan, Al-Ayadin and Al-Ayafa, Banu Humayd, Al-Zaqa'in, Al-Mahmid Al-Suhul, Al-Ubayd, Al-Manjal, Al-Su'ub, and Al-Zahran. These are from Al-Masha'ibah from Al-Sudah in Subay'. From Subay' are Al-Qababina and Al-Mahlaf; they attach to Al-Shammasat from Al-Dhukur Al-Sudah. From Al-Qababina people of Dammam is Ahmad bin Abdullah bin Hasan. The dwellings of Subay' are in Bisha, Zaniyah, and Al-Hazmah. From Subay' in Al-Ahsa: Barrak, Al-Mahazi'ah, Al-Shu'aba, Al-Qunyan, Al-Amir, Al-Hudayb, Al-Na'athil, Al-Umayr, and family of Sheikh Husayn bin Falah people of Al-Kut. This Falah is brother of Umayr grandfather of Al-Umayr people of Al-Kut. Al-Na'athil and family of Muhammad bin Abd Al-Wahhab residents of Darin; they are described with generosity and bounty. From them is Abd Al-Rahman bin Fawzan owner of Al-Butah. From them in Najd are Al-Thabit Al-Qu'ayd in Huraymila. From Subay' are Al-Wunyan in Al-Uwaynid, and Al-Siba'a in Marat; they are from Al-Shammasat. From the clans of Hamdan is Bakil; their dwellings are between Yafim and Sana'a. From the clans of Bakil is Banu Thawr, Banu Al-Nahr, and Banu Mawhabah; from them is Abdullah bin Abbas. From them is Banu Ma'afir from whom are the Ma'afiriyun. From the clans of Bakil is Arhab bin Malik bin Muawiyah bin Sa'b bin Duman bin Bakil. To them Al-Rahibah camels are attributed. Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, said about them on the Day of the Camel poetry: 'Hamdan has morals and religion adorning them... And people of dashing when they meet and good speech. If I were a gatekeeper at the gate of Paradise... I would say to Hamdan enter in peace.' He said about them on the Day of the Camel: 'If their number reached a thousand men, Allah would be worshipped as He deserves.' When he saw them he would quote the poet: 'I called Hamdan while the doors were locked... And with the likes of Hamdan the opening of the door is attained. They are like the Indian sword even if its edges are notched... A beautiful face and a heart not fearful.' From the clans of Bakil: Harb, they are the Harbis, from Banu Harb bin Shihab bin Malik bin Rabi'ah bin Sa'b bin Lawnan bin Bakil. Banu Shakir clan; he is Banu Shakir bin Rabi'ah bin Malik bin Muawiyah bin Sa'b. They are the ones Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, meant by his previous saying. From them is Mula'ah bin Amir the Poet, and Al-Sahf bin Qays the Poet. From the clans of Hamdan is Banu Sulayh; they are Banu Al-Qadi Muhammad bin Ali Al-Hamdani Al-Sulayhi. They are the ones who upheld the Ubaydi (Fatimid) mission in Yemen. The first to rise with this mission among them was Ali bin Al-Qadi, then his son Ahmad, then Al-Mansur Abu Himyar Saba bin Ahmad Al-Muzaffar bin Ali Al-Sulayhi, then his son Ibn Al-Mansur Saba bin Ahmad, and he was the last of them. From the clans of Hamdan is Banu Khariq clan from Hashid; their lands were in Yemen. They converted to Islam. The Prophet, peace be upon him, wrote to King Hashid bin Malik bin Al-Namat, so he converted. From the clans of Hashid is Awd clan from Hashid. From them is Al-Afwah Al-Awdi the Poet. He is Awd bin Abdullah bin Qadim bin Zayd bin 'Arib bin Jashm bin Hashid. From the clans of Hamdan is Banu Nawf clan from Hamdan. From the clans of Hamdan is Awza'; from them is Al-Awza'i, and from them is Al-Awza' in Ghitan Otaybah. From the clans of Hamdan is Al-Su'ayr; from Su'ayr are Al-Sa'ran known in Mutayr.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From the clans of Hamdan is Al-Wahibah, the tribe known in Oman. From the clans of Hamdan is Al-Duru' clan, and Karab clan. From the clans of Hamdan is Al-Sa'id clan; he is Ibn Sharhabil bin Amr bin Jashm. From them is Arhab bin Ad'am mentioned previously; he is Abu Ruhm bin Mut'im the Poet. He migrated to the Prophet, peace be upon him, while he was one hundred and fifty years old. In Hamdan is Alhan bin Malik clan; he is the brother of Hamdan. From them is Hawshab, killed at Siffin. From the clans of Hamdan is Yam bin Jashm bin Jubran bin Nawf bin Hamdan. To Jashm was born: Yam bin Jashm bin Hashid bin Jashm bin Jubran bin Nawf bin Hamdan. To Yam was born: Mudhakkir and Murrah. From Al-Murrah is Al-Bishr; he is Bishr bin Sa'id bin Shabib bin Ali bin Murrah bin Yam. From the clans of Bishr are Al-Fadil - who are Al-Fuhayd - Al-Adhbah, Al-Bahij clan from Bishr, Al-Thabit clan from Bishr, Al-Jabir clan - he is Jabir bin Sa'id bin Shabib bin Ali bin Murrah. Al-Ghufran is a clan from Shabib bin Ali bin Murrah. From the children of Ali bin Murrah are three clans: Al-Ulaywiyah, Al-Jarab'ah, and Al-Ghayathin; they attach to Ghayyithat Al-Dawasir. These are Banu Ali bin Murrah. From the children of Murrah are Al-Admanan, Al-Safur, and Al-Hindi. From Mudhakkir bin Yam is Hubayrah clan, Mawajid clan, and Anazzah clan. From Al-Mawajid are Al-Muflih, Al-Salam, Al-Rizq, and the people of Ibn Nusayb. From Hubayrah is the group of Yusaq. As for Banu Anazzah, they are called: The Allies (Al-Ahlaf). From the clans of Yam is Banu Dalan; he is Dalan bin Sabir bin Nashih bin Mani'. They are from the nobles of Hamdan. From them is Malik bin Harim Al-Dalani, who was a horseman and poet. From them is Muhammad bin Malik Al-Khayrani. He used to protect Quraysh in Jahiliyyah against Yemen. The clans of Yam are many. From the clans of Yam are Al-Ajman. They are the children of Marzuq bin Ali. Due to this, he is called Amim (Ajim?), because of a lisp in his tongue: he is Ali bin Hisham. From Al-Ajman is Al-Ma'idh; they are seven clans: Al-Rashid bin Ma'idh are two clans, Al-Naji'ah and Al-Safran, children of Rashid bin Al-Ma'idh. Al-Salih bin Ma'idh, Al-Hadi bin Ma'idh, Al-Ziz bin Ma'idh, Al-Hamad bin Rimah bin Ma'idh, and Al-Salbah bin Ma'idh. These are the children of Ma'idh bin Ali bin Masawi bin Nashwan bin Marzuq bin Ali, who is Ajim mentioned. From the children of Ali bin Masawi mentioned is Al-Hubaysh. From the children of Masawi bin Nashwan is Al-Sulayman. From the children of Nashwan bin Marzuq is Al-Hithlan. From Nashwan also is Al-Mahfuz. From Marzuq bin Ali is Al-Dha'in, Al-Misra', and Al-Shamir; they are children of Mas'ud bin Marzuq bin Ali bin Hisham. From Al-Mahfuz are the people of Al-Rass, and from them Al-Assaf and Al-Adhal. From Al-Hithlan is Al-Jawfan in Al-Wasilah of Al-Washm. These are the Ajman. From the children of Hisham is Al-Arja', who are Qunaybir, and Al-Salah. These are the children of Madhkur and Murrah sons of Yam. It is said he is Yam bin Asfa bin Mani' bin Malik bin Jashm bin Hashid bin Jashm bin Jubran bin Nawf bin Hamdan. And it is said he is Yam bin Jashm bin Hashid as we presented. From the clans of Hamdan is Dahm; Dahm is the clan of A'sha Hamdan. Among them is Khayran; he is Malik bin Zayd bin Jashm bin Hashid. Among them is Awlan clan; he is Awlan bin Sabiqah bin Fasikh bin Rafi'. From them is Harim the Poet. From Banu Dalan bin Sabir bin Nashih bin Mani': Talhah bin Nasr and Zayd bin Al-Harith. Their dwellings were Hamdan in Yemen, and they dispersed in the conquests. It is told about the Commander of the Faithful Ali, may Allah be pleased with him and honor his face, that he ascended the pulpit and said: "Let no one of you marry Al-Hasan bin Ali, for he is a frequent divorcer." A man from Hamdan stood up and said: "By Allah, we will marry him; if he gives a thick dowry and begets a noble child." Ali, may Allah be pleased with him and honor his face, said: The commentators said regarding the Almighty's saying: (If you turn away, Allah will bring forth a people He will love and who will love Him; humble toward the believers, powerful against the disbelievers) they said: They are Hamdan and Tujib. Hamdan was known for might and succor, and it remains in them to now. From the tribes of Qahtan is Rufaydah; they are a large clan. Their dwellings are between Yemen and Bisha. Rufaydah used to join Janb, the clan known in Madhhij; it is in Ubaydah of Janb. This ends what we mentioned of the lineage of Qahtan bin Hud, peace be upon him. Section: The Second Category "The Arabized Arabs"

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: They are Banu Ishmael son of Abraham, peace be upon them. They were named by this name because when Abraham, peace be upon him, settled in Honored Mecca, he stayed with the Second Jurhum, who are from Banu Qahtan. Al-Suyuti mentioned it in his book and said: The age of Ishmael, peace be upon him, when his father settled him in Mecca as narrated, was fourteen years. That was two thousand seven hundred and ninety-three years before the Hijra. Ishmael married a woman from Jurhum and learned Arabic from them. She bore him twelve children. Ibn Ishaq and other genealogists said: To Yashjub bin Ya'rub was born Yatrah, to Yatrah Nahor, to Nahor Muqawwim, to Muqawwim Udad, and to Udad Adnan. This is weak. There has been much difference among genealogists regarding the duration and number. The truth is that the duration is much longer than what the latter mentioned. In summary, the guardianship of the House was with Banu Ishmael, and its keys in their hands, until Jurhum overcame them in that and seized the House after Nabit. Regarding that, Amir Al-Harith Al-Jurhumi says poetry: 'We were the guardians of the House after Nabit... Circumambulating that House, and the matter is apparent. We ruled so we became mighty, so how great was our rule... For there is no tribe other than us there boasting. Did you not marry from the best person I knew... So his sons are from us and we are the in-laws.' Until he said: 'As if there was not between Al-Hajun to Al-Safa... Any companion, and no one conversed by night in Mecca.' This poem is long, said by Mudad Al-Jurhumi after Khuza'a overcame Jurhum and took the keys of the House from them. They remained in their hands until they passed to Ghayshan. He got drunk one day, so Qusay bought the keys of the House from him for a skin of wine. Thus the proverb ran: "A worse deal than the transaction of Abu Ghayshan." The news of this story is famous. Since that is established, Adnan is the branching point of the lineage of the Arabized Arabs, from whom its tribes, clans, bellies, thighs, and virtues branched. It was mentioned in Al-Ibar and others: All existing descendants of Ishmael are from the lineage of Adnan. To Adnan was born Ma'ad. To Ma'ad was born Nizar, as came in Al-Ibar. The homelands of Banu Adnan are exclusive to Najd, and they are all nomadic travelers, except Quraysh in Mecca. Al-Suhayli said: No one from Qahtan shares the land of Najd with Banu Adnan except Tayy from Kahlan. He said: Then Banu Adnan dispersed in Tihama of Hijaz, then in Iraq and the Jazira Euphrates region, then they dispersed after Islam to the regions. The famous children of Nizar bin Ma'ad bin Adnan are four: Mudar, Rabi'ah, Iyad, and Anmar. From Banu Mudar, most Adnanite tribes branched out. They are Banu Ilyas bin Mudar and Banu Qays Aylan bin Mudar, whose name is Al-Nas. Khandaf is the name of Ilyas's wife; his sons were known by her. Ilyas had children: Mudrikah on the column of lineage, Tabikha, and Qam'ah. Mudrikah begot Khuzayma and Hudhayl. Khuzayma bin Mudrikah begot Kinana, father of the famous tribes, and Asad, father of Banu Asad. Kinana begot Al-Nadr; Al-Nadr begot Malik; Malik begot Fihr. He is Fihr bin Malik bin Al-Nadr bin Kinana. In him the lineage of Quraysh gathers entirely. Quraysh is a title for him; likened to a beast in the sea called Quraysh (Shark), or for other reasons. The gatherer of Quraysh is Fihr; whoever is below Fihr is Quraysh, and whoever is above him is Arab like Kinana, Asad, and others from the tribes of Mudar. From Fihr the tribes of Quraysh branched out. The famous among them are seventeen clans: Banu Hashim, Banu Al-Muttalib, Banu Nawfal, Banu Abd Shams - these are four. Banu Abd Manaf bin Qusay bin Kilab. Banu Abd Al-Dar, Banu Asad bin Abd Al-Uzza - these three are brothers of Abd Manaf bin Qusay bin Kilab. Banu Zuhrah bin Kilab brother of Qusay bin Kilab. Banu Tamim and Banu Makhzum bin Yaqazah - they are brothers of Kilab bin Murrah bin Ka'b. Banu Adi, Banu Sahm, Banu Jumah - brothers of Murrah bin Ka'b bin Lu'ayy. Banu Amir brother of Ka'b - they are sons of Lu'ayy bin Ghalib bin Fihr. Banu Al-Harith and Banu Muharib brothers of Ghalib bin Fihr bin Malik bin Al-Nadr. Banu Tamim bin Ghalib - from them is Abdullah bin Khatal whose blood was shed with impunity on the Day of Conquest. From Banu Muharib bin Fihr bin Malik are Al-Dahhak bin Qays Al-Fihri, Habib bin Salamah, and Dirar bin Al-Khattab, the horseman and poet of Quraysh. He converted on the Day of Conquest. He is the one saying: 'O Prophet of Guidance, to you sought refuge... The tribe of Quraysh, and you are the best refuge. When the vastness of the earth narrowed upon them... And the Lord of Heaven became their enemy. Indeed Sa'd wants a back-breaking calamity... Upon the people of Al-Hajun and Al-Batha'. A Khazraji, if he could out of rage... He would throw at us eagles and barking dogs.'

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: As for Banu Al-Harith bin Fihr, from them is Abu Ubaydah bin Al-Jarrah, Suhayl and Safwan sons of Wahb, Iyad bin Uthman bin Zuhayr, and Abu Jahm bin Khalid. As for Banu Amir bin Lu'ayy, from them is Suhayl bin Amr, Abu Dhu'ayb the Jurist - his name is Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman - Abdullah bin Abi Sarh, and Ibn Umm Maktum the Muezzin of the Prophet, peace be upon him. From Banu Adi bin Ka'b bin Lu'ayy bin Ghalib bin Fihr are Al-Umariyun; they are the descendants of the Commander of the Faithful Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him. He is Umar bin Al-Khattab bin Nufayl bin Abd Al-Uzza bin Rabah bin Abdullah bin Qurt bin Rizah bin Adi bin Ka'b bin Lu'ayy. He meets the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah honor his face, at Ka'b. He and Abu Bakr also meet at Ka'b. Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, had nine sons: Abdullah, Abd al-Rahman, Zayd, Asim, Zayd the Younger, Ubayd Allah, Abd al-Rahman the Middle, Iyad, and Abd al-Rahman the Younger. It is mentioned that the offspring are from three: Abdullah, Asim, and Ubayd Allah. The Umariyun exist to now in Egypt, Sham, and elsewhere. From Banu Jumah are Banu Husays bin Ka'b bin Lu'ayy mentioned previously. He had children: Hudhafah and Sa'd. From Banu Sa'd is Abu Mahdhurah the Muezzin of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and his brother Anis killed as a disbeliever at Badr. From Banu Hudhafah are Umayyah and Ubayy bin Khalaf, the enemy of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, Kaladah bin Asad, and Jami' bin Ma'mar. It says in Masalik Al-Absar: In Adhri'at of Al-Sham are people from them. From Banu Sahm bin Amr bin Husays mentioned previously, he had children: Sa'd and Sa'id. From Banu Sa'd Sahm is Qays bin Adi; from them is Abdullah bin Al-Ziba'ra the Poet. From Banu Sa'id bin Sahm are Al-Amriyun; they are the descendants of Amr bin Al-As. It says in Masalik Al-Absar: Of the Amriyun, there are people in Fustat, and dispersed groups in Upper Egypt having a share of the Waqf of Amr bin Al-As. Al-Quda'i mentioned in his Khitat the House of the Sahmis, that it is around the Mosque where Fustat was. He said it is the place of the Mihrab and what follows it. From Banu Taym bin Murrah bin Ka'b bin Lu'ayy, they are the clan of Talha. From Banu Taym are Al-Bakriyun; they are the descendants of Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him. His name is Abdullah, and it is said Atiq, bin Uthman. His kunya is Abu Quhafah bin Amir bin Amr bin Ka'b bin Sa'd bin Taym bin Murrah. He had three sons: Abdullah the eldest, second Abd al-Rahman, and third Muhammad, kunya Abu Al-Qasim, who was among the ascetics of Quraysh. Al-Suyuti said: In the Egyptian lands are a large group of Bakris from the descendants of Abd al-Rahman bin Abu Bakr; some in Fustat and some in the district of Dahrut of Al-Bahnasa. A group of scholars of the Shafi'i and Maliki schools emerged from them. Al-Hamdani said: From the Bakris is a group in Upper Egypt, including Banu Talhah bin Abdullah bin Abu Bakr. He said they are three factions, and the name Banu Talhah is applied to all. The first faction is Banu Ishaq. The second is Qaday Talhah (?); they are many clans, and the most dispersed faction in the lands. The third faction is known as Banu Muhammad; Muhammad is from the descendants of Muhammad bin Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him. Al-Hamdani said: The dwellings of Banu Talhah are in Al-Rajin - they are the Barjaniyah - Masqat Askara, and Batha' Al-Madinah. From Banu Makhzum bin Yaqazah bin Murrah bin Ka'b. Makhzum had: Umar, Amir, and Amran. From them is Khalid bin Al-Walid, may Allah be pleased with him; he is Khalid bin Al-Walid bin Al-Mughira bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Makhzum. From them is Abu Jahl, enemy of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him; his name is Amr. His brother Salamah bin Hisham converted, may Allah be pleased with him. From them is Sa'id bin al-Musayyib the Tabi'i, may Allah have mercy on him. Al-Hamdani said: Khalid of Homs is from Khalid of Hijaz, but not from his offspring. Banu Makhzum are among the most numerous of Quraysh in remnants and the noblest in Jahiliyah. From Banu Makhzum are a group existing in dispersed regions. He said: I have seen some of them in the Egyptian lands. From Banu Makhzum is Zuhrah bin Kilab; he had children Abd Manaf and Al-Harith. From them is Amina bint Wahb, mother of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. From them is Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him. From them is Abd al-Rahman bin Awf, may Allah be pleased with him. Al-Hamdani said: From the offspring of Abd al-Rahman bin Awf is a group in Al-Bahnasa of Upper Egypt. He said: I have seen people of them in Sayf of the land of Jazira. From Banu Abd Al-Dar are Banu Qusay. He had children: Uthman and Abd Manaf. From them is Al-Nadr bin Al-Harith; he was severe in enmity to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, captured at Badr and killed in captivity.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: In Banu Abd Al-Dar was the Doorkeeping (Hijaba) of the Kaaba from ancient times; so the custodianship (Sadana) remained in him and his sons after him. From Banu Abd Al-Dar are Banu Shaybah bin Uthman bin Abd Al-Dar bin Qusay, in whose hand is the custodianship of the Kaaba. Some of them are in Mecca. Al-Hamdani said: Among them is a group in the Egyptian lands known as Jama'at Nahar. From Banu Asad Abd Al-Uzza bin Qusay are Khadija wife of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and Waraqah bin Nawfal. From them is Al-Zubayr bin Al-Awwam, may Allah be pleased with him. He is Al-Zubayr bin Al-Awwam bin Khuwaylid bin Asad bin Abd Al-Uzza bin Qusay. Al-Tabari said: He had seven children: Abdullah, Mus'ab, Urwah, Ubaydah, Amr, and Al-Mundhir. Al-Hamdani said: In Al-Hinsayah of Upper Egypt lands are peoples of them. From Banu Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr are Banu Badr, Banu Muslih, Banu Rawaq, and Banu Urwah. Banu Urwah are Banu Ghani. He said: Most of them possess livelihoods and are people of agriculture and livestock. Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr is the one whom the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, gave his cupping blood to cast where people would not see it, but he drank it. The Razat who are in Mutayr and Al-Suhul, their blood is taken for the one bitten (by snakes/scorpions?) and he recovers; it is said they are from his offspring. From them is Banu Umayyah bin Abd Shams bin Abd Manaf bin Qusay. Abu Ubayd said: They are two Umayyahs. Umayyah the Elder; he had ten children: four called Al-A'yas and six called Al-Anabis. From the offspring of this Umayyah is the Commander of the Faithful Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him. They are Uthman bin Abi Al-As bin Umayyah. From them are Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan, may Allah be pleased with him, Al-Hakam bin Al-As, and the rest of the Umayyad Caliphs in Sham and Andalusia. The second is Umayyah the Younger; they are called Al-Abalat. Al-Jawhari said: They were named so after their mother Ablah. Abu Ubayd said: They were named so for Umayyah, and his name is Ablah, and he is Ablah the Poet. From the offspring of Umayyah the Younger is Al-Thurayya bint Abdullah, whom Amr bin Abi Rabi'ah mentioned in his poetry. Suhayl bin Abd al-Rahman bin Awf had married her. Ibn Abi Rabi'ah says about her poetry: 'O marrier of Al-Thurayya to Suhayl... By Allah, how do they meet? She is Levantine if she rises... And Suhayl if he rises is Yemeni.' Al-Hamdani said: In Upper Egypt is a group of Banu Umayyah in the area of Tanda and its surroundings, from the Ashmulin in the Egyptian lands from Banu Aban bin Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him, Banu Khalid bin Zayd bin Muawiyah, Banu Salamah bin Abdullah, and from Banu Habib bin Al-Walid bin Abd al-Malik, and from Banu Marwan bin Al-Hakam, who are Al-Marawinah. They have kinships in Andalusia. Among them are dispersed groups in the lands of the Maghreb. Then he said: They are there now. He mentioned a faction of them in Al-Balqa of the land of Sham. He said: In Al-Sha'ra of the land of Sham are a people of them. From Banu Nawfal bin Abd Manaf bin Qusay are Adi bin Al-Khabbar, Al-Harith bin Amir owner of the Rifadah, Jubayr bin Mut'im bin Adi, and Shafi' bin Darb bin Amr bin Nawfal, who is the scribe of the Qurans for Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him. It is said: The family of Nawfal, people of Al-Sirr, trace back to Nawfal. From Banu Al-Muttalib bin Abd Manaf bin Qusay are Ubaydah bin Al-Harith bin Al-Muttalib, and his brothers Al-Husayn and Al-Tufayl, sons of Al-Harith. Also Mistah bin Uthathah bin Al-Muttalib. From them is Imam Al-Shafi'i Muhammad bin Idris, may Allah have mercy on him. Hashim bin Abd Manaf bin Qusay had two children: Abd al-Muttalib, upon whom is the column of lineage. The second is Asad, father of Fatima mother of the Commander of the Faithful Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him. To Abd al-Muttalib were born twelve children: Abdullah father of the Prophet, peace be upon him, Abu Talib, Al-Zubayr, Abd Al-Ka'ba, Al-Abbas, Dirar, Hamza, Hajl, Abu Lahab, Taym, Al-Ghaydaq, and Al-Harith. Abu Ubayd said: Offspring came from Hamza and Al-Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, and Abdullah, Abu Lahab, and Al-Harith. From Hashim is the Flower of Existence and Fruit of its Calyx, our Master Muhammad, peace be upon him, the Essence of Existence and Cream of the World. He is Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Abd al-Muttalib bin Hashim bin Abd Manaf bin Qusay bin Kilab bin Murrah bin Ka'b bin Lu'ayy bin Ghalib bin Fihr bin Malik bin Al-Nadr bin Kinana bin Khuzayma bin Ilyas bin Mudar bin Nizar bin Ma'ad bin Adnan. The gatherer of Quraysh is Fihr. The famous of Banu Hashim are two clans. The First Clan: The Abbasids. They are Banu Al-Abbas bin Abd al-Muttalib bin Hashim mentioned previously, uncle of the Prophet, peace be upon him. He had nine children: Al-Fadl, Abdullah the Ink of the Nation, Abdullah the Second, Qutham, Abd al-Rahman, Ma'bad, Tammam, Kathir, and Al-Harith.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: The Abbasid Caliphs are from the descendants of Abdullah, the Ink of the Nation, may Allah be pleased with him. The first of them to assume the Caliphate was Abu Al-Abbas Al-Saffah. His name is Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Ali bin Ubayd Allah bin Al-Abbas. The Second Clan of Banu Hashim: The Talibids. They are Banu Abi Talib. Ibn Ishaq said: His name is Abd Manaf. Abu Abdullah Al-Hakim said: His name is his kunya, son of Abd al-Muttalib bin Hashim. Abu Ubayd said he had children: Talib, by whom he was nicknamed, who had no offspring; Aqil; Ja'far; and Ali. From the Talibids are the Ja'farids (Al-Ja'afirah), who are Banu Ja'far bin Abi Talib. Ja'far had: Muhammad and Abdullah. Abdullah bin Ja'far was the most generous of people, such that the people of Medina used to incur debts based on (expectation of) his arrival during the season. It says in Al-Ibar: From the descendants of this Abdullah is Abdullah bin Muawiyah bin Abdullah bin Ja'far; he rose in Fars and was pledged allegiance for the Caliphate at the end of the Umayyad state. From the Talibids: The Alawids (Al-Alawiyun). They are the children of the Commander of the Faithful Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him. Judge Al-Tabari said: He had thirteen male children: Al-Hasan, Al-Husayn, Amr, Talha, Yahya, Al-Sajjad, Isma'il, Ishaq, Ya'qub, Musa, Zakariya, and Yusuf. Offspring came from six: Muhammad ibn al-Hanafiyyah, Al-Sajjad, Yahya, Ishaq, Ya'qub, Musa, and Zakariya. Al-Quda'i in 'Banu Al-Abbas' said, citing Al-Tabari: Lineage continued in five: Al-Hasan, Al-Husayn, Muhammad ibn al-Hanafiyyah, Amr, and Al-Abbas. Most Alawid lineage returns to Al-Hasan and Al-Husayn and their descendants, and Muhammad ibn al-Hanafiyyah. Then the famous of the Alawids: The Hassanids (Al-Hasaniyun). They are Banu Al-Hasan the Grandson (Al-Sibt), son of the Commander of the Faithful Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, from Fatima daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and may Allah be pleased with them both. From them is Al-Mahdi Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Hasan Al-Muthanna bin Al-Hasan; he was pledged allegiance for the Caliphate in Mecca at the end of the Umayyad state. From them is Ibrahim, brother of Al-Mahdi, pledged allegiance for the Caliphate in Basra. From them are the Idrisids (Al-Adarisah). They are Banu Idris bin Abdullah bin Hasan Al-Muthanna bin Al-Hasan. They had a kingdom in the Far Maghreb. Idris was the first to rule, then his son Idris ruled after him; he is the one who built the city of Fez in the Far Maghreb. Then they had a kingdom after that in Andalusia. From them are the Idrisids people of Yemen. From them are the Sulaymanids (Al-Sulaymaniyun); they were Emirs of Mecca, deputies of the Abbasid Caliphs. They are Banu Sulayman bin Dawud bin Al-Hasan Al-Muthanna bin Al-Hasan. It says in Al-Ibar: The Abbasids did not cease to be over Mecca until the time of Al-Musta'in, then it went to Banu Sulayman this one. He said: Their elder was Muhammad bin Sulayman. From them are the Hawashim (Al-Hawashim). They are Banu Abi Hashim bin Muhammad bin Al-Hasan bin Muhammad bin Musa bin Abdullah bin Abi Al-Karam bin Musa Al-Jawn bin Abdullah bin Al-Hasan Al-Muthanna bin Al-Hasan Al-Sibt. These are the ones to whom the Emirate of Mecca went after the Sulaymanids mentioned previously. The first to rule among them was Muhammad bin Ja'far bin Abi Hashim mentioned, and it remained in them. From them are Banu Qatada, called Banu Dawud Qatada. They are Banu Qatada bin Idris bin Mata'in bin Abd Al-Karim bin Musa bin Musa bin Abdullah bin Abi Al-Karam bin Musa Al-Jawn bin Abdullah bin Al-Hasan Al-Muthanna. He possessed Mecca from the hands of the Hawashim after possessing Yanbu, Al-Safra, Yemen, and the land of Najd. He died in the year 610. The Emirate of Mecca remained in his descendants, then went to Banu Ajlan bin Rumaythah bin Abi Numay bin Abi Sa'id bin Ali bin Qatada. It settled finally in the sons of his son Al-Hasan, and the family of his brother's son Rumaythah bin Muhammad bin Ajlan until the year 818, and the matter is upon that. From Banu Qatada are the Emirs of Yanbu from Banu Al-Hasan bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them both. Then the Emirate of Yanbu settled in Idris bin Al-Hasan bin Qatada and his cousins Ahmad and Jamman. From Banu Al-Hasan are Banu Al-Rassi, from whom are the Zaydi Imams in Yemen. They are Banu Al-Qasim bin Al-Rassi bin Ibrahim bin Tabataba bin Isma'il Al-Dibajah bin Ibrahim Al-Namir bin Abdullah bin Al-Hasan Al-Muthanna. Their abode is Sana'a. The first to undertake the Imamate among them was Yahya bin Al-Husayn bin Al-Qasim Al-Rassi mentioned previously in the year 282. It remained in their hands until the Sulaymanids, Emirs of Mecca, overcame when the Hawashim expelled them from it. Then it returned in the year 793. From them is Al-Salah bin Yahya bin Hamza, then his son Al-Najah.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From Banu Al-Hasan other than what preceded in the East and West is what we cannot record nor enumerate. Those of them who enter the Register of Ashraf in the regions are a part from every pass. Those existing in Hijaz and Najd are four clans: First, Al-Abdal, who are the Abadilah of the Ashraf; from them is Husayn bin Ali the Sharif and those Ashraf who attach to him. Second Clan: Al-Harrah; from them is Ali bin Al-Husayn owner of Al-Zaymah. From the Ashraf are Al-Lu'ayy people of Al-Hazmah, and Al-Yabs people of Bisha, and other Ashraf of Bisha. Third Clan: Banu Jud Allah, who are Al-Jawada; they are Bedouins and settled people in Ta'if and its vicinity. Fourth Clan: Dhuwi Husayn; from them is Banu Husayn who are with Zafir between Najd and Iraq; their elder is Ibn Murshid, and they are thighs. From Al-Murshid are Al-Muhanna in Marat; from them are Al-Aftan and Ibn Khalaf. From them are Al-Suwayri people of Qasr Al-Shams; their grandfather is Udamah bin Suwayri known in the time of Imam Saud bin Abd Al-Aziz, may Allah have mercy on him. From Banu Husayn are Al-Hudhayfat from the children of Ali, inhabitants of the town of Zubair. From them are Muhammad and Ibrahim children of Hamad, inhabitants of Al-Jam'ah of Najd. From them are Muhammad and Ibrahim sons of Abdullah bin Musa bin Ibrahim, inhabitants of Al-Mubarraz in Al-Ahsa. From Banu Husayn are Al-Husayn people of Mufayjir of the villages of Najd. From them in Al-Aflaj are Al-Bishr, family of Sheikh Abd Al-Aziz bin Bishr. From Al-Husayn are Al-Hamid people of Sayh Al-Aflaj, called Sayh Al-Hamid; nothing remains in their hands of it now except a little. From Al-Hamid are Al-Dar'an people of Al-Aflaj, distinct from Dar'an of Al-Wada'in. From Banu Husayn in Riyadh and Dharma are Al-Mahmud Al-Rawati', Al-Hudhayfat, and Al-Bishr. These are from Banu Husayn in Najd. Entering into the Register of Ashraf are Al-Sa'dun people of Iraq; their number is now in Banu Al-Muntafiq. From the clans of the Alawids from Banu Husayn the Grandson are Al-Ja'afirah. They are Banu Ja'far Al-Sadiq bin Muhammad Al-Baqir bin Ali Zayn Al-Abidin bin Al-Hasan the Grandson [sic, should be Al-Husayn]. This Ja'far is one of the Twelve Imams according to those who hold that the Imams are twelve, starting with Ali bin Abi Talib may Allah be pleased with him, then his son Al-Hasan may Allah be pleased with him, then his brother Al-Husayn may Allah be pleased with him, then his son Ali Al-Sajjad, then his son Al-Baqir, then Ja'far Al-Sadiq, then his son Musa Al-Kazim, then his son Ali Al-Rida, then his son Al-Muttaqi [Muhammad Al-Jawad], then his son Ali Al-Taqi [Ali Al-Hadi], then his son Al-Zaki Al-Hasan [Al-Askari], then his son Muhammad Al-Hujjah, called Al-Qa'im, who is the twelfth; they believe in his life and await his emergence. He had children: Musa Al-Kazim and Muhammad Al-Dibajah. From the descendants of Al-Kazim is his son Ali Al-Rida, whom Al-Ma'mun made Crown Prince of the Caliphate, and he died in Al-Ma'mun's life. From his descendants is Isma'il the Imam to whom the Ismaili sect in the regions of Tripoli and others is attributed. From Al-Ja'afirah are the Ubaydids (Fatimids). They are Banu Ubayd Allah Al-Mahdi bin Muhammad Al-Habib bin Ja'far bin Muhammad Al-Mukarram bin Isma'il bin Imam Ja'far Al-Sadiq mentioned previously. They had a state in the Maghreb, then in Egypt and Sham. Abdullah was the first of them pledged allegiance in the Maghreb; he built the city of Al-Mahdiyah on the outskirts of Ifriqiya and inhabited it. From them are Al-Tahir, Emirs of the Prophet's City (Medina). They are from the descendants of Zayd the Jurist, from descendants of Al-Hasan bin Ja'far Hujjat Allah, from descendants of Ja'far bin Abdullah bin Al-Hasan the Grandson. In the year 799, it was in the hand of Thabit bin Hamadah bin Qasim bin Muhanna bin Al-Hasan bin Dawud bin Abdullah bin Tahir bin Yahya mentioned previously. Then it transferred after him to his cousins until it came to Aziz bin Hayazi'. These Banu Al-Husayn are Emirs of Medina; their followers are all Rafidah (Shia), but they do not declare that openly out of fear. The remnants of Banu Al-Husayn are dispersed with their cousins Banu Al-Hasan. From them are Al-Barraqi, Shia, and their dwelling is the village of Al-Tuwaythir of the villages of Al-Ahsa. As for Banu Ja'far inhabitants of Khaybar, they are from the descendants of Ja'far bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him. Khaybar possessed palms, crops, and rivers. Banu Anazzah bin Asad bin Rabi'ah overcame them for it, and little remained in their hands, and they dispersed after that from it. From them are Al-Ja'afirah inhabitants of the town of Al-Ahsa. From Banu Ja'far Al-Tayyar are Al-Tayayirah. As for Aqil bin Abi Talib, from his lineage are Al-Adasanah; from them is Al-Adsani, inhabitants of Al-Ahsa. Attached to the Ashraf are the children of Sayyid Ahmad in Kuwait from Al-Ahsa. This ends what we mentioned of the lineage of Quraysh. Section: On Kinana.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From the clans of Kinana: Banu Layth and Damrah, sons of Bakr bin Abd Manaf bin Kinana bin Khuzayma bin Mudrikah. And Banu Al-Hun, and the rest of the Ahabish. And Banu Mudlij bin Murrah bin Abd Manaf bin Kinana, known as the Qafah (Trackers). And Banu Firas bin Ghanm bin Tha'labah bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Kinana. About them Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, says to some of those with him: "I wish I had for a thousand of you, seven from the family of Firas." From Banu Asad bin Khuzayma bin Mudrikah bin Ilyas bin Mudar: Banu Faq'as bin Tarif bin Amr bin Qu'ayn bin Al-Harith bin Tha'labah bin Dhuzan bin Asad. From them is Faq'as Banu Hajwan clan from Asad bin Khuzayma; Abu Ubayd said: From them is Nasr bin Sayyar, Emir of Khurasan. From the clans of Asad is Hadhlm bin Faq'as; Abu Ubayd said: He was named Hadhlm for his excessive speech. From them is Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr the Poet. Banu Dithar are clans from Asad bin Khuzayma. Banu Walbah is a clan from Asad bin Khuzayma; from them is Bishr bin Hazim the Poet. Banu Sa'd is a clan from Asad bin Khuzayma; from them is Salim bin Wabisah, and Utbah bin Yazid the Poet. Banu Kahil is a clan from Asad bin Khuzayma; from them is Ali bin Al-Harith. Banu Al-Kahiliyah is a clan from Asad bin Khuzayma. Banu Al-Sayda' is a clan from Asad bin Khuzayma. Banu Jadhima is a clan from Asad bin Khuzayma; Al-Jawhari said: Attribution to Jadhima is Jadhmi. From Banu Asad, Banu Amr is a clan from Asad bin Khuzayma; Abu Ubayd said: This Amr was the first to work iron among the Arabs. He had children: Al-Musayyib, Wahb, Mu'arrad, Al-Latakh, Al-Qalib, Hashim, and Al-Halik. From Banu Mudrikah bin Ilyas bin Mudar: Hudhayl. They are a clan from Khandaf. Hudhayl had children: Sa'd, Khabab, and Umayr. Harmah is a clan. It says in 'Nihayat Al-Arab': From Hudhayl is Banu Al-Hayyan clan. He had children: Tabikha and Dabigha. From them is Umamah bin Umayr the Jurist; Abu Ubayd said: He was noble among his people. Banu Sahilah is a clan from Hudhayl; from them is Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, companion of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Banu Subh is a clan from Hudhayl son of Banu Kahil; from them is Abu Bakr Al-Hudhali Al-Subhi. Banu Tamim is a clan from Hudhayl; he is Tamim bin Khafa'ah bin Umayrah bin Hudhayl. From them is Muawiyah clan, Awf clan, and Al-Harith clan. The lands of Hudhayl are known in Hijaz, and their remnants are there to now. From Hudhayl in Najd are Al-Hidhlan, the thigh known in Al-Sa'ran of Mutayr. From Hudhayl are Al-Ajlan inhabitants of the town of Raghbah, Al-Ajlan and Al-Eid inhabitants of the town of Al-Barrah, and Al-Hajr inhabitants of the town of Marat. As for Qam'ah bin Ilyas, no remnant is mentioned for them. Section: On Tabikha bin Ilyas. They are a clan from Khandaf. The name of Tabikha is Amr. He was named Tabikha only because he and his brother Amir were herding camels belonging to them. They hunted game. An enemy attacked their camels. Amir said to his brother Amr: "Will you catch the camels or cook the game?" Amr said: "I will cook." So Amir caught the camels and brought them. When they returned to their father and informed him of their affair, he said to Amir: "You are Mudrikah (Catcher)." And to Amr: "You are Tabikha (Cooker)." To Tabikha was born: Wadd. To Wadd was born: Murr, Zayd Manat, Safiyah, Amr, Abd Manat, and Al-Rabab. To Murr was born Tamim; he is Tamim bin Udd bin Tabikha. Tamim in language means intensity/perfection. It says in Al-Ibar: The dwellings of Tamim were in the land of Najd circling Basra and Al-Yamamah, extending to Al-Udhayb of the land of Kufa. Then they dispersed afterwards into the settled lands. Ghazziyah of Tayy and Khafajah of Banu Uqayl bin Ka'b inherited their dwellings. From Banu Tamim is Zayd Manat bin Tamim, Amr, and Al-Harith. To Zayd Manat was born Malik. To Malik was born Hanzala, father of many tribes. From them is Banu Darim bin Malik bin Hanzala; they are the nobles of Banu Tamim. From them are Awf and Abu Sud, sons of Malik bin Hanzala; they are Banu Tuhayyah. From Hanzala branch clans, among them Banu Yarbu' bin Hanzala. From them is Attab bin Harami bin Rabah bin Yarbu', who was among the leaders under Al-Nu'man. From them is Ma'qil bin Qays from the men of the people of Kufa; he was with Ali and is the one who killed Ibn Samah and took captives from them. From Banu Yarbu' is Banu Tha'labah bin Al-Anbar bin Yarbu'. Banu Al-Anbar is a clan from Hanzala. From them is Sajah bint Aws; she claimed prophethood and what happened between her and Musaylima the Liar happened. From them is Banu Dughah, regarding whom the proverb ran: "Stupider than Dughah," which is their mother's name. Banu Tha'labah bin Al-Anbar is a clan from Banu Yarbu'. Banu Tha'labah, Banu Amr, Banu Jubayr, and Banu Al-Harith are called the Trustees (Umana') of Yarbu'. Al-Harith is the son of Sulayt. From the descendants of Sulayt is Al-Musawir bin Rababah. From Banu Al-Harith is Al-Zubayr bin Al-Makhur Al-Sulayti the Kharijite. From Banu Yarbu' is Banu Rabah clan from Hanzala, from Suhaym the Poet who says:

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: 'I am the son of Jala and climber of heights... When I put down the turban you know me.' From Banu Yarbu' is Uraynah. Uraynah are three clans in the Arabs: This Uraynah in Tamim, Uraynah in Qahtan who are from Uraynah bin Anmar bin Irash of Kahlan, and Uraynah bin Thawr in the clans of Quda'a. From Banu Yarbu' is Banu Kulayb clan from Hanzala; Al-Jawhari said: This Kulayb is the clan of Jarir bin Al-Khatafi the Poet. Banu Ghudanah clan from Yarbu' bin Hanzala. Banu Kulfah clan from Hanzala. Banu Amr clan from Hanzala; from them is Qays bin Khafaf the Poet. Banu Al-Zalim clan from Hanzala. Banu Qays clan from Hanzala. From the clans of Tamim is Sa'd bin Zayd bin Manat bin Tamim. He had five children: Abd Shams, Malik, Awf, Awanah, Jashm, and the sixth Ka'b. The children of Ka'b bin Sa'd are called Maqa'is. Al-Ahadhib are the family of Amr and Awf in Banu Ka'b. From Banu Abd Shams bin Sa'd is Thumaylah bin Murrah, chief of police of Ibrahim bin Abdullah bin Al-Husayn. And Ilyas bin Qatada, bearer of blood monies in the war of Azd; he is the nephew of Al-Ahnaf bin Qays. And Abdullah bin Al-Tayyib the Poet. And Abd Al-Uzza bin Ka'b bin Sa'd. Al-Ahzab is a clan from Sa'd; they are Rabi'ah bin Kulayb bin Sa'd, and Banu Al-A'raj bin Ka'b bin Sa'd. From Banu Al-Ahzab is Haritha bin Qudamah, chief of police of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him. And Amr bin Jarmuz, killer of Al-Zubayr bin Al-Awwam. From the thighs of Maqa'is is Al-Harith bin Amr bin Ka'b bin Sa'd, and Banu Mushaqqar bin Ubayd bin Maqa'is. From them is Qays bin Asim; the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, named him the Master of the Bedouins (Ahl al-Wabar). And Amr bin Al-Ahtam. And Khalid bin Safwan bin Amr bin Al-Ahtam. From Banu Ubayd bin Maqa'is is his brother Minqar, and Al-Ahnaf bin Qays, who is: Al-Dahhak bin Qays famous for forbearance; his virtues are many and renowned. From them is Salamah bin Jandal. And Sulayk bin Sulakah, the Man of the Arabs; he used to raid alone. From them is Abdullah bin Al-Saffar to whom the Sufriyyah are attributed. And Abdullah bin Ibad to whom the Ibadiyyah are attributed. These are Maqa'is and their multitudes. From Banu Sa'd is Banu Atarid bin Ka'b bin Sa'd. From them is Karb bin Safwan bin Shijnah, owner of the Ifada of the Pilgrim. Banu Quray' is a clan from Ka'b bin Sa'd. From them is Al-Adbat bin Quray' chief of Tamim. Banu Atarid and Banu Anf Al-Naqah (Nose of the She-Camel) are a clan from Quray' bin Awf bin Ka'b bin Sa'd, named Ja'far; his sons are called Banu Anf Al-Naqah. Abu Ubaydah said they are of the nobles of Tamim, and Al-Hutay'ah praised them. From them is Aws bin Al-Maqra' the Poet. From the clans of Sa'd is Banu Bahdalah bin Awf bin Ka'b bin Sa'd. From them is Al-Zibriqan bin Badr, his name is Al-Husayn; they are a great clan of Tamim. From them is the family of Haymar bin Khalaf bin Bahdalah, owner of Burda Muharriq. Jashm bin Awf bin Ka'b bin Sa'd. Banu Jashm, Atarid, and Banu Bahdalah are called Al-Jiza'. Banu Malik bin Hanzala is a clan; his sons are called Banu Tuhayyah. Tuhayyah is their mother by whom they are known; she is the daughter of Abd Shams bin Sa'd bin Tamim. It is said that Malik the Fool. Banu Rizam clan from Hanzala, from the children of Hanzala bin Zayd Manat bin Tamim; from them is Umayr bin Al-Ta'i whom Al-Hajjaj killed. Banu Yarbu' bin Malik bin Hanzala; his son is Rabah bin Yarbu'. From them is Attab bin Warqa' Al-Rabahi, governed Isfahan and was one of the generous men of Islam. And Matar bin Najiyah who overcame Kufa in the days of Al-Ash'ath. And Suhaym bin Wael the Poet. Yarbu' bin Malik bin Hanzala bin Malik bin Zayd Manat bin Tamim; their mother is Al-Adawiyah, by whom they are known. Banu Tuhayyah and Banu Al-Adawiyah are called Al-Jimar. From Banu Tuhayyah is Banu Al-Shaytan. From them is Darim bin Malik bin Hanzala bin Malik bin Zayd Manat Tamim. Born to Darim bin Malik were: Abdullah, Mashja', Sadus, Khayri, Nahshal, Jarir, and Aban. From the children of Abdullah bin Darim: Hajib bin Zurara bin Udas bin Abdullah bin Darim, who is the House of Banu Tamim and owner of the Bow. And Muhammad bin Atarid. And Hilal bin Waki' bin Mujashi' bin Darim. From them is Al-Farazdaq the Poet, Al-Aqra' bin Habis, A'yan bin Dubay'ah bin Iqal, Al-Hubab bin Zayd, and Al-Harith bin Shurayh bin Yazid, owner of Khurasan. And Al-Ba'ith the Poet, his name is Khidash bin Bishr. And Al-Asbagh bin Nabatah companion of Ali. And Nahshal bin Darim. From them is Khazim bin Khuzayma commander of Al-Rashid. And Abbas bin Mas'ud whom Al-Hutay'ah praised. And Kuthayyir Azza the Poet. From Banu Darim is Aban bin Darim. From them is Sawdah bin Bahr, who was a horseman. And Dhu Al-Hiraq bin Shurayh the Poet. Banu Sadus is a clan from Darim. Rabi'ah is a clan from Malik bin Hanzala bin Malik bin Zayd Manat; they are called Al-Raba'i'. From them is Abu Hilal the Kharijite. From them is Banu Alqamah bin Abadah the Poet, and his brother Shas.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From Rabi'ah bin Malik bin Hanzala is Al-Hantaf bin Al-Sajf, and Hubaysh bin Malik; his mother is Hatta', by whom they are known. From them is Husayn bin Numayr who was over the police of Abdullah bin Ziyad. From Banu Tamim is Banu Adi bin Imru' al-Qais bin Ka'b bin Zayd Manat bin Tamim. This Imru' al-Qais is the one after whom the town of Marat was named; it is the town of this Imru' al-Qais, not the Kindi. From them is Adi bin Zayd the Poet. From Banu Imru' al-Qais is Hisham whom Dhu al-Rumma used to satirize, and Jarir bin Al-Khatafi. From Jarir's satire: 'The genealogists count for Tamim... Four great houses of glory. They count Al-Rabab, the family of Amr... Sa'd, then Hanzala the choice ones. If a man has daughters growing up for him... They bind blame and shame to his head.' From Banu Malik, a clan of Amr bin Tamim: Banu Mazin clan from Tamim. From them is Qatari bin Al-Fuja'ah the Kharijite. From Amr bin Tamim is Usayd bin Amr bin Tamim. From them is Aktham bin Sayfi the Wise Man of the Arabs, and his brother Al-Rabi' bin Sayfi, father of Hanzala the Scribe, may Allah be pleased with him. From them is Abu Halah husband of Khadija, may Allah be pleased with her. And Aws bin Hajar Al-Asadi. From Al-Harith bin Tamim is Shaqrah. From them is Al-Musayyib bin Sharik the Jurist, and Nasr bin Harb bin Makhramah. Shaqrah's name is Muawiyah bin Al-Harith bin Tamim. From Banu Malik bin Amr bin Tamim is Banu Aylan clan. From Banu Amr bin Tamim is Mazin bin Malik bin Amr bin Tamim. From them is Abbad bin Akhdar Al-Jahdami, and Hajib bin Dinar known as Hajib Al-Fil, and Malik bin Al-Rayb the Poet. From Banu Fuja'ah are the Azariqa (Kharijites), and Maslamah and his brother Hilal bin Ahwaz Al-Habatat. They are a clan from Banu Al-Harith bin Amr bin Tamim. They were named Al-Habatat because their father Al-Harith ate food and his belly swelled (Habita). From them is Abbad bin Al-Husayn, one of the horsemen of the Arabs. And Ghaylan, Aslam, and Hirmaz from Banu Amr bin Tamim. From Banu Tamim existing today from Banu Sa'd bin Zayd Manat bin Tamim: Al-Ulayyan people of Buraydah, from whom is Hujaylan. From Al-Ulayyan are Al-Saffad people of Shaqra and people of Al-Hariq. Al-Anaqir people of Al-Qara'in, called Al-Sallum. Al-Anaqir people of Wuthaythiyah, called Al-Dahman. Al-Anaqir people of Tharmada; they are three thighs: Al-Abd Al-Rahman, Al-Abd Al-Aziz, and Al-Nasir. From Al-Abd Al-Rahman is Sheikh Abdullah bin Abd Al-Aziz. From Banu Tamim is Al-Masharifah. They are the group of Musharraf bin Amr bin Mi'dad bin Rayyis bin Zakhir bin Muhammad bin Alawi bin Wahib bin Qasim bin Musa bin Mas'ud bin Uqbah bin Sunay' bin Nahshal bin Shaddad bin Zuhayr bin Shihab bin Rabi'ah bin Abi Mas'ud bin Malik bin Hanzala bin Malik bin Zayd bin Manat bin Tamim. Al-Musharraf are thighs. From their thighs is the family of Sheikh Muhammad bin Abd Al-Wahhab bin Sulayman bin Ali bin Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Rashid bin Barid bin Musharraf. Sheikh Muhammad had children including: Hasan, Husayn, Abdullah, and Ali. From the children of Ali are Al-Ali known in Riyadh. From the children of Husayn is Hasan bin Husayn. From the children of Hasan bin Muhammad is Sheikh Abd Al-Rahman bin Hasan and Sheikh Abd Al-Latif. From the descendants of Abd Al-Latif are Sheikh Abdullah bin Abd Al-Latif, Sheikh Ibrahim bin Abd Al-Latif, Sheikh Muhammad bin Abd Al-Latif, Sheikh Abd Al-Aziz, Sheikh Umar, and Sheikh Abd Al-Rahman. These are the sons of Sheikh Abd Al-Latif. From them are the children of Sheikh Ishaq. From Al-Sheikh is the family of Sheikh Salih bin Abd Al-Aziz. From them is Abdullah bin Ibrahim inhabitant of the town of Marat. From the thighs of Musharraf are Al-Masharifah people of Al-Hariq, and Al-Masharifah people of Sudair. From them are Al-Abd Al-Malik people of Al-Hawtah. As for those attached to this lineage called Al-Wahbah, from them is Banu Barid. From Banu Barid are Al-Barrak, people of Buraydah, and Al-Barid. From their clans are Al-Wahbah inhabitants of the town of Ushayqir. They are from the town of Wahib bin Qasim bin Musa bin Mas'ud bin Uqbah bin Sunay' bin Nahshal bin Shaddad bin Zuhayr bin Shihab bin Rabi'ah bin Abi Mas'ud bin Malik bin Hanzala bin Malik bin Zayd bin Manat bin Tamim bin Murr bin Udd bin Tabikha bin Ilyas bin Mudar bin Nizar bin Ma'ad bin Adnan. This lineage is copied from records in the handwriting of famous Wahbah scholars, such as Muhammad bin Munif the Judge, Sheikh Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Salim, Sheikh Ahmad Al-Qasir, Sheikh Sulayman bin Ali, and other scholars of Al-Wahbah. They dispersed from the town of Ushayqir except for a few. From the column of this lineage are all Al-Wahbah. From Al-Wahbah remaining in the town of Ushayqir now are Al-Kharasha, Al-Bijad, Al-Yahya, Al-Jasir, Al-Fayiz, Al-Nashwan, Al-Aba Husayn, and others.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: Among those who moved from Ushayqir are Al-Bassam people of Unayzah, and all Al-Bassam. As for Rashid bin Bassam, he settled in Marat, and his descendants are Al-Rashid. Among those who moved from Ushayqir are the Judges known in Unayzah and elsewhere. From Al-Wahbah are Al-Duhaym, the family of Muhammad bin Duhaym in Shaqra. From Al-Wahbah are Al-Shiha people of Al-Qara'in, and Al-Wahbah people of Al-Waqf. From Al-Wahbah are Al-Umar people of Wuthaythiya, Al-Umar people of Marat, and Al-Fayiz people of Wuthaythiya. From Al-Wahbah are Al-Sanad people of Al-Qassim and people of Wuthaythiya. From Al-Wahbah are Al-Aydan; they are from Banu Zakhir bin Muhammad bin Alawi bin Wahib. From the column of this lineage are Al-Ma'adid from Banu Mi'dad bin Rayyis bin Zakhir bin Muhammad bin Alawi bin Wahib. From them are Al-Thani Emirs of Qatar, and all Al-Ma'adid are from this lineage. From Banu Tamim are Al-Madi people of Al-Rawdah; they are called Al-Rajih. They had politics and emirate over the people of Al-Rawdah and have a beautiful mention. And Al-Bu Sa'id, from whom is Rumayzan the famous poet. His maternal uncle was Jabr bin Sayyar, inhabitant of the town of Al-Qasab. From them is Abu Hilal and Al-Mazru'. From Al-Mazru' are Al-Mazarru' people of Al-Ahsa, and Al-Mazarru' people of Al-Arid. From Banu Tamim are Al-Man'at; from them is Al-Ashri, people of Ashirah. From Tamim are Al-Mufid. From Banu Tamim are Al-Farhah known as Al-Farhah in the town of Ushayqir and elsewhere; it is said they are from Al-Anaqir, from Banu Sa'd. From Banu Tamim are Al-Manaqir in Sudair, and Al-Fuqaha in the town of Dharma. From Banu Tamim are the people of Al-Hawtah in Burayk and Ni'am; they are the majority of settled Tamim. They are numerous thighs. Famous among them are Al-Husayn and Al-Murshid. From Al-Husayn are Al-Khurayf people of Al-Hulwah and people of Raghbah, and Al-Nahid in Al-Ahsa. From Al-Murshid are Al-Yusuf people of Tharmada, from whom are Al-Daraba, Al-Dakhil, Al-Mudlij, and Al-Zamil people of Marat. From the clans of Tamim are Al-Nawasir. From them are the people of Al-Mudhnib; famous among them are Al-Aqala and Al-Abd Al-Jabbar people of Al-Majma'ah. From Al-Nawasir are Al-Husayn residents of the town of Shaqra. From Al-Nawasir are Al-Majid residents of Thadiq. From them are Al-Hamada people of Al-Qasab, and Al-Muqbil known in the castles of Dharma. It is said Al-Muqbil are not from Al-Nawasir, but from Al-Suwaydan Qahtan; this is what their people and ancients hold. It is also said they are from the children of Muqbil from Al-Harqan, from Ubaydah, and Allah knows best. From Banu Tamim are Al-Ghannam people of Al-Ahsa. They are two thighs: Al-Abi Bakr thigh and Al-Mubarak thigh. Children of Abu Bakr: Abd Al-Wahhab, Sheikh Husayn author of 'Tarikh Najd', and Abd Al-Rahman. From the children of Abd Al-Rahman is Muhammad bin Abd Al-Rahman bin Abi Bakr bin Abd Al-Rahman, who has the offspring. From Al-Mubarak are Sheikh Muhammad bin Abd Al-Rahman, and the children of Ahmad bin Abd Al-Aziz. From Banu Tamim is the family of Sheikh Mubarak residents of Hofuf, city of Al-Ahsa; they are from Banu Hanzala bin Tamim. From Banu Tamim in Al-Ahsa are Al-Mutlaq and Al-Fayruz; Al-Fayruz moved to Kuwait. From Banu Tamim are Al-Ju'ayman residents of Kuwait from Al-Ahsa. And Al-Mani', family of Sheikh Muhammad bin Mani'; from them is Al-Sulayman residents of the town of Unayzah in Al-Qassim. From Tamim are many clans in Iraq, Basra, and Jabal Tayy Ghazziyah Tayy. Tamim mixed with the people of Al-Sawad. Regarding Al-Jaza'ir (Algeria?), no definitive text has been received that they are from Tamim bin Marwan, and Allah knows best. From Tamim are Al-Bu Sa'id people of the town of Muscat Oman. This ends what we summarized of the lineage of Tamim. Section: From Banu Udd bin Tabikha are Muzaynah bin Udd and Dabbah bin Udd. Muzaynah were named after Muzaynah bint Kulayb bin Wabrah. Muzaynah are Banu Amr bin Udd. Al-Rabab bin Udd bin Tabikha. They are: Adi, Tamim, Thawr, Ukl, and Sufah. He is Al-Labit bin Al-Ghawth bin Udd bin Tabikha; they are the owners of the Ijazah of Pilgrims, then it transferred from them to Banu Atarid bin Tamim. From Banu Dabbah Udd they are: Sa'd, Sa'id, and Basil - about whom is the proverb containing: 'Is it As'ad or Sa'id?'. Sa'id was killed and had no offspring. Basil joined the land of Daylam and married a woman from the land of the Persians who bore him Daylam. So it is said: Basil bin Dabbah is the father of Daylam.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: From Banu Sa'd bin Munabbih bin Sa'id bin Malik bin Bakr bin Sa'd bin Dabbah is a clan. They are Banu Kunuz bin Ta'b bin Bajalah bin Dhuhl bin Malik bin Bakr bin Sa'd bin Dabbah. Banu Zayd bin Ka'b bin Bajalah bin Dhuhl bin Malik bin Bakr is a clan from Dabbah. Banu 'A'idhah bin Malik bin Bakr bin Sa'd bin Dabbah is a clan. From them is Banu Abd Manat bin Bakr bin Sa'd bin Dabbah. Banu Tha'labah bin Sa'd bin Dabbah is a clan. From Banu Kuz is Al-Musayyib bin Zuhayr bin Amr. From Banu Amr bin Malik bin Zayd bin Ka'b, who was an obeyed master, and his children: Abd Al-Harith, Husayn, Amr, Dahim, Dhibhah, Amir, Qabisah, Hanzala, Khiyar, Harith, Qays, Shaybah, and Mundhir. All these are noble who led and took the quarter (Mirba'); the chief used to take a quarter when the army with him took booty. From the offspring of Al-Husayn is Sirar bin Zayd Al-Fawaris the First Chief, and Muhallim bin Suwayt and Taym Al-Rabab. From Banu Zayd Al-Fawaris is Ibn Shubrumah the Judge. From Banu 'A'idhah bin Malik is Sharhaf bin Mulaththam who killed Umara bin Ziyad Al-Absi. From Banu Usayd bin Malik is Zayd bin Husayn who governed Isfahan, and Abdullah bin Alqamah the Jahili Poet. From them is Umayrah bin Al-Yathribi Judge of Basra, who was killed. From Banu Tha'labah is Sa'd bin Munabbih bin Asim bin Khalifa bin Ya'qal who killed Bistam. From Banu Muzaynah bin Amr bin Udd mentioned previously: from them is Al-Nu'man bin Muqarrin, and Ma'qil bin Sinan companion of the Prophet, peace be upon him. From them is Zuhayr bin Abi Sulma the Poet, and his two sons Ka'b, may Allah be pleased with him, and Bujayr. From Muzaynah is Ma'n bin Aws the Poet. From them is Iyas bin Muawiyah the Judge. From Muzaynah is Muzaynah the clan known in Harb. From Muzaynah are Banu Uthman and Amr; regarding that Zuhayr bin Abi Sulma says: 'Whenever I call upon Aws and Uthman they come to me...' until he says: 'They are lions in battle and gathering in hospitality... And they fulfill covenants with the neighbor.' Al-Rabab are: Adi, Tamim, Thawr, and Ukl. They were named Al-Rabab only because they allied and dipped their hands in a handful of Rubb (syrup/paste). From Banu Adi Al-Rabab is Ghaylan Dhu al-Rumma the Poet; he is Ghaylan bin Uqbah. From Banu Tamim Al-Rabab is Amr bin Laja' the Poet, who used to satirize Jarir bin Al-Khatafi. From Banu Ukl Al-Rabab is Al-Namir the Poet. From Banu Thawr Al-Rabab is Sufyan Al-Thawri the Jurist. From Banu Al-Ghawth is Sufah; they are Banu Al-Ghawth bin Murad bin Udd bin Tabikha. In them was the Ijazah (Pilgrimage permit). From Banu Al-Ghawth is Sharhabil bin Al-Simt, whose name is Abdullah, called Sharhabil bin Hasanah. End of lineage of Ilyas bin Mudar. Section: From the clans of Mudar is Qays Aylan. There is no other Aylan with un-dotted 'Ayn in the Arabs. He is Qays bin Aylan, whose name is Ilyas bin Mudar bin Nizar. Abu Ubayd said: Qays had children: Khasafah, Sa'd, and Amr. Al-Kalbi and Ibn Abd Al-Barr said: Khasafah is the mother of Ikrimah bin Qays, not his son. The author of Hamah said: Allah placed in Qays a great matter of abundance due to its many clans. From Banu Qays Aylan is Banu Fahm; they are Banu Fahm bin Amr bin Qays bin Aylan. The Judge mentioned: They attended the conquest of Egypt and settled there. Imam Al-Layth bin Sa'd Al-Fahmi is attributed to them; his virtue is too famous to mention. From Banu Fahm is Banu Tarud; they are Banu Tarud bin Sa'd bin Fahm. From them is A'sha Tarud the Poet. It says in Al-Ibar: They are a wide clan; they were in the land of Najd and none of them is there now. He said: A tribe of them is in Ifriqiya of the Maghreb lands; they settle and migrate with Sulaym and Rabah. From the clans of Qays Aylan: Ghatafan bin Sa'd bin Qays Aylan. It says in Al-Ibar: They are a wide clan with many peoples and clans. He said: Their dwellings were towards Wadi Al-Qura and the Two Mountains Aja and Salma. Then they dispersed in the Islamic conquests. The tribes of Tayy seized their homelands there. Among their nobles are Banu Murrah bin Awf bin Sa'd bin Dhubyan bin Baghild bin Rayth bin Ghatafan. From them is Harim bin Sinan whom Zuhayr bin Abi Sulma praised. From them is Banu Isa bin Baghild, and Dhubyan bin Baghild, between whom the Great War occurred because of the horse of Qays bin Zuhayr, owner of the horse known as Dahis, which raced with Al-Ghabra', and the war was because of it. From them is Antara Al-Absi known for bravery. It says in Al-Ibar: None of them remain in Najd now. He said: In the tribes of Raghbah in the Maghreb are those attributed to Abs; I do not know if it is this Abs or another Abs from Raghbah Dhubyan? He said: Dhubyan bin Baghild bin Rayth bin Ghatafan. Abu Ubayd said: He had children: Sa'd, Fazara, and Haribah. He said: They are a clan from Banu Tha'labah bin Sa'd. Amir is in Banu Yashkur, and Salman in Banu Abs.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: It is said: Al-Shararat are from the remnants of Abs. It is said from its remnants are Al-Haddabun known in Banu Abdullah. It says in Al-Ibar: He had children: Murrah, Tha'labah, and Fazara. These are Banu Dhubyan. From Banu Dhubyan is Fazara. He had children: Mazin and Adi. Their poet says about them: 'Fazara is the House of Glory and Glory is in them... Fazara of Qays, the lineage of Qays is its defense. It has the unyielding might and the lineage which... Its men built for Qays in ancient times.' It says in Al-Ibar: The dwellings of Fazara were in Najd and Wadi Al-Qura. None of them remain in Najd now. Tayy settled in their dwellings. He said: In the land of Barqa to Tripoli are tribes of them. Informants from the people of Barqa informed me of several of their tribes. They are: Subh, Dhu Nafar, and many of them are Awlad Muhammad, Al-Jama'ah, Al-Hassasnah, Al-Sha'ub, Al-Aqibat, Al-Awasi, Al-Alawi, Al-Ghashashimah, Al-Qabus, Al-Lawahig, Al-Masawirah, Al-Ma'aymir, Al-Mawahid, Al-Mawaris, and Al-Namasah. It says in Al-Ibar: In Ifriqiya and the Maghreb are many tribes of them mixed with its people. From them is a group in Al-Ma'qil in the Far Maghreb. From them is a faction in the land of La'a and Waklah; they are two villages inside the desert. A faction of them came from Barqa and what follows it to the Egyptian lands. They settled at the outskirts of Al-Bahnasa towards Al-Jazira. Al-Hamdani said: By them the ruins of Fazara in the land of Qalyubiyya are known. From Banu Fazara: Banu Mazin; their dwellings are Qalyubiyya of the Egyptian lands. This is the last of what Allah facilitated. Following it are three benefits: First Benefit: Explanation of the branching of the thighs of Al-Wahbah, from whom are Al Thani rulers of Qatar, and definition of their clans by the pen of the scholar historian Sheikh Ibrahim bin Salih bin Isa. He said, may Allah have mercy on him: My knowledge in this is that all the tribe of Al-Wahbah gather in Muhammad bin Alawi bin Wahib. Muhammad bin Alawi is the grandfather uniting their clans. Muhammad bin Alawi mentioned had two sons: Zakhir, and Muhammad bin Muhammad named after his father; because his father died while Muhammad bin Muhammad was in his mother's womb. When he was born, he was named Muhammad after his father's name. As for Al-Zakhir, in him gather Al-Bassam bin Munif, Al-Bassam bin Asakir, Al-Rajih, Al-Rayyis, Al-Bassam bin Uqbah, Al-Masharifah, and Al-Rayayisah. The known ones now from Al-Bassam bin Munif bin Asakir bin Bassam bin Uqbah bin Rayyis bin Zakhir are: Al-Hasana and Al-Kharasha known in Ushayqir. Al-Bassam who are in Zubayqah of the land of Al-Kharj. Al-Qadi known in Unayzah. Al-Hasan who are in Ushayqir. And their cousins Al-Hasan who are in Zubair known as Al-Wanasah; they are other than Al-Hasan bin Muqbil who are in Al-Majma'ah and Harmah. As for Al-Bassam bin Asakir bin Bassam bin Uqbah bin Rayyis bin Zakhir, the known ones among them now are Al-Muqbil in Ushayqir, and Al-Duwayan bin Muqbil; for Duwayan is a nickname for Muhammad bin Ali bin Muqbil, father of Abd Al-Aziz bin Muhammad bin Ali mentioned. From them are Al-Uthaymin bin Muqbil known in Shaqra, Al-Qara'in, and Unayzah. And Al-Hasan bin Muqbil known in Al-Majma'ah and Harmah. From Al-Bassam bin Asakir are Al-Faris bin Bassam who are in Al-Tuwaym and Harmah. From them are Al-Murid bin Umar. From them are Al-Ibn Umar in Uthaythiyah and in Ushayqir.
