From them are Al-Abi Nama known in Ruwaydat Al-Khays. From them are Al-Suqayh people of Hulayfah and Daqalah. From them are Al-Suqayh known in Buraydah, Subayh, and Al-Nabhaniyah. As for Al-Asakir bin Bassam bin Uqbah bin Rayyis bin Zakhir, the known ones among them now are Al-Yusuf bin Ali bin Ahmad bin Rayyis bin Rajih bin Asakir in Ushayqir and in Al-Uyun of the towns of Al-Qassim. Al-Unayq in Al-Tuwaym, and Al-Ali bin Musa bin Unayq in Shaqra; from them is Muhammad bin Duhaym the well-known. From them are Al-Mashahidah in Uthaythiyah. From them are Al-Dubhan in Sudair and in Zubair. From Al-Asakir mentioned are Al-Sa'id bin Rayyis; they are Al-Hasana known in Shaqra and in Al-Qasab. Al-Ma'yuf in Jalajil and in Rawdat Sudair; they are children of Muhammad bin Sa'id bin Rayyis, nicknamed Ma'yuf. From them are Al-Jubayl in Mulham. As for Al-Rajih bin Rajih bin Asakir bin Bassam bin Uqbah bin Rayyis bin Zakhir, the known ones among them today are Al-Jasir bin Muhammad bin Jasir Al-Bijadi known in Shaqra and in Ushayqir. Al-Uthman bin Muhammad bin Nasir Al-Bijadi known in Ushayqir. Al-Quhaydan known in Ushayqir. Al-Khalaf bin Nasir Al-Bijadi known in Ushayqir. Al-Atiq known in Al-Qasab and in Zubair. Al-Ghamlas bin Hajji bin Uqbah known in Zubair.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: It is known today among the people of Ushayqir that Al-Bassam bin Asakir, Al-Asakir, and Al-Rajih are all called Al-Rawajih. As for Al-Bassam bin Uqbah bin Rayyis bin Zakhir, the known ones among them today are Al-Bassam known in Al-Qassim in Unayzah, and Al-Bassam in Ushayqir and in Diriyah. From them are Al-Fayruz bin Muhammad bin Bassam, and from them Al-Fayruz in Buraydah. As for Al-Masharifah, children of Musharraf bin Umar bin Mu'adid bin Rayyis bin Zakhir, from them are Al-Sheikh known in Riyadh and Atwar (?). Al-Rashid and Al-Muhanna in Al-Hariq, Al-Jurayfah, and Al-Nashwan. Al-Abd Al-Wahhab bin Fayyad and Al-Abd Al-Wahhab in Ushayqir. Al-Sa'id known in Al-Jahra; from them is Abdullah bin Sa'id known as Al-Hurr in Ushayqir. From Al-Masharifah are Al-Maghamis people of Al-Khatamah and Al-Nughaymish. Al-Baradi people of Khabb Al-Baridi from the Khabub of Buraydah. From them are Al-Khalifa people of Al-Shinanah. Al-Khalifa bin Aqil people of Qasr bin Aqil known near Al-Rass. Al-Aydan in Buraydah and in Al-Ahsa. Al-Fakhiri known in Al-Tuwaym. Al-Haraqa in Ushayqir. Al-Shayi' Al-Hariqi in Shaqra. As for Mi'dad bin Rayyis bin Zakhir, it is known now that among those attributed to him are Al Thani known in Qatar. As for Al-Rayayisah children of Rayyis bin Zakhir, from them are Al-Rayyis known in Tumayr and in the towns of Sudair. For every clan of the children of Zakhir mentioned. As for Shibl known in Unayzah from whom are Al-Khurub, some genealogists mention they are from Al-Masharifah, and some say they are from Al-Rawajih, likewise Al-Umayrah in Sudair. Al-Shibl mentioned are other than Al-Shibl also known in Unayzah from whom are Al-Shibali; they are from Al-Anaqir. As for Al-Munif known in Hawtat Sudair, some say they are Al-Munif bin Asakir bin Bassam bin Uqbah, and some say they are from Al-Muhammad, and Allah knows best. As for Al-Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Alawi bin Wahib, he is the grandfather of Al-Muhammad and Al-Haraqa. The known ones today from Al-Muhammad are Al-Abd Al-Jabbar bin Shabanah, and their cousins Al-Shabanah in Al-Majma'ah. Al-Ibn Nasir and Al-Shabalat in Ushayqir and in Al-Majma'ah. Likewise Al-Ibn Nasir in Unayzah; from them is Abdullah bin Abd Al-Aziz bin Nasir the well-known. Al-Sanad in Ushayqir, in Uthaythiyah, Al-Majma'ah, and Unayzah. Al-Khurayf bin Abdullah bin Shabanah; from them is Salih bin Ibrahim bin Mani' bin Khurayf in Shaqra, and Al-Khurayf in Jalajil. From them are children of Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Shabanah known as Al-Raqraq in the town of Shaqra and in Al-Ahsa. To Al-Shabanah mentioned are branches attached to them, who are children of Shabanah bin Muhammad Abu Musnad. From them are Al-Qasara known in Ushayqir, Al-Dahinah, and Zubair. From Al-Muhammad bin Muhammad mentioned are Al-Shabarmah people of Samira and those in Al-Qusay'ah. Al-Dubayb in Janubiyat Sudair. Al-Sawakit in Al-Zulfi, and from them in Unayzah and in Kuwait. From them are Al-Abi Husayn bin Shabarmah in Ushayqir, in Sudair, and Zubair. From them are Al-Mani' bin Shabarmah in Ushayqir, in Shaqra, in Unayzah, and in Al-Ahsa. From Al-Shabarmah mentioned are Al-Shiha bin Shabarmah. From them are Al-Shiha in Ushayqir, in Shaqra, Al-Qara'in, Tharmada, and Unayzah. From them are Al-Luhayb bin Shiha; they are Al-Luhayb in Ushayqir, Al-Humayd in Ushayqir, Al-Sallum in Unayzah, Al-Shiha in Shaqra and Al-Dawadimi. Al-Muhammad bin Mansur bin Luhayb in Ushayqir. Al-Abu Humayd in Ushayqir. From Al-Shiha are Al-Subhayn in Al-Qara'in; from them is Rashid bin Salman bin Subhayn known as Abu Ruqayyah in Buraydah. For every clan of Al-Muhammad mentioned, there are branches attached to them. From them are Al-Bijad in Ushayqir, Al-Durayfis in Uthaythiyah, and Al-Sa'd in Al-Qasab. As for Al-Khurfan, the known ones among them today are: Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Khurayf in Raghbah, he and his children. His brother's son in Al-Barrah. The children of Al-Khurafi in Unayzah, and Hasan Al-Khurafi in Kuwait, and Allah knows best. This is what I found here of the lineage of Al-Wahbah from the dictation of the scholar historian Sheikh Ibrahim bin Salih bin Isa Al-Ushayqiri, who died in Unayzah in the year one thousand three hundred and forty-three Hijri. I copied it from a poor manuscript and did not find another copy for comparison and correction, but due to the dire need to know what these papers contained, we hastened to publish it, hoping it would not be problematic for the knowledgeable, by the power and strength of Allah. Second Benefit: Praise be to Allah and peace and blessings upon the Messenger of Allah. The scholar historian Ibrahim bin Salih bin Isa said: As for what follows:

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: This is a clarification of the knowledge of the children of Ibrahim bin Mani' bin Ibrahim bin Hamdan bin Muhammad bin Mani' bin Shabarmah Al-Wuhaybi Al-Tamimi. He had children: Two, Muhammad, and Ibrahim named after his father because his father died while he was in his mother's womb. As for Muhammad bin Ibrahim, he had three children: Abdullah, Abd Al-Karim, and Abd Al-Aziz nicknamed Quray'. As for Abdullah, he died in the town of Ushayqir on the fifteenth of Dhu al-Hijjah year one thousand two hundred and forty-eight. He had two sons: Sheikh Muhammad inhabitant of the town of Unayzah, and Hamad inhabitant of the town of Shaqra. Hamad died in Shaqra and has no offspring. Sheikh Muhammad died in Unayzah on the night of Sunday the nineteenth of Jumada al-Akhira year one thousand two hundred and ninety-one. He had several children, among them Sheikh Abd Al-Rahman who died in Al-Ahsa in Rabi' al-Awwal year one thousand two hundred and eighty-seven and his line ended. Among them is Sheikh Abd Al-Aziz; his birth was the night of Monday 29 of Safar year one thousand two hundred and sixty-three. He assumed the judiciary in Unayzah and died there on the twenty-seventh of Jumada al-Ula year one thousand three hundred and seven. When he died, one of his students eulogized him saying: 'Sweet sleep is far from the eye, distant... So constantly tears pour from it. Like the state of a sick or healthy man among people... Who took poison soaking into the heart. If it is said the sea of knowledge and generosity has settled... Enclosed by a grave and empty deserts. The ally of piety Abd Al-Aziz bin Mani'... Imam of guidance hastening to noble deeds. A knowledgeable Imam, precise and verifier... Brother of trust in transmission and speech, brilliant. If the intelligent scholar hears his speech... A knowledge appearing from him, vast, confuses him.' And from it: 'Judgments with clear truth all of them... Before him, the lowly and the high are equal.' And from it: 'Scholars acknowledged his knowledge and piety... So all are obedient and listening to what he judges. If judgment baffles every judge and scholar... And a reality confronts them in their affair. I found for it a decisive chapter with the Sheikh... A light from clear truth shines for it.' To the end of the useful poem. He had several male children who died, and none remained except Muhammad. Muhammad has three male children: Abd Al-Aziz, Abd Al-Rahman, and Ahmad. From them is Abdullah bin Sheikh Muhammad, who is now in Unayzah, then died after that in the year one thousand three hundred and sixty. He assumed the judiciary of Unayzah for about ten years after the death of Judge Salih bin Uthman Al-Qadi, who held the judiciary of Unayzah for nearly twenty-seven years. This judge, Allah gave him knowledge, forbearance, and generosity; he is one of the intelligent, achieving students of Sheikh Abd Al-Aziz bin Muhammad Al-Mani'. Sheikh Muhammad had several children other than those we mentioned, and they died having no offspring. These are the children of Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Mani'. As for his brother Abd Al-Karim bin Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Mani', he had a son named Abdullah, and Abdullah died. He had two sons: Salih and Abd Al-Aziz. As for Salih, he died in Al-Ahsa and left no offspring. As for Abd Al-Aziz, he is now in Ushayqir "at the time of writing this lineage", but he died. As for his second brother Abd Al-Aziz bin Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Mani' nicknamed Quray', he is a resident of the town of Shaqra. His children are three: Abdullah, Ibrahim, and Sa'd. As for Abdullah, he had two sons: Abd Al-Muhsin and Abd Al-Aziz. Abd Al-Muhsin died in Al-Ahsa and has no offspring. Abd Al-Aziz died in Shaqra and left only a daughter. As for Ibrahim bin Abd Al-Aziz, he married Aisha bint Abd Al-Rahman bin Mani' in Al-Ahsa and died in Al-Ahsa leaving only females. As for Sa'd bin Abd Al-Aziz, he had a son named Fahd in Al-Ahsa, and I do not know today any of his descendants other than him. These are the children of Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Mani' bin Ibrahim bin Hamdan bin Muhammad bin Mani'. As for the brother of the mentioned Muhammad, he is Ibrahim bin Ibrahim named after his father. His children are five: Hamad, Muhammad nicknamed Al-Awd (The Elder), Abd Al-Aziz, Sulayman, and Abd Al-Karim. As for Hamad bin Ibrahim, he had three children: Ibrahim and Muhammad, both residents of Unayzah, and Abdullah nicknamed Arayj, who is in Ushayqir. As for Muhammad nicknamed Al-Awd, he had a son named Sulayman; Sulayman died, and he had a son named Ibrahim. They are now "at the time of recording this lineage" in the town of Al-Jahra in the works of Kuwait.

book_title: Al-Muntakhab fi Dhikr Nasab Qaba'il al-Arab
text: As for Abd Al-Aziz and Sulayman, they have no offspring. As for Abd Al-Karim bin Ibrahim, he lived in Shaqra and died. He has a son in Shaqra named Muhammad nicknamed Akhina (Our Brother). These are the children of Ibrahim named after his father: Ibrahim bin Mani' bin Ibrahim bin Hamdan bin Muhammad bin Mani' bin Shabarmah Al-Wuhaybi Al-Tamimi. End of what the investigative scholar Sheikh Ibrahim bin Salih bin Isa, famous in the Najdi lands for knowledge of lineage, mentioned, so he became the reference in it when there is doubt. We have inserted here some words for further clarification and explanation due to the distance in time between the previous and subsequent writing. May Allah bless Muhammad and his family and grant them peace. Third Benefit: Know that Al-Wahbah are united by Muhammad bin Alawi bin Wahib. He had two sons: Zakhir and Muhammad. Muhammad was named after his father because his father died while he was a fetus, so he was named after his father. Zakhir bin Muhammad bin Alawi is the grandfather of Al-Bassam bin Munif, Al-Bassam bin Asakir, Al-Bassam bin Uqbah, Al-Musharraf, Al-Rayayisah, and Al-Rajih. As for Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Alawi, he is the grandfather of Al-Khurfan and Al-Shabarmah. And Al-Mani', among whom is Muhammad bin Mani' the famous scholar. I say: He has a mention in Majmu' Al-Manqur, and he was in the time of Sheikh Sulayman bin Ali. He gave a fatwa in a famous ruling agreed upon by Sulayman Ali, grandfather of Sheikh Muhammad bin Abd Al-Wahhab. End. From Al-Muhammad is Shabanah, grandfather of Al-Ibn Nasir. Among those attached to Al-Ibn Nasir are Al-Aydan; from them are Al-Abi Hasan, Al-Shiha, Al-Luhayb, Al-Qasari, and Al-Musnad. And Allah knows best. This is what I copied from the handwriting of one who copied it from the handwriting of the historian Sheikh Ibrahim bin Salih bin Isa. End. By the pen of Muhammad bin Abd Al-Aziz bin Mani', may Allah bless Muhammad and his family and grant them peace. The one in need of Allah Almighty, Muhammad bin Abd Al-Aziz bin Mani', says: This is the last of what we found of this useful book. It appears from his work that he did not complete it, but what we mentioned is extremely useful. We saw fit to append to it, like a conclusion, three benefits authored by the scholar historian Sheikh Ibrahim bin Salih bin Isa, who died in Unayzah in the year one thousand three hundred and forty-three. One of them is in mentioning the thighs of Al-Wahbah and their dispersion in the lands, among whom are Al-Ma'adid, the clan of Sheikh Ali Al Thani, printer of the book. The second is in mentioning a thigh of Al-Wahbah, clarifying the children of Ibrahim Ibn Al-Mani'. The third is regarding who unites Al-Wahbah, who is Muhammad bin Alawi bin Wahib. Praise be to Allah first and last, and blessings and peace upon His Chosen Prophet and his family until the Day of Judgment.
